Furthermore , the RFID tag does not bring health problems to the users .
An example is European council proposed on the limitation of the exposure of electromagnetic field to the public  .
In conclusion , the use of RFID should not be totally banned but it could be restricted in some cases .
RFID serves as a tracking device and an identification system in safeguarding the safety of loved ones and public and identifying patients .
Human genetics has made tremendous leaps over the past years , and consequently made significant impact on many people's lives .
As such , the growth of genetic testing technology has initiated considerable debate over the privacy and confidentiality of genetic information .
In any cases , I advocate and concur that the individual should have the final say in whether to reveal the results of genetic testing or not .
This is due to the legislation polices that have been implemented for genetic testing as well as the moral aspects of genetic testing on individual or third parties involved .
Firstly , genetic information is not like any other medical information .
Basically , it is far more confidential as it may contain more enhanced personal health issues of individual such as determining whether one carries any defective genes .
Hence , it is rightful to say that genetic information should be kept confidential and could only be revealed by the individual .
In accordance with United States federal law , it states that such medical information should be kept confidential and genetic professionals or doctors do not have the right to disclose any information without seeking the consent of the patient .
Though , they may assist the patients by informing them the likelihood of their relatives contracting the same diseases , the final decision ultimately still depends on the individual .
On the other hand , critics may argue that genetic professionals can interpret the genetic testing results more accurately than the patients .
Thus , they can explain the implications of the results more precisely to the family members .
However , only the patients will understand the family members' different behavioural patterns .
This means that they are more appropriate to reveal the results by using a more desirable method .
As a result , they may help reduce the psychological stress on family members .
In conclusion , the decision of whether to reveal the results of genetic testing should lie only on the individual and not other third parties involved .
Any disclosure of results by third parties will be considered breaching the genetic privacy and confidentiality law and may cause unnecessary moral implications .
Genetic testing is generally used to test for any diseases that arise due to gene mutation .
Genetic testing is becoming more ubiquitous in recent years .
Issues that revolve around genetic testing are no longer limited to whether the individual should go for a genetic test but include the concerns of privacy and confidentiality .
I advocate the idea that the patients should have the final say to decide whether to disclose the test results to relative and families .
First , the law and human rights declaration recognizes the rights to privacy of the individuals .
A law , under any circumstances , is justified and objective .
The law , by no means , states that moral implications have to be considered by the individual .
In serious cases of diseases which are infectious , even though the doctor thinks that the family has a right to be informed of the risk , he cannot breach the confidentiality agreement between him and the patient .
Under the European Convention , article eight states clearly that "everyone has the right to respect for his private and family life ."
Unless there is mutual agreement on both sides , the final say should lie in the patients .
Second , the final say should lie in the patient as he knows what is best for their family members .
The patients know the different behavioral patterns of his family members and will know the best way to approach them regarding his genetic condition .
He can also decide not to tell his family members if he thinks that they might not be able to cope with the news emotionally .
In this way , the family members of the patient are protected from any emotional harm like stress and anxiety .
A doctor cannot determine how the family members will react to the news and hence should not have the final say in the disclosure of genetic test results .
In conclusion , the final say to the disclosure of genetic test results should lie in the patient according to the legal jurisdiction and to the fact that the patients understand the different personalities of their families and will have their best interests in mind .
The advancement in Science and Technology has lead to many possibilities , one of which is the ability to predict one's risk of contracting certain diseases , mostly hereditary , via the study of one's genes .
Called genetics testing , the test results , though not definitive , are highly accurate .
Hence this predictive power leads to one of the many controversies- should the individual have the final say in whether to reveal his/her results ?
Because the results could potentially be used to save lives , yet at the same time be misused , the individual requesting the test should not have the final say .
In fact , this authority should go to the medical professionals basically the physician undertaking the proceedings of the test and has the part in interacting with the patients firsthand .
Firstly , the physician is a profession that is bounded with standard protocols and most importantly the physician possesses medical ethics .
As the genetics results also apply to the family and relatives' health risks other than the patient's own , many lives are concerned and any unjustifiable reason not to disclose should be overwritten .
The American Society of Human Genetics even propose conditions whereby patient autonomy should be disregarded  , emphasizing importance of disclosure of results .
Secondly , there are laws such as Genetic Information Non-discrimination Act or the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act which protect the confidentiality and interests of the patient .
These are laws that the physician adheres to , which the patient may be un-familiarised with and overlook , despite pre- test counselling .
Thirdly , the society benefits when sound decisions are made by pragmatic , rather than individualistic , individuals .
Patients can make informed decisions and adopt healthy practices when they face the harsh truth of the results something the patient may not anticipate at first hence must be brought to picture by the physician . 
The opposition may state that leaving the decision to third party who may be insensitive and hence jeopardize the patient's chances in employment and insurance .
However , there are laws in place that will prevent such occurrences .
Moreover , the physician still respects patient autonomy unless certain conditions permit otherwise .
It is also suggested that the harsh truth of inheriting a genetic risk may create an emotional impact , especially when disclosed despite the patient reluctance .
However , the physician is present to provide advice and post-test counselling .
Moreover , the mental preparedness of the patient is most likely moulded on the pre-test counselling before genetics testing is carry out .
In conclusion , the physician should have the final say in whether to reveal the genetics testing results as they have the know-how on managing the entire situation before and after the patient is subjected to the test .
Genetic testing is an issue that mankind has place great emphasis on .
After test results are analyzed by physicians , there is a dilemma if the information should be made known to others or it being kept confidential by the individual .
Despite the fact that human rights exist , the physicians actually have a clearer understanding of the results and , the ethical and social issues that surfaces by withholding such information .
Hence , the proposition that genetic test results be made known to others by the medical professionals should hold .
Firstly , genetic testing has led to the ethics of medical professionals being questionable .
There are instances when a patient tested positive for a disease , but refuses to know their results  .
I must admit that the rights to privacy should hold .
Nevertheless , by not sharing this critical information , it creates more problems for themselves .
This is clearly true as test results indirectly reflect genetic information related to family members and there is a possibility of them inheriting the disease too .
In such a situation , the authority to release the result should lie with the healthcare professionals .
Secondly , genetic testing has also been deemed as a social issue .
It has been speculated that discrimination occurs during employment and the application of health insurance when genetic information lands in the hands of the employers and insurance companies  .
However , they fail to realise that there have been laws legislated to prevent discrimination of such forms  .
As a result , the employers and insurance companies should have the rights to request genetic information from their employees or clients directly , or indirectly from medical professionals who has a better interpretation of the genetic test results .
In conclusion , although on the surface there seems to be disturbing issues in sharing genetic information , but when observed in depth , the information when shared can be more of an advantage to the individual as well as those around him .
Eventually , the stand that test results should be made known to others by the medical professionals should hold .
The use of the technology such as radio frequency identification in tracking people has been heatedly discussed recently due to privacy and security concerns .
Nevertheless , these concerns are outweighed by its pros due to the benefits it brings in ensuring safety of loved ones , public as well as identifying patients .
Hence , I strongly agree that surveillance technology such as RFID should be used to track people .
Firstly , RFID can ensure the safety of loved ones .
In case of kidnapping , those who had RFID implanted can be easily located by RFID readers .
For elders who suffer from memory loss , RFID can provides their identities once they are found lost their way home .
Secondly , RFID can ensure the safety of public .
By implanting RFID tags on prisoners , their movements can be monitored and their location can be easily spotted should they escape .
It can also be used on ex-convicts to track their movements and prevent them from committing crimes again .
Thirdly , RFID helps to identify patients .
A RFID tag which contains patients' complete medical history can be implanted to enable treatments by doctors according to their conditions .
Furthermore , RFID tags help to prevent wrong prescription of medicine and any delay treatments which will endanger the lives of patients  .
There are some arguments about the disadvantages of RFID .
Firstly , people argue that RFID tagging will infringe one's privacy .
However , this is not true as the existing rules and legislations are able to cope with the development of RFID and protect users' privacy .
For example , the Data Protection Directive and the Privacy and Electronic Communications Directive had been set up in Europe to provide security for privacy and data security .
Another argument is that RFID tag may exert negative health effects to the users .
Nevertheless , the relatively low power of RFID actually gives minimum health risk comparing to other wireless applications such as mobile communications and broadcasting .
Moreover , World Health Organization's research also shows that under certain limits , electromagnetic magnetic field from RFID will not incur any negative health effects  .
In conclusion , surveillance technology such as RFID should be used to track people due to its advantages in ensuring the safety of loved ones , public and also identification of patients .
Medical advances in technology have made it possible to detect if one has genetic disease through genetic testing .
Genetic testing can be defined as the analyzing of one's DNA to detect a possible risks in contracting genetic disease .
This brought about many debate on the ethical and law issues on whether the individual have the final say in revealing the genetic testing results .
Due to privacy and effects of emotional stress , the individual should have the final say .
Firstly , rights to privacy are recognized in many legal jurisdictions  , especially in regards to personal information , such as genetic testing results .
Laws have been implemented to protect the confidentiality of such personal and sensitive information .
Therefore , due to law issues , only the individual has the right to decide whether or not to reveal their personal information .
Secondly , there will be emotional stress experienced by relatives , if results are revealed unnecessarily .
For example , letting parents know about the genetic risks may cause them to have a guilty conscience , they may feel responsible for passing a genetic mutation on to their child .
However , there is a common misconception that being tested positive means that they will definitely get sick .
This is not necessarily going to happen as many other factors are needed like non-genetic risks such as smoking to occur as well .
Therefore , revealing of result could be redundant if relatives do not have non-genetic risks , but instead create undesirable emotional stress for the relative .
So , the individual could first observe for any signs of symptoms of the genetic disease the relative may have , such as deformity or behavior problems , before deciding whether or not to tell .
In this case , third parties such as doctors should not reveal , as doctors are usually more concerned of alerting the person of the possible chances of contracting the genetic disease , rather than the possible negative impacts this news may bring to the person .
In conclusion , due to the law issues and the possible undesirable emotional stress by relatives , the individual should have the final say in revealing the results , as it is their personal information , and that they understand the relatives emotionally better .
Tracking of individual's movement using RFID technology is make possible when it is used in a combination with Global Positioning System technology , as proposed by RFID vendors .
A person's movements can be tracked if the RFID tag is associated with a person .
The RFID tag could be tag in an article of clothing or under the skin in some parts of the body and it could also serve as an identifier for the person wearing it .
RFID should not be banned as it brings many benefits to our lives .
There are many advantages of using RFID technology to track people's movement .
Firstly , companies/family members could leverage on this RFID technology to locate their loved ones/employees if they were missing or working in dangerous environment .
Secondly , in hospital , a positive patient identification system uses radio frequency identification , RFID , to identify patients can led to fewer patient misidentification .
Patient misidentification has been the leading causes of medical errors and medical malpractice , posing a serious risk to patient safety .
Thirdly , monitoring of RFID tagged convicts in prison can prevent possible prison break .
In addition , RFID tagged offenders that are serving their term in the community this can help to enforce their home curfews .
It is often argued that the implantation of RFID is a violation of privacy .
However in some cases like working in a dangerous environment , safely is prioritized over privacy violation .
Furthermore , the tags can be deactivated to prevent tracking if there's a need .
There are also worries over leaked confident information through RFID tags .
However , the tags can be encrypted and cleared of information before discarding .
Finally , there are health concerns over exposure to electromagnetic fields , EMF , from the usage of RFID .
But guidelines in recommended limits of EMF exposure have been adopted internationally to prevent any known negative health effects . 
In conclusion , tracking of people's movement using RFID technology should not be banned as its benefits heavily outweigh the downsides it might bring .
Advancements in technology have allowed the inventions of new devices that have helped improve lifestyles and bring about much convenience in our lives .
Surveillance technology such as the Radio Frequency Identification is one example .
It has made tracking people a simpler task .
Hence , it should not be banned due its benefits .
RFID is an essential tool used for tracking of people .
It can be used in various situations .
In hospitals , RFIDs serve as a means for tracking of patients as well as indentifying them .
Instead of having to go through long procedures , one's personal details , medical histories and other information can be obtained through the use of RFIDs .
This reduces time taken to track down these details and hence makes procedures simpler .
It also allows for the tracking of patients when they are lost .
This is especially the case for elderlies suffering from illnesses such as dementia who tend to lose their way .
Hospital staff and family members can thus easily track down the locations of their loved ones with the use of the RFID .
RFIDs are also used in monitoring crimes and to keep our society safe .
Through the use of RFIDs , escaped convicts can be easily traced .
Locations of ex-convicts can also be known so as to track their daily activities .
It also makes things easier for the police and government agencies to locate them should they engage in a crime .
Hence safety of the society in ensured .
Alternatively , RFIDs are a beneficial tool for convicts as it gives them a chance of entering society again .
This is because the police would be able to track the locations of the convicts and hence would be more willing to allow these convicts out of prison and into society . 
However , there are also downsides to the use of RFIDs .
The main issues are that concerning privacy and health .
The use of such tracking device would mean that the locations and actions of the person will always be known .
Hence the person might feel that he is always being watched and would not have the freedom to do whatever he wants .
Health is also a concern as the implants of RFID into the body might lead to complications and hence cause health problems .
Nonetheless , these problems can be solved with advancing technology .
Data protection technology has already been put in place to ensure that privacy of individuals is not compromised .
Restrictions can also be made to prevent leakages .
With regards to health concerns , precautionary measures can be put in place to ensure the safety of the human implants .
Operations can be carried out with extra care to reduce the risk of complications .
In conclusion , RFIDs should not be banned as it can benefit us widely in many ways .
Despite the disadvantages it may pose , these can be offset with appropriate actions put in place .
Hence , we should not totally shun away from the use of RFID to track people but put in place measures to overcome the problems so as to ensure its optimal use .
Today , Radio Frequency Identification technology has been used almost worldwide .
Many countries are developing this technology with positive anticipation of its useful applications and benefits .
However , the use of RFID in tracking people has brought about many controversies .
Nevertheless , the use of RFID technologies to track people is essential in today's society as it is effective in locating people .
Therefore , the use of RFID to track people should not be banned .
In conclusion , we should not ban RFID technologies to track people as there are many benefits and its use as an effective measure to locate individuals during times of emergencies .
In recent years , the aging process has affected many countries as the life expectancy of people has increased .
This is due to countries becoming more affluent and thus have better living environment and are also more educated to be conscious of their health .
However , living longer also means the need to depend on others as aging will weaker a person physically and thus results in a person unable to contribute to the society .
In order to ease the aging process such that the elderly can aged without being neglected and also in comfort , research and development and policies have been implemented .
To a large extent , these have helped to ease the aging process through investing in healthcare for elderly , giving financial aids to the elderly and also enhancing the psychological well being of the elderly .
Firstly , Governments are setting aside more funds for healthcare to meet the growing demand of the elderly .
In Singapore , $4 billion was committed over 5 years to expand the healthcare infrastructure which includes redevelopment of older hospitals and also building of 2 new hospitals .
Healthcare professionals like nurses are also trained to be able to handle more complicated procedures as compared to the past  .This provide quality healthcare for elderly in a high standard of living environment .
It may be costly to implement these policies but it is necessary as in future the aging population is projected to soar .
In Japan , it is expensive to create and own a nurse robot but it is necessary as in future there will be lack of human resources to take care of the elderly .
Such technology will allow elderly to be self equipped to take care of themselves which is vital in current competitive society where their children will be overload with work to take care of them .
Secondly , the financial aids come up by the policies makers also manage to ease the aging process .
Governments help to reduce the burden of the elderly by subsidizing healthcare , giving financial aid and also enforcing the people to save for retirement .
In Singapore , elderly are entitled to a subsidy of 75 per cent of the fees charged at polyclinics and even free medical service for frail or disabled elderly .
However , some may argue that the financial benefits may still be inadequate as elderly may need long term medical treatment and take longer time to recover .
Also , elderly may abuse the medical services when it is provided through financial aid .
Thus , to counter these problems there is also the Central Provident Fund which consists of compulsory medical savings in Medisave , health insurance in MediShield and government aid in Medifund to make the people save for their own retirement .
This will lighten the financial burden of the elderly easing the aging process as they can retire with more security and less worries .
However , Critics of this position point out that there are also policies that have not helped to ease the aging process .
This is particularly the case for policies that tackle on increasing birth rate .
By increasing birth rate , there will be more productive population who can generate income to support the future aging population .
For example , the baby bonus scheme in Singapore was ineffective as the birth rate remains at 1 .28 .
The attractive financial incentives like getting cash gift of up to $4 ,000 each for the 1st and 2nd child and $6 ,000 each for having a 3rd and 4th child and also paid maternity leave of 4 months were not enough to make people wants to have more children .
This can be due to lifestyle of Singaporeans like having long working hours and high standard of living , thus they prefer not to have any children .
As long as government considers solution to these issues like encouraging working from home , the policy may be more effective .
If these policies were successful , it will definitely ease the aging process .
In conclusion , current policies have helped to ease the aging process in many different areas .
In the coming years , more countries will also be facing this problem and thus different types of research and development as well as policies should be explored to prepare for the future .

There should be a limit on public spending on the aged so that money could be diverted to other areas of the country's development is a suggestion that should be implemented in order to combat the rising cost of healthcare for the elderly .
With the rapid growth of the elderly population for example in a country like Singapore , where the median age is expected to hit 41 years old from the present 36  , increasing public spending in healthcare could further strain the government's expenditure as more money need to be poured in to cater to the growing numbers of elderly in the country .
There are several factors that explains the need to limit public spending on elderly healthcare .
Government needs to focus the spending on more important sectors first like economic development before worrying about healthcare for the elderly .
As Friedland and Summer suggested , with more economic growth , the country will be able to have more choices and more resources to invest into the elderly healthcare sector .
This move will be beneficiary in the long run as it does not only ensure that the country is progressing economically , it is also securing a brighter future for the healthcare sector as more money could be spent on it in the long run .
In contrast , if the government decides to cut back spending on economic development and rather channel it into the elderly healthcare sector , tougher choices like tax increase have to be made in the future if the economic development is unable to sustain the rise in healthcare spending .
For example , assume that the government has 100 dollars and it has 2 choices of either investing it for 2 times the return or spending it on healthcare .
Assume that the government decides to invest all of the 100 dollars at first and gets 200 dollars in return .
The government can now choose to allocate some money into healthcare , invest the remaining money and as time goes by , not only the government will be earning more profits but the healthcare will be getting bigger allocation .
However , should the government decides to spend all of the 100 dollars into healthcare , there will be no profits and the government will also suffer a deficit .
Secondly , public spending on elderly healthcare should only be limited to elderly who really need it to prevent abuse by other citizens .
If there are no limits implemented , the normal citizens could abuse the system by using it indiscriminately and denying the rights of healthcare to truly needy patients .
An example could be seen in the United Kingdom where healthcare is fully subsidized by the government .
People would go to the doctor for even the smallest discomfort , causing doctors to waste time on non critical care and forsaking those that need immediate attention  .
This may in turn cause a clog up of cases where there will be more patients waiting longer for their operation reducing the quality of the healthcare sector  .
Besides encouraging abuse , increased spending in healthcare for the elderly will also cause an increase in taxpayers' money to subsidize the cost , placing a heavier burden on the people .
This could probably cause a public reprisal as the current economy crisis has yet to fully subside and the government should instead focus on recovering the country's economy first .
Public spending on the elderly should therefore be limited to those with chronic conditions or need immediate attention who cannot afford the cost of healthcare to avoid abuse and increase of taxpayers' money .
Finally , the responsibility of taking care of the elderly should first rest on the children , not the government , if the elderly has any working child .
Some might argue that it is the government's duty to look after the welfare of its citizens , but if the government were to look after all of the elderly without the help of the children , it would certainly cost the government an enormous amount of time and money .
The government needs to first concentrate on more important matters regarding the country for example in issues regarding national safety , trade , education , international relations and defense to ensure that the nation's interests is safeguarded and not act as a nursery home for the old .
Public spending on elderly healthcare must not be raised to compensate for the failure of children to look after their parents .
Children should be taught the importance of filial piety since young to ensure that they do not abandon all of their responsibility of taking care of their parents when they are old .
The government could also enact a law to compel children to support their parents if the children are capable and the parents are in need .
An example would be the Maintenance of Parents Act in Singapore , where parents could lawfully demand support from their child in court .
In conclusion , there are many reasons on why and how public spending on elderly healthcare should be limited to allow government to channel the money to other areas of development .
While healthcare for the elderly is still important , however governments must ensure that other important areas will not get neglected as well .
Ageing population is a serious problem faced by many developed state .
It is mainly caused by the increased number of elderly and the drop in birth rate .
The ageing population is creating many social problems such as health problems , high government expenses and high income taxis , which are stressing the young workers and the aged people .
Many states such as the US , the UK , Japan and Singapore start to implement various policies such as increasing child birth rate , saving plans for elderly and health care policies to ease the ageing process .
However , most of these policies tend to be ineffective in easing the ageing process because they either have their limitation or fail to solve the social problems behind the ageing process .
This essay is going to examine the limitation and the problem ignored by those current policies .
Health care policies can be found in many developed countries in easing the ageing process to a very limited extent , because they creates social burden and fail to service minorities most of the time .
For example , the UK has tried to make the nation to become welfare state , but this leaves heavy tax burden to the working class and created low working incentive for the workers .
It shows that medical policies must be planned well to provide health care to people who really need it .
For example , Japan has introduced medical service , which allows its citizens to save for their personal medical account so that we can use the money when they fall sick in their old age .
Similarly , Singapore has introduced same kind of policies call Medi-save and Medi-shield .
However , these policies cannot help those people who have long term disease because these diseases requires huge amount of money to cure .
Ironically , the World Health Organization has released a report in year 2006 which showed that the number of people who have long term disease such as heart disease and cancer is increasing sharply .
The data has also showed that stressful working life is contributing to the poor health of the people .
Moreover , the minorities who do not have proper job or income do not have a medical care account will not be taken care by the health service .
They will be having nothing to rely when they fall sick .
Therefore , the health care policy in most developed countries should be improved to help those patients with long term disease and those who are neglected .
The baby bonus policy also has its limitation in easing the ageing process through increasing the birth rate to support the elderly .
Today , both two leading states such as Japan and Singapore in the area of slowing down the ageing population have implemented "Baby Bonus Policy" .
Basically , families that give birth to more than one child will get economic support from child birth rate and ease the ageing process .
This is because the fact that many elderly couples only have one child to breed them and this always puts a heavy burden to the child .
Hence , with more children , more economic support could be provided and the old parents could be taken care better .
However , the "Baby Bonus Policy" does not work well although almost everyone aware its benefit .
For example , Singapore's birth rate is 1 .28 , which is the lowest in the world .
This is because firstly , the stressful social environment that forces couples to put their time and effort in their work , so that they are unable to spend time with each other .
Secondly , getting more salary through longer working hours makes life much easier than appealing for limited economic aids after having many children .
Thus , government fails to notice the two root of the evil .
Therefore , baby bonus policy could not increase the birth rate effectively in easing ageing process .
The modern society today is fulfilled with modern values that lead to the ageing population , thus caused the some government policies to become ineffective in easing the ageing process .
Many states have introduced housing policies , which allow the young couples to live near their parents or giving priority in purchasing house to those people who have married .
This allows the couples to take care each other especially when they are old , or to take care their parents when they are still young .
However , the states fail to realize that people's value towards family is changing today .
The family bonding in most western society is very weak and the young generation does not really have a sense of filial piety in their head .
Also , the stressful working market created by capitalism today is taking away too much time and effort from people so that they cannot spend them with their family , or even cannot think of having a family .
It creates modern value that allows people of opposite sex to live together without having a family .
So , what if people do not get married ?
What if the idea of family is vanished ?
What if the young no longer care about their parents ?
If all these assumptions occurred , the housing policy therefore will not be relevant at all .
Hence , besides housing policies , the governments should also raise the awareness of having strong family bonding .
In conclusion , most of the current policies in easing ageing process have their limitation or ineffective .
The fundamental problem is because the states fail to realize the social problems behind , which contributed to the stressful ageing process .
Hence , in order to ease ageing process , the policies should be designed to solve the root of the evil rather than just focus on the surface of the problems .
Population aging , as stated in the introduction of the report World Population Aging: 1950-2050 is the process by which older individuals become a proportionally larger share of the total population .
It was at first experienced by the developed countries , but now taking place around the globe .
Why is our world aging ?
This can be explained through two main factors .
Firstly , the increased of longevity as the elderly are leading longer lives .
A special report from Economist .com stated that average life expectancy for the whole world was only 30 years during the 1990s , and the rich countries under 50 .
However , the figures have each increased to 67 and 78 , and it has no signs of stopping .
The next factor contributing to the aging phenomenon is the declining of birth rates as people tend to have lesser kids than the previous years .
Therefore , as this phenomenon poses a certain threat to the development of a country , many governments have produced policies and initiatives to ease the aging process .
Nevertheless , the strategies taken do not seem to help ease the aging process .
Between the two significant contributing factors to this phenomenon , declining fertility is likely to hold primary responsibility for the aging global population .
As a result , new policies are now introduced to increase the birth rate .
For instance , the "Stop at two" policy that was once carried out in Singapore is now replaced by "Three , or more if you can afford it" policy , together with other incentives .
Despite these measures , the birth rate of Singapore has not increase significantly  .
The "Stop at two" policy had been so successful that couples in Singapore saw that they can have a better standard of living with a smaller family .
Educated women prefer to pursue their careers before getting married , thus women have a sense of insecurity in losing their job when they have to take maternity leave or when they are about to give birth to their child .
Other than that , educated women do not just want to be successful in their careers , but also a good mother .
Therefore , by having a small family , a woman may be able to be more attentive to each and every child , in terms of education , values , and overall well being , so that the children will be able to survive in the competitive world ahead of them .
As we grow older , our body turns weak and so , we tend to face difficulties in conducting normal activities in daily life .
The decline performance of the body limits the ability of the aged to care for themselves .
But , we are now living in a world surrounded by all sorts of advance technology .
It has improved our quality of life in many ways , especially the field of medical science .
High awareness for healthcare among elderly people allows them to seek professional help such as undergoing kneecap replacement surgery to ease the pain of arthritics .
Their children are also willing to finance the medical bill as there are government policies to cover the spending .
For instance , in Malaysia by paying your parents medical bill , you are able to claim up to RM1000 .
This is a government policy to encourage filial piety .
However , this raises an implication that the upper class and middle class people who are likely more easily to access information will use this advantage .
This , in turn will create a misguide impression that medical fees of the elderly are high , resulting in the debate between the government and policy makers whether to limit healthcare spending on the aged or not .
Thus , the welfare of those who are really in need is also neglected .
Some may argue that , the measure of increasing the retirement age should be able to reduce the negative effects of the aging population .
It is true that by letting the elderly people carry on working can increase manpower in labor markets simultaneously letting them increase their savings to support themselves during old age .
However , are employers willing to do so ?
Employers tend to hire the inexperienced young people in order to save money .
It is also a common mindset that young people have a higher level of work productivity in contrast to the elderly people .
In some cases , employers have the notion that employing the aged , the setting of the workplace might have to undergo some changes to accommodate to the needs of the elderly .
In short , life today is not similar to the past , challenges lies ahead waiting for us to overcome .
The effects of the aging population maybe exaggerated , but we should not lack foresight and neglect it .
Therefore , government and policy makers have to put more effort to ease the aging process as the elderly are still experiencing inadequate protection .
Singapore is currently a develop country .
Currently the investment in both the Marina bay and resort world at Sentosa will bring in more income to Singapore .
35000 new jobs will be created and expected to bring in an estimated 1 .5 billion annual boost for GDP in the country  .
Hence money is still needed for the country development in order to maintain its world class standard which is important for the growth of the country .
Despite that money is important for the growth of Singapore the current ageing problem must still be dissolve .
Citizen is the most valuable asset of a country .
In order for the development in Singapore to prosper , money is necessary to solve the problem of ageing population .
In order to encourage elder dependency , the government introduces central provident fund in 1955 .
It was a compulsory saving plan for the work force .
Every month both the employer and the employee contribute to the account .
This is to ensure that individuals will be able to take care of themselves when they grow old .
The money can also be used to pay for medical cost incurred related to health .
Despite the introducing of the central provident fund , the aged population feels that it was insufficient for them to retire .
Having better medical facilities and better standard of living , people live longer now .
In 2008 , the lifespan of Singaporeans has increase making the average life expectancy to become 80 compared with 61 in 1957  .
Hence funds are needed to prepare for the ageing population who live longer now .
Money is needed to encourage elders to work longer and lifelong learning .
For example incentives are given to company like MacDonald who employ retired workers .
Trainings are given at subsidies rate for workers to upgrade themselves , to remain competitive in the workforce .
Children are encouraged to take care of their parents .
For example , housing grants are given to encourage children to stay near to their parents .
The government had increased the housing grants from $30000 to $40000  .
New condominium units are built with two units on each level to encourage children to stay with their parents .
Even though government encourages children to take care of their parents , there are still cases where parents sue their children for not taking care of them .
Singapore government had passed the maintenance of parents act to make children responsible for their parents .
In cases where the elder do not have any children or saving left , money is also needed to cater for their daily expenses , housing and medical expenses .
Over the last 50 years aging population was considered as a big problem that influenced western countries economic development .
However , during the next 50 years there will be a dramatic increase in aged and it is inevitable for Asian countries to face this challenge from now on .
To date , aging population whose age is above 5 comprise 14 percent of the world .
According to the survey done by United Nations , aging population in Asia is estimated to increase by 314 percent , from 207 million to 857 million in 2050 and among those sub regions East Asia will suffer most .
Japan is still the country with largest amount of and most rapidly growing aging population .
Both china and Singapore are anticipated to become the second right after Japan in 30 years and aged above 65 will make up 20 percent of the total population .
Moreover , the rate of birth kept falling down and family will have less adult children than they had in the past , which puts more burdens together with aging population to the government to deal with .
So it has been a controversial issue that whether government shall cut public spending on the aged and divert to other areas of economic development to secure stable productivity and GDP .
It looks aging population will become a worse problem if current low-level government spending is going to be cut further .
However , taking all the advantages and disadvantages of this policy from the angle of the future into account , there will be more effective ways to handle this challenge rather than directly or indirectly giving "fish" to the elderly , so it will be necessary for the government to limit public spending on the aged .
There is not dispute that the average age is climbing up continuously as it is impossible to prevent people from getting old , which is the most outstanding but only one part of the features of aging population .
It is more important to pay attention to other trends and characteristics of aging population in order to solve this problem it in some other ways .
One of the biggest factors that the aged may causes excessive burden on economic development is the less support to the family from their adult children as a consequence of less birth rate and higher child bring-up fees .
For example , there has been a baby booming period between 1947 and 1949 in Japan but since 1949 the total fertility rate started to fall , from 4 .54 to 2 .04 per woman in less than 10 years and from 2 .14 to only 1 .29 nowadays .
The same kind of situation is also confronted by Singapore , china , Thailand , South Korean and other Asian countries .
On the other hand , the number of adult children who are willing to live with their parents fell instead of rising .
The proportion of Japanese elderly people living with their adult children fell from 80 percent in 1950 to 50 percent in 1990 , in south Korean from 78 percent in 1984 to 47 percent in 1994 .
Thus it will be more essential for the government to emphasize the responsibility that adult children bear to support the family rather than directly give financial support to the aged , which will in turn lay more tax burdens on the working group .
In other words , making the adult children actively support their parents will be better than passively pay tax .
In some relatively politically stable regions like Singapore , it is good for the government to enact the laws for the adult children to provide family support .
In addition to getting support from adult children , it is identically important to give more employment opportunities or put off the mandatory retirement ages for the elderly , which is also a good method to ease the rapid productivity downturn as people tend to live longer than before .
Similar to the problem of adult children , although the number of aging population keeps rising , the amount of old people who could get chance to work either full time or part time tends to fall due to economic and social changes that less employers want to hire old labor - from 38 percent of the population 65 and above in 1950 to 25 percent in 2000 and 22 percent in 2010 by the survey from United Nations .
This opposite direction of number of aged and working group affects the economic productivity to a great extent .
So the government's task is to make more policies concerning both the mandatory retirement age and employers' restriction .
For instance , hiring the elderly as part-time worker may be a good choice for both aged and employers so as to enable the elderly to earn more as well as enhance productivity .
This is also a good way to let the aging population take , if not all , part of the public spending by themselves .
Apart from the methods mentioned above , there are more and more effective methods to be come up with to handle aging population instead of direct public spending on the aged .
The elderly is a large part of the society that cannot be ignored and the best way to keep a sustainable economic development as well as give them a beautiful autumn is to set up a systematic methodology rather than focus on any single policy .
The government have also been legislating laws that require employers to offer re-employment to their workers until the age of 65 .This is a flexible approach because the workers do not have to get the same job or pay .
The government have incorporated this approach from Japan because it is a pragmatic step compared to just increasing the official retirement age .
By encouraging re- employment , the government is assisting the elderly to lead an active and productive life .
Life-long employability also helps the elderly to accumulate more wealth so that they can support themselves .
However most employers would prefer hiring younger working adults because they are more productive compared to the elderly .
To tackle this issue the government have introduced the Workfare Income Supplement which is a negative income tax and it is weighted in favour of older workers .
Workers above the age of 50 also pay lower CPF contribution to decrease the cost of hiring them .
These steps have increased the employment rate of older workers .
In addition to that , the government have various programs to retrain older workers and improve their skills . 
The government is also building step down care sectors which includes more community hospitals , nursing homes and home care centres to provide better elderly care .
However these services are currently only provided by voluntary welfare organisations and they need more government support .
The government is aware of this situation and they have come up with a solution to overcome this problem by linking up acute hospitals with community ones .
This allows patients to recuperate at community hospitals and make room for more serious medical condition to be treated in acute hospitals .
This is an effective solution because the role of caring for the elderly is divided as effectively as possible between the private and government sectors .
To ensure better comfort for the elderly , the government have also been upgrading home care to serve the elderly better . 
The government have also upgraded infrastructure to help ease the aging process .
Upgraded infrastructure helps the mobilization of the elderly .
The Housing and Development Board have been building more studio apartments to accommodate senior citizen .
.New lifts have been installed in every floor of apartments and flats .
The bus system is also improved by making buses wheelchair accesible .The trains in Singapore are already wheelchair assessable .
The government have also gone beyond transportation and housing to help ease the aging process by providing neighbourhoods with decent public toilets and green spaces which enables the elderly to lead an active lifestyle .
In conclusion , most of the policies and steps taken by the government have helped eased the aging process to a large extend .
In the areas of healthcare and financial security the government have been constantly upgrading and implementing new strategies to help ease the aging process .
Hence the measures taken by the government are effective ones and it has helped the elderly age comfortably .
Ageing is an inevitable part of life and it is often not easy at all to deal with the difficulties that old age brings .
However , with the world noticing the shift in it's demographic to a more aged society , things are becoming more accommodating for the elderly .
Indeed , developments like companies becoming more inclined to hire older workers , government policies giving the elderly more protection , and medical policies being designed to ensure the affordability of health care have helped make ageing much easier .
The difficulties in ageing are well-documented and hence have always been a source of debate for any society .
In our society , the aged have been marginalized in the struggle of the survivor of the fittest as their contributive power to society were reduced .
Yet , as society matures , one can see how ingenious and novel methods have been developed and set into place to help bring the elderly from living on the margins of society into being a part of the family structure again .
The three developments and policies highlighted are examples of the efforts made to help ease the ageing process for the elderly by helping them keep themselves relevant to society and their family .
Thus , what were once sore sticking points in the issue of ageing has been tackled largely by the methods described .
It is interesting to note , also , that in helping to ease the ageing process , society has prepared itself to adapt to the prospect of an ageing population .
Ever since the "Silver Tsunami" swept our regions , there has been much debate with regards to public spending on the aged .
Some feel that giving our full support to the elderly is of the utmost importance while others suggest limiting expenditure on the aged drawing concerns from other sectors of the country such as economic growth and sustainability .
I agree with the latter those concerns are very real , and if left unattended can pose a serious threat to the country's development .
Though I feel that public spending on the aged should be limited , it should be done flexibly and contextually .
The seniors have in the past , contributed to our society as well and it would be our immediate moral obligation to support them .
Suffice to say , this must be done prudently lest we should neglect the well being of other sectors in the process .
In this essay , we will be addressing these dilemmas and attempt to propose several possibilities as well as solutions that come with it .
Limiting public is something which the governments must consider seriously .
From a pragmatic stand , majority of the elderly are unable to contribute economic growth due to deteriorating health conditions which come naturally with aging .
Some common conditions such as rheumatism , failing eyesight and hearing , dementia , Parkinson's disease , all of which render them unfit for work .
Not only are the elderly hindering the country's economic growth , they are depleting it at an alarming rate as well .
Member of Parliament Paulin Tay-Straughan said that " . . .spiraling healthcare costs could potentially be a major strain on the Singapore government's resources .
If don't have adequate coverage , there will be a tremendous strain on subsidized care which will drain revenues from the state .
"Suffice to say , limiting public spending on the elderly must be considered in order to maintain a sustainable economy .
Another reason why public spending on the elderly should be limited is so that the funds could be diverted into other sectors of the country's development .
Experts predict a financial toll in the near future stating , "East Asia may experience widespread capital shortages as funds are diverted from financing productive investments in Hong Kong and Singapore to financing pension deficits in Berlin and Washington ."
By diverting the funds into sectors such as foreign investments , it would enable us to provide for the elderly even more sufficiently with the extra capital .
Even if we had enough capital for elderly spending , recent surges of new pandemics such as the H1N1 virus , call for more funding into the medical field .
Not to mention there are others like the needy who need financial aid as well .
However , limiting public spending on the seniors should be done flexibly and contextually .
Limiting does not mean depriving them of support , but only to provide what's necessary .
Certain categories fall through the gaps of the system and are left dry and powerless , even without the basic needs .
An example could be seen in the following article which writes "Isn't the HDB's policies self-contradictory , when it's income ceiling policy 'forces' the lower-income to buy larger flats than they can afford . . . HDB's income eligibility requires a household earning more than $ 2 ,000 a month to buy a flat that is bigger than a two-room flat . . . a household earning just over $ 3 ,000 , is also not eligible to buy a three-room flat , and have to buy a four-room flat ."
This example is one that stresses for flexibility .
It doesn't necessarily mean that when one has some money , he/she doesn't need help .
Spending on the aged should also be contextualized accordingly with economic situations , such as the recent economic crisis where employers are extremely selective , making jobs all the more scarce for the elderly .
Clearly , it can be seen that though limiting public spending on the elderly might produce certain immediate difficulties , it will ease the process inevitably during the long run .
It is important that for us to maintain economic stability , we should keep our sights focused on a more macro scale .
However , the application of flexibility and context is most crucial as there are indeed too many factors and variations for the system to account for , thus it is better that humans master the system instead of the opposite case .
