Singapore's life expectancy at birth for males is 78 .4 , for females is 83 .2  .
Total fertility rate per female is only 1 .28 .
These statistics explain why Singapore is no doubt one of the fastest aging populations in Asia .
The problems associated with aging process can be categorized into five aspects , namely economics decline , mental agility , health , emotional and social problem .
Among all , economics and social policy aspects are widely discussed in the society .
Although it is impossible to increase the fertility rate in the short run , the problems of aging process is still alleviated by research and effective developments and policies .
On economics aspect , aging population leads to shrinking workforce , low productivity and slow economic growth .
Annual inflation rate of has been increasing from 2 .1 to 6 .5 from 2007 to 2008  .
Old age dependency ratio last year was 11 .9 which shows that 11 .9 working persons would support one elderly .
Together with the problem of low fertility rate , government encourages Singaporean to work longer to cumulate affluence for future use .
In order to encourage late retirement , Singapore retirement age has been increased from 60 to 62 .
CPF contribution rate for employer has been increased by 1 .5 percentage point in 2007 in order for citizen to better prepare for aging problem .
However for older workers , CPF contribution by both employers and employee has also been reduced in order to keep the workers remain competitive and increase their take-home salary  .
Research on how to cater for elderly needs on public facilities has also come into action .
There are ramps for people using wheelchairs in most of the buildings , toilets and buses are specially designed to accommodate elderly and handicapped .
Singapore social service sector have been taking care for elderly with current housing , healthcare and job support policies .
HDB encourage child live in close proximity with their parents so that child can take care of parents during emergency .
Under the Single Singapore Citizen Scheme in 2008 , single Singaporeans aged 35 and above are able to apply for higher CPF grant of $20 ,000 if they want to purchase HDB resale flats to live with their parents  .
Beside , upgrading of housing lift on every floor would make elderly life easier .
The Healthcare 3Ms , Medicare , MediShield and Medifund also provide subsidies for elderly .
In order to benefit whose who needs help more , subsidy for hospitalization in public hospital has been adjusted so that 60 percent of workers are able to enjoy full subsidy for type C and B2 wards whereas those have higher earning power will receive substantial subsidies for both C and B2 class wards  .
NTUC , WDA and employers have worked on the Job Re-creation Programme to recreate and redesign jobs targeting older workers and provide training opportunities for them to take up new job openings .
Besides , SPUR focus on retraining for older workers whereas ADVANTAGE !
encourages businesses to employ older workers .
Opponents of this position will argue that healthcare cost is still the main problem for aging population .
Medisave account may not be sufficient for many Singaporeans once they need to pay the medical bills for their parents , spouse and children .
Although most of the Singaporean have to pay for not only their own medical bills , there are other subsidy schemes which may lesser their financial burden .
Eldershield is designed for elderly who need long-term care or cannot afford the expenses on severe disability .
Elderly will receive monthly cash payout therefore their children's Medisave account can use to pay for their own bill .
Other than that , Interim Disability Assistance Programme for the Elderly and Primary Care Partnership are other subsidy schemes available .
To summarize , government encourage later retirement in order to reduce elderly dependency and implement social policy such as subsidy on housing medical fee .
At the same time , more and more facilities are designed to meet the needs of elderly and disability .
Therefore , current research and policies are able to cater most of the needs of Singaporean to prepare for aging problem .
Also , individual have to keep fit to reduce the probability of getting ill in order to avoid expensive medical bill at older age .

The world is still recovering from the aftermath of the recent market crash .
Many economies have dipped into recession , job losses are prevalent and many countries are experiencing social instability .
Fortunately , with the introduction of multimillion rescue packages , the situation seems to be hopeful .
Slowly and steadily , the world's economy will pick up again .
However , the world must address yet another dire issue an ageing population .
According to the United Nation's prediction , by 2050 , 22% of the world's population of 9 billion will be over 60 .
Such statistics are indeed worrying .
The world will experience slow growth , shrinking labour and rising public spending .
Such cost even micrify the impact of the recent financial crisis .
As stated in the Economist , the current crisis makes up about 10% of the future ageing-related costs  .
However leaders of the world have stepped up measures to combat this unforgiving phenomenon .
Ongoing researches and implementations are initiated to allow the world to accept such emergence comfortably .
Reducing elder dependency is one way in which governments can take into consideration in tackling the worrying phenomenon of a greying population .
One possible strategy is to enhance the opportunity of elderly employment .
In the past , the elderly are often labelled as slow and inefficient .
However in recent times , such stereotypes have been shelved away as the younger generations learn to embrace the wealth of experience the elderly share , thus increasing the likelihood for elder employment .
In Singapore , the ADVANTAGE !
Scheme is an initiation to help employers financially in hiring and retaining older workers .
This will open up more opportunities for the elderly to support themselves without burdening the tax-payers .
It also increases the labour force and tax revenue .
Therefore the elderly should not be deprived of employment by providing more incentives for employers to attract such workers and help for those seeking employment opportunities .
As such , the exchange of experience and skills will only benefit the workforce and hence reduce the effects of a greying population .
Another problem which the older generation may face is social discrimination .
Mental and physical health will inevitably deteriorate as one ages .
Such liability will only discourage the older ones and thus create an invisible segregation between the strong and the weak .
Thankfully in Singapore , such issues have been ironed out and certain measures have been carefully implemented .
Under the Main Upgrading Project  , grab- bars in the bathroom and non-slip floor tiles have been installed in upgraded sold flats .
Recently , recreational facilities such as exercise corners and elder-care centres have also been built in the neighbourhood to provide social interaction opportunities among the community .
Also , the Housing Development Board has introduced Married Child Priority Scheme to grant privileges to married children to live near or together with their parents .
These policies would greatly foster ties and improve communication between the young and old , in hope to eliminate the social discrimination and bolster the well being of the elderly .
On the contrary , as much as solutions are sought to reduce the effects of an ageing population , the rate of replacing the world's population is not desirable .
According to the Economist , the fertility rate in member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development fell sharply from an average of 3 .2 children per female in 1960 to 1 .6 in 2009 , which is below the recommended replacement level of 2 .1  .
Women now are more career-proactive and hence delay marriages and family formations .
Additionally , the number of children in a family has been limited to two due to individual family's preference and financial ability .
However , there are many ways in which governments can compensate the falling birth rate .
Longer paid maternity leave , more child- care leave and greater incentives for working mothers are some possible corrections to the problem .
In France , such policies were implemented and were rewarded with a near replacement fertility rate  .
Although this may increase the government's expenditure , it is a necessary investment for the better future of the country .
For many decades , the world has been taking a lot of beatings .
From economic crisis in 1997 to uncontrolled viral spread such as H1N1 pandemic in 2008 , the world survived all these obstacles .
On hand , the repercussions of an ageing population are tirelessly being subdued by various helpful and effective solutions .
These are proved successful in certain countries but with a necessary cost .
Results may seem moderate and unprogressive .
Nonetheless with many support in place , the future of world may not be as bleak as before .
Aging is a difficult process as the elderly are more incline to get sick because of lower immune system and having to recuperate longer would be financially draining .
They also face difficulties in finding and retaining jobs .
Under the seniority based-wage system , it's more expensive to hire older workers and along with the perception that older workers are inefficient , it resulted in low employment rate among the elderly  .
However , policies on the aged in Singapore have significantly help to reduce the problems they faced .
In recent years , the Ministry of Manpower have been working closely with its tripartite partners to enhance employability of the older workers  .
One of the schemes that were developed was the 'Advantage !
Scheme' .
In this scheme , companies are given a grant up to $400 ,000 to encourage them to retain its mature workers .
Coming in 2012 , the government will enact the re-employment legislation to enable elderly to work beyond the retirement age of 62  .
This is preferred than increasing the retirement age because a higher retirement age might cause older workers to be less employable as they are no longer cost competitive and resulting of them being layoff even before they are 62  .
With re- employment , employers can provide jobs to their mature workers and also offer them a different job position with different salary and terms .
Here , both employer and employees can negotiate the terms and companies can remain competitive by adjusting the wages and benefits according to the value of the job .

In terms of healthcare , the government have come out with a few financial assistance schemes to ensure that the citizens are able to afford healthcare and are prepared during their old age .
Other than the basic healthcare financing schemes like Medisave , Medishield and Medifund , the government had come out with another scheme called 'Elder Scheme' .
This is an insurance scheme where those eligible pay premiums and they can claim benefits at any age of their life and receive monthly cash payout up to 72 months .
This would help support them should one day they stop working  .
Other than financial schemes , the government also provide subsidies for patients who require intermediate and long term care .
The subsidies given could be as much as 75% of the total bills depending on the family income and it's extended to community hospitals  .
This is beneficial as sick elderly require long term care and they might choose to recuperate at community hospitals .
However , even with all of these policies and subsidies , there is no guarantee that the elderly is able to pay for all of their living expenses .
Even though they have worked for many years , they might have little or no savings because they might not know how to manage their money .
It's essential that they learn how to not only manage their wealth but also expand it so that when they choose to stop working , they would have enough money to pay for their necessities and have enough for any unexpected expenses .
To ensure that its citizen will be financially prepared when they reach their retirement age , the Central Provident Fund Board have came out with a learning portal called 'Retirement Ready @ my cpf' to help citizens to plan for their retirement  .
Here they show a step-by-step process on how to achieve the desired retirement lifestyle a person wants .
They teach from how to do basic budgeting to doing investments .
This is one of many ways to ensure that Singapore citizens will live a better life when they get older .
Clearly the government and its related agencies have been working hard to help easing the aging process through many of its policies .
Through it , the elderly not only will be able to continue working , they also need not worry much on their health expenses .
These policies along with early retirement planning would help to ensure that the elderly will be economically independent and lead a better life .

Singapore is facing a shift in distribution of population towards greater ages , where the median age of population faces an increase , and a decline in fertility rates , resulting in a rise in the number of elderly in Singapore .
Aging impacts a person's well being in many ways , with both psychological and physical changes , including chronic diseases associated with aging .
The labour age composition has thus shift towards the older workers , where implications towards the competitiveness of Singapore's economy will occur , especially if older workers do not make significant contribution to the productivity growth in the economy  .
Hence more support and care for the aged should be provided which in turn will pose a strain to the younger generation .
As of 2008 , '8 .4 economically active persons are supporting one elderly' and 'by 2030 , only 3 .5 persons will be supporting one elderly'  .
This has reflected the importance for each individual to have the ability to support themselves through their golden years .
In order to do so , Singapore has introduced policies that worked to ease the aging process .
Facing high cost of living , Singapore has moved up from the 13th position in 2008 to the 10th in 2009 , in the worldwide cost of living ranking  , especially for the medical cost , where each household spend an increasing amount of expenditure in health care , with 3 .3% in 1998 to 5 .1% in 2003  , and is expected to further increase in the future years , with more aged citizens in Singapore .
Hence , Singapore has introduced policies to ease healthcare financing , such as Medisave , Medishield , Medifund , and Eldershield  .
Singaporeans have recognized the need to prepare for aging in terms of escalating medical costs , thus net withdrawal of Medisave scheme , including Eldershield , has dropped to 213 .6 million in 2009 , and Medishield scheme of 62 .5 million  .
A drop in withdrawal of healthcare schemes has thus reflected that more Singaporeans have felt the need for such policies .

Available from source: http://www .fas .nus .edu .sg/ecs/pub/wp-scape/0613 .pdf
Singapore has not only faced with aging population resulted from low fertility rates , but also longer life expectancy for individuals .
With rising life expectancy , given only 2 .5% of annual interest in the Central Provident Fund  , and with most funds in the CPF used to fund housing or tertiary education , the CPF figure left is no longer sufficient to last through retirement  .
"The best way for people to adjust to longer life spans is to continue working for as long as they can"  , as working provides a source of income , more savings can thus be build up .
Increasing the retirement age is insufficient to encourage individuals to work longer , hence the Re-employment policy will be enact in 2012 .
In order to ensure that older workers are not at disadvantage , Singapore established schemes such as smaller CPF contributions to the aged  , as well as the Advantage !
Scheme introduced in 2005 to lighten the cost of hiring the aged as well as to move away from the seniority-wage system and provide assistance in funding to re-employ mature workers .
And as of 2005 , 1 ,142 companies have benefited from this scheme .
In addition , retraining programmes were also introduced an example would be 'Skills Programme for Upgrading and Resilience '  .

Through amelioration and subsidizing of healthcare and public facilities the process of aging population has been eased .
Through amelioration and subsidizing of healthcare and public facilities the process of aging population has been eased .
Over the last 5 years , Singapore government health expenditure for the citizens has increased from $1 .53 billion in year 2002 , to $1 .93 billion in year 2006 which is an average growth rate of 6% per annum  .
Through the increment on healthcare expenditure , we can see that the government is bringing in better technologies and putting the focus on the Singaporeans' health .

Be careful how means testing is applied to hospital care .
Retrieved September , 16 , from {http://www .moh .gov .sg/mohcorp/uploadedfiles/News/Current_Issues/2004/BeCarefulHowMeansTestingisAppliedtoHospitalCare .pdf}
With advance healthcare facilities , preventing or curing of diseases are made possible .
One of the most common diseases associated with the old age is the Senile Dementia , where the patient encounters mental deterioration  .
Two major types of senile dementia are Alzheimer type and those due to vascular problems .
Studies show that of all people over 80 , 20% suffers from Alzheimer  .
Researchers have come up with several ways to improve and slow down the deterioration of elderly brain .
For instance , the researchers have invented medications such as tacrine and donepezil which are used by patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease  .
Researchers not only focus on inventing new medications , they also hope to protect people against mental decline through aerobic exercises and getting a dose of the sun - vitamin D  .
Singapore being one of the fastest aging populations in the world , with the estimation of 23% of the population to be over 65-year-olds by the year 2030 , there is a need for more hospitals to be built to meet the needs of the aging population  .
Hence , Jurong General Hospital which will be up in five years and Khoo Teck Puat Hospital which will be up next year will be linked to a community hospital next door .
This is to ensure that older people will have the right health care treatment at the right place and in return helps them to cut costs  .
It is understandable that older people often require more medical care , but they need not remain in hospital for this care .
Thus , it would be much cheaper for them to get such care from a community hospital - hence the idea of "stepping down" the care is needed .
Public transportation systems must continue to expand in order to deal with an aging population .
In June 2006 , Singapore Bus Services transit launches Singapore's First Ever Wheelchair accessible buses - Service 21  .
In conjunction , another public transport operator Singapore Mass Rapid Transit came up with its first wheelchair-friendly buses on June 2009  .
With these buses , the elderly and wheelchair bounded commuters could travel conveniently to hospitals and polyclinics for their medical appointments .
Even with government funding , not every Singaporean is able to luxuriate in the use of better healthcare and public facilities .
Even with government subsidies and paying through their CPF they might still find it hectic to handle hefty medical bills .
Hence , even a small family with a monthly income of $10 ,000 might also find it difficult to cope with a big hospital bill , if they have to support one or two elderly people with chronic illness  .
Hence , policy such as senior citizens' bonus the where lower-income elderly aged 55 and above with an annual income of $100 ,000 or less will receive $200 to $1000 over a period of 4 years to lighten the burden of lower income families .
There is no need to worry as statistic shows that direct subsidies to patients have increase from $850 million in 2001 to $1 .6 billion in 2007 and it is project to increase to $2 .2 billion in 2012  .
In conclusion , amelioration and subsidizing of healthcare and public facilities has eased the aging population .
Therefore , maintaining a healthy lifestyle , saving up for the future and contribute monthly to their CPF account assist the citizen for in a better retirement and lower their economic burden .

Ministry of Health .

Electronic References .

One in five residents in Singapore will be 65 and above by the year 2030  .
Singapore society's aging process brings on numerous set of challenges for the government .
The effects of aging process in Singapore are as follows .
First , economic decline would occur as the size of the working force shrinks .
Second , decline in the citizen's health due to weaker immunity system and age related illness .
Third , social problems brought on by the living environment .
Fourth , emotional problems caused by the different mindsets of the young and old generations and connections to family and society .
Last , the decrease in mental agility affecting active aging .
Therefore , the government has embarked on reforming its older policies and implementing new ones to cater to and prepare for the trend of population aging in Singapore .
Critics might argue that the government introducing policies encouraging employability of mature workers or re-employment of older workers does not mean companies in Singapore would follow suit .
Also , not all the workers would benefit from the policies mentioned above .
However , in evident of the above policies , Singapore was the only Asian country which won the AARP International Innovative Employer Award  .
The award is given to companies in countries for showing innovative Human Resource practices that deal with matters related to the workforce , age 50 and older  .
Also by the end of 2008 , 700 unionised companies have already committed to re-employ close to 5 ,000 workers above the age of 62  .
The statistics show that the reemployment is a useful tool and the government's policies have had a positive impact on the companies .
Furthermore , workers can refresh or upgrade their skills from more than 800 SPUR courses  .
This benefit is not limited only to employed workers but unemployed workers also can turn SPUR to sharpen their skills while they search for jobs .
Moving on , Singapore wants for its seniors , even the less mobile to have a safe and accessible environment .
As such , a Barrier Free Accessibility Masterplan was executed  .
The plan is for all our public housing estates to be barrier-free by 2011  .
Also by 2014 , eligible HDB blocks would have lift access to all floors .
In the past , there was no exact emphasis on structure for all ages .
However , since July 2006 , HDB's new public housing projects are built are all people  .
For example , switches and sockets low enough to be accessible from a wheelchair and toilets being wide enough and having hand rails .
Moreover , our government is not only building barrier-free estates but also concentrating on public transportation .
By 2010 , pedestrian walkways , public roads , taxi and bus shelters and access to MRT stations would be barrier-free , using a $60 million programme started by the government  .
We can also observe that wheelchair-accessible buses are progressing gradually .
Thus , Singapore's environment and transportation services for its citizens are transforming in line with the changing needs of Singapore society .
Our government's constant review of the policies , setting up of many specified committees to head particular goals in relation to changing times , and counter measures to external and internal factors have been impressive .
It has also gained recognition in local and abroad .
In conclusion , our current policies clearly have helped to ease the aging process in Singapore .
It has enabled our society to be better prepared for the aging trend in Singapore .
When Singapore's Ministry of Finance unveiled the government budget for 2009 , it is stated that an estimated total of S$66 million or 0 .15% of the total government expenditure will be spent on establishing various programs and upgrading facilities for the elderly  .
As the problem of aging population intensifies throughout the years , there will always be a debate on how much of the public spending should be allocated to the aged .
While it is important to provide funds for implementing policies to support the elderly , it is plausible for the government to work on areas which can aid both the country's development as well as provide support towards the aged .
Firstly , it is vital to develop the country's economy .
A sustained economic growth improves the level of business activities , ensures low unemployment rate and increases government tax revenue .
More funds is thus available to finance additional projects for the needy including the aged .
Also , more people will become self-sufficient and therefore able to support themselves , even without government aid .
Hence , more funds can be directed to other economic development areas  .
Contrarily , with slower growth , more people will be unemployed and more money would have to be spent on unemployment benefits .
This will inevitably constrict the public spending on the aged due to a smaller pool of resources .

Pillars of the Nation: Child Citizens and Ugandan National Development .
University of Chicago Press
* Lee Harvey .
New Realities: The Relationship between Higher Education and Employment .
Springer Netherlands .
* Robert B . Friedland and Laura Summer .
Doomsday Predictions about Population Aging Are Exaggerated .
Demography Is Not Destiny , Revisited .
Center on Aging Society , Georgetown University .
Secondly , the funding spent on the education sector cannot be compromised .
Cheney wrote that children are the pillars of the nation .
This means that the country's progression will depend on the next generation .
If the young are not well educated , there may be social implications such as increasing crime rates and unemployment .
In a research done by Shirley  , crime rate and education have an inverse relationship .
This is due to the increased opportunity costs involved with a higher education level .
Adversely , there is a positive relationship between higher education and employment opportunities  .
This is because employers tend to link working abilities with academic qualifications .
Hence , reduction in education expenditure will put the country's progress at risk .
Critics may argue that even if the country is performing well economically , she may not be progressing socially if she fails to address the people's needs , especially the elderly's .
This is because the elderly have once contributed to the country's economy and their well-being should not be overlooked when they aged and unable to work .
Thus , it is justifiable that the society should give in return and support the old members of the workforce , on the account of their past contributions to the nation .
Furthermore , aging is a natural process and everyone will grow old one day .
When the time comes , it is man's instinct to hope that more efforts will be invested to help him .
Therefore , it is pertinent that the government does not overlook their needs .
However , it is essential to regulate the amount spent on assisting the aged .
Some fear that with government aid , some may in turn become over-reliant and fail to be self-sufficient .
Therefore , it would be better for the government to offer the basic infrastructure and introduce policies to help the aged gain independence while receiving necessary help .
For example , one feasible policy is to encourage companies to provide extra training for the older workers to stay in touch with the advancing technology , thus increasing their working lifespan disregarding health factors .
Not only will the elderly become more financially able , they will also attain a sense of belonging in the society and purpose in their lives .
Concurrently , the government can invest in other sectors , such as the research and development sector , which will indirectly aid the aged .
For instance , public facilities , such as buses , are being upgraded and improved to facilitate easier movement for the elderly and handicapped .
Also , there are ongoing medical research on senile dementia and Parkinson's disease .
All these will improve the lives of the elderly significantly .
In conclusion , public spending for the aged is a necessity but should be regulated .
In order to strike a balance and better maintain the state of the economy , the government has to prioritize the country's needs and analyze the current problems the country is facing .
Resources are always limited , thus the government has to allocate them cautiously for the continuous development of the nation .

Aging is an ongoing process .
Everybody will grow old and is bound to experience the effects of it at one point in their life .
Although we cannot escape from it , we can certainly make the process a less painful one to go through .
Indeed , current research and development/policies have greatly contributed in easing the aging process .
Research and development is essential to help improve the lives of an ageing population .
Only through research and development will we be able to gain knowledge on the issues circling them and come up with ways to overcome it .
For example , the development of humanoid robots in Japan which promises to free us from physical labor and help us with our household chores such as folding laundry , doing the dishes , cooking , etc  .
This will therefore ease the burden of people from all these time-consuming chores .
In addition to this , there is also development on robots serving as companions .
A robotic companion could add a lot of fun and excitement to the life of a lonely retiree especially .
Another R&D policy that has played a role in easing the aging process includes buses that are elderly and handicapped friendly .
An example would be the new SBS Transit single-deck buses that are capable in accommodating two wheelchair-bound passengers at any one time .
These new buses are also low floor and zero stepped enabling easy boarding and alighting for the elderly and handicapped  .
Thus , by coming up with new technologies , research and development do help in easing the aging process .
Apart from research and development , policies with regards to ageing population have also help to ease the ageing process .
These policies help the elderly to age with grace and dignity .
For example , HDB has been actively implementing various policies and improvement programs in making the elderly feel more comfortable .
One such program is the Lift Upgrading Program where the lifts will now land on every floor as compared to the past where not all public housing are provided with the accessibility to lifts .
This does not only benefit the elderly , but the disabled as well as families with young children  .
In addition to this program , HDB has also come up with policy which encourages children to live in close proximity to their parents .
This policy provides the children to buy resale flats with a housing subsidy of $40 ,000 higher-tier Family Grant under the CPF housing grant scheme .
For singles aged 35 years and above who wish to buy a resale flat , they will be provided with a housing subsidy of $20 ,000 higher-tier Singles Grant under the scheme  .
These policies all have the common intention of promoting the value of an extended family staying together for mutual care and support which will in turn ease the aging process of the elderly .
Research and development/policies are not the only ways in easing the aging process though .
Palliative care is now getting the recognition it deserves together with professional training and more funding .
On top of relieving a patient's pain , palliative care also lightens the emotional burden of the patient's caregiver too .
In light of the increased awareness and growing importance of palliative care , demand for it has increase .
For example there is a rose in the number of patient referrals to Dover Park Hospice from 680 in 2006 to 750 in 2008  .
By becoming more affordable , it helps to ease the financial burden of the patient and their family .
Although palliative care does not prolong life , it helps the ill to live meaningfully by helping to manage their pain and discomfort .
To conclude , research and development/policies have no doubt manage to ease the aging process but on top of that , palliative care also has a role to play in relieving suffering and improving the quality of life for people facing serious illness .

Singapore is one of the fastest ageing countries in the world .
In the year 2000 , Singapore has 7 .2% of its population aged 65 and above .
By 2030 , the ageing population in Singapore is predicted to increase to 18 .4% of the total population  .
This is a pressing issue which may lead to an economic decline as the workforce is affected .
The current research and development as well as the policies drawn are effective in alleviating the ageing process such as declining in health , economic downturn and the emotional problem of the elderly .
In this rat-raced world , everything seems to be progressing rapidly , leading to a higher standard of living .
Better medical facilities allow people to live longer but at the same time increase their cost of living as well .
As people age , their health starts to deteriorate and their savings will also decrease as the years pass .
They will not be able to afford the high medical costs and thus are unable to get proper treatment for their illness .
In this aspect , some critics argued that development in the medical field does not aid in the ageing process .
However , one of the policies in Singapore includes healthcare subsidy for the elderly .
The Singapore government will provide up to 75% subsidy for the elderly provided that they are either Singapore citizens or permanent resident and this also depends on the income of the family  .
This aid enables medical treatment to be more affordable .
Hence , the policy is able to ease the ageing process of deteriorating health of the elderly .

Current research in the medical field is conducted to find out the causes and cures for common aged illnesses such as senile dementia and Parkinson's disease .
One example is the Dementia Research Centre located at the National Hospital for Neurology and Neurosurgery in the United Kingdom .
It is the lead centre for finding new drugs to delay the onset of Alzheimer's disease  .
When such research is successful , it will benefit humanity and better the medical treatments in the world .
This will decrease the suffering of the elderly , making them less susceptible to diseases and thus helping to abate the ageing process .
There are a few measures taken by the Singapore government to ease the ageing process .
One of the measures taken is to encourage the elderly to undergo training and upgrading of their skills .
This will enable them to enter the workforce again and increase their retirement age .
The 'ADVANTAGE !
Scheme' was implemented in 2005 some companies such as the retail and logistics have adopted it to help them recruit and retain workers aged 62 and above  .
This will increase the retirement age of the elderly and thus improve the economy and workforce in an aging population .
Another policy is the 'Central Provident Fund Housing Grant Scheme' which is a subsidy given by the government to encourage children to live in close proximity with their parents .
They will have a disbursement of grant if they live in the same town , or 2 kilometers apart from each other if they are to stay in different towns  .
When the children live near their parents , there is a higher probability of them visiting their parents often , hence making it easier for them to take care of their parents .
Moreover , the family is able to provide emotional support for the elderly .
Hence , these development plans and policies will help to ease the ageing process of the elderly .
In conclusion , the research conducted to discover more about the illnesses of the elderly and the policies implemented which provide subsidies as well as schemes to aid the elderly , will help to ameliorate the ageing process .
An ageing population will still be a problem in time to come .
Hence , such developments and policies are vital to ease the ageing process .
Family might be a better solution to abate the process , as they are the main emotional and financial support for the elderly .

An elderly is an irreplaceable and valuable source of asset that acts like glue which holds families together .
These valuable assets are deemed to increase in numbers globally .
Being one of the fastest aging populations in Asia  , Singapore faces a huge challenge in developing infrastructures and public policies in terms of healthcare , housing , re- training , transportation and financial aid to accommodate this changing age structure .
Despite the large expenses in the various aspects for the aged , these implementations would also benefit the younger generations in due course .
Hence , the government and society would have to do everything that is possible to support and prepare for the inevitable increase in the aging population even at the expense of the country's development in other areas .
Currently , the main concern for Singapore is the overwhelming baby boomers that are progressing into the senior status .
Nevertheless , the government should prioritize its spending and not neglect this aging population .
Reports have shown that in mid 2008 , an estimated 506 million population worldwide are above 65 years old .
However , this figure will reach 1 .3 billion by 2040 .
In context of Singapore , the aged above 65-years old are projected to represent 23% of the population by 2030 and this would be the second highest percentage in Asia after Japan  .
The repercussions following the aging population would be social and economy concerns as the younger generations would have to struggle to support their families .
Moreover , with less working population , Singapore's economy would be greatly affected .
Therefore , the society should be aware of its situation and address to this problem before it becomes a severe issue for the country .

With a paradigm shift in many countries towards a greying population , many governments are confronted with a responsibility of implementing policies that assist the ageing process .
The elderly often face emotional , mental and physical problems and if these issues are not addressed , there will be economic and social implications for the country .
Different countries respond to this problem differently and the ease at which the elderly are living their lives is evidence of the creative policies that many governments have introduced to benefit them .
As countries face the daunting task of ensuring that the needs of their elderly population are met , Singapore is not spared .
The government estimates that by the year 2030 , 23% of its population will be over the age of 65  .
Among the various policies introduced to allow the elderly to have an easier time aging include housing , employability and healthcare which will help to ease their ageing process .
Enhancing the employability of elderly workers by improving skills and retraining elder workers ensures that they have the relevant skills to take on different jobs should the need arise .
The government has also encouraged employers to be more welcoming in employing the elderly .
One such example is the Tripartite Committee which introduced the ADVANTAGE !
scheme in 2005  .
This scheme was introduced to support companies to recruit and retain older workers as well as to re-employ them beyond age of 62 .
This ensures that companies are willing to review their work process to cater to older workers .
By introducing such policies , the government ensures that the elderly do not have to be afraid that they might face difficulties at work with rising competition from the younger generations .
Housing has always been a key issue for elderly during their years of retirement .
The government thus introduced the Lease Buy Back scheme in 2009 .
Through Singapore's successful CPF scheme , many elderly have been able to become flat owners .
They may be asset-rich but many are cash poor .
Therefore the government introduced the Lease Buy Back Scheme this year to ease cash flow .
This scheme allows the government to buy back the HDB flats of the elderly by first giving them a lump sum payment of $5000 and a monthly income for the rest of their lives  .
This eases the burden of the old as they are ensured they receive money every month .
As with old age , there is always a possibility of illness .
Therefore the government has introduced holistic affordable healthcare and eldercare .
Singapore's government introduced Singapore workforce skills qualification to train more than 900 therapy assistants and patient service assistant over the next three years  .
These training programmes ensure that the elderly are properly cared for with upmost professionalism and efficiency to make certain that they do not face any obstacles .
Furthermore when the elderly are in good care of such trained professionals , families do not have to burden themselves with worry the of whether the safety and wellbeing of their elderly is being taken care of .
As much as government policies have been beneficial to the elderly , critics may state that by increasing the age when elderly can withdraw their CPF , the government is taking away a good few years away from the elderly which can be spent either relaxing , holidaying or purchasing something they have yearned for .
While this may be true , it is essential to remember that these retirement funds are meant to last the elderly till the end of their lives .
The earlier they receive the funds , the more the likelihood the funds may be depleted well before their actual intended duration of use .
Thus the intention of the government to increase the CPF withdrawal age has proved to be a wise decision .
In conclusion , it is of upmost importance that the government keeps coming up with new and improved policies to ensure that our elderly stay active for as long as possible and are able to fruitfully enjoy their old age .
It is only through policies such as these that the elderly will ensure that our future generations do not have to fear the process of ageing as they are certain that with continuous implementation of such policies , growing old would be a graceful process .
Singapore: The fact that the majority of the elderly is reliant on their children for financial support still remains .
In 2005 , it was 31 .9% among those aged 55 to 64 , 55 .8% for those aged 65 to 74 and 63 .7% for those aged 75 years and above .
Shockingly , the age-support ratio has declined from 10 .4 in 1998 to 8 .4 in 2008 , resulting in the challenge that the current caregiver generation has fewer or no siblings with whom to share the burden .
Furthermore , the percentage of elderly persons aged 65 and above has increased from 6 .8% in 1998 to 8 .7% in 2008 .
Thus , the government has to critically consider these worrying demographic changes and allocates a satisfactory portion of the national budget to lighten the burden of the caregiver generation .
The first approach to reduce elder dependency is to ease barriers to elder employment and encourage the elderly to work longer and retire later  .
According to the national survey conducted in 2005 , more than half of the elderly population aged 55 and above were economically inactive .
The main reasons included retirement and a drop in their fitness and agility levels .
It is reported that the government will be raising the current retirement age of 62 to 65 by 2012 and ultimately to 67 and has also made amendments to the Retirement Age Act which increases the employability of elderly workers .
By working longer and saving more , the elderly can build up their retirement nest egg much faster than before .

Secondly , couples are encouraged to settle down early and set up families , hence , expanding the economy's size and tax base .
Meanwhile , the cost burden of providing for the elderly can be spread over a larger future generation .
However , the first barrier to starting a family among Singaporeans is the sky-high costs associated .
Just the housing policy alone affects the young couples' choices .
During the process of house-hunting , the initial excitement to starting a family among couples starts to fade .
Bigger families require bigger homes at steep prices which force couples to reconsider about the decision to have more children .
Is it possible for a couple to purchase a spacious and comfortable place at an affordable price for a family of five ?
Making matters worse , if the retirement costs and providing for aged parents are added into the equation , having children will be the last thing on the couples' minds .
Last but not least , the strategy about emphasizing filial obligation and increasing the willingness of grown children is not an easy feat .
It is heartening to read that almost fourth-fifth of the elderly lived with their children .
However , the children are not always the party at fault .
In fact , there are some parents who do not welcome the prospect of having unmarried children in their 30s living with them as they have a perception that living with more people under the same roof require some sacrifice of personal space and freedom .
The truth lies in the fact that singles under the age of 35 are not eligible to purchase resale flats and are not able to move out of "Hotel Mama" their parents' flat .
In any case , humans tend to be self-centred and less obliged to give of their time beyond personal pursuits .
In any event when the government cuts down or eliminate welfare benefits due to rising elderly-related expenditure , it ought to bear in mind the net effects of such actions  .
It is obvious that the daily lives of the families will be adversely affected and the living standards will deteriorate , particularly the low-income families .
Consequently , there will be a surge in family and social problems .
The children may isolate the fragile elderly , leading to higher suicide rates and psychological problems .
Bringing the issue closer to the government , the confidence level inflicted on the government by the citizens will plummet and they would rather render their support for opposition parties .
In essence , while the education and defence still remains as the government's priority , it does not simply mean that expenditure for elderly welfare can be diverted into other areas .

Nowadays , "ills of old age" is no longer a topic that "only poets and philosophers" would interest in .
"Governments and policy makers are now confronted with the unprecedented problem of a fast aging population ," claims Peter G . Peterson ,  .
Although problems related to aging population become increasingly severe , with more important priority , governments should limit the spending on aging population .
This is because of three reasons: an increasing spending in dealing with problems in regard to aging population would probably affect other objectives with higher priority government cannot solve the "ills of old age" alone and the cost of "unlimit" the spending on aging population cannot justify the benefits in the long run .
Secondly , the answer to the problem with regard to aging population should be the cooperation between the elders themselves and the government , not simply by given priority in terms of unlimited government spending .
For example , government could help in training elders and engaging them with more jobs .
A new welfare law with higher retirement ages could also be passed so that the elders would have more time to accumulate wealth in preparing for the future .
By doing so , government spending on aging population could be effectively reduced .
With larger part of welfare supported by elders themselves , more elder citizens would have access to limited government budget .
With a relatively higher income and a broader base of beneficiaries from the government financial support , the average elder citizen should be able to enjoy a better living quality .
Meanwhile , governments could invest more money in economic development , which is at governments' first priority , and generate more revenue to support the aging population in the future though a larger scale of economy instead of an unlimited percentage increase in government spending .
Last but not least , with an increasing aging population , the cost of easing aging-society problems through larger government spending cannot justify the benefits in the long run .
A government's first priority should be the economic development and the overall improvement of the citizens' life quality .
These goals could not be achieved with most of the budget transferred to take care of the elders in the short run .
Thus , governments should deal with objectives with first priority and limit the budget for aging population .
In conclusion , it is clear that the problems generated by aging population cannot be ignored .
However , government should limit the spending on aging population and take care of the objectives with higher priority first .
This is because , due to the limited budget , in order to make the cost justify the benefit for the whole society in the long run , governments have to ensure a growing economy through continuously invest in infrastructure and advance technology with most of its budget .
The problem in regard to aging population would eventually be eased through more financial support generated from a larger scale of economy instead of increasing percentage cost of budget and participation of the elders themselves .
''It is well known that our society is aging .
Media stories and political rhetoric abound concerning the impending demographic challenges as the population aged 65 and older is anticipated to more than double by the year 2030 ,''  .
Increase in the population of aging group implies there will be more government spending on the old aged .
If the population of aging group is still expanding , the national budget will soon be drained up by supporting the old aged group with welfare treatment .
The nation will be affected if this continues changes  .Therefore , government should amend the policy by limiting public spending on the aged so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development which will benefit the nation .
In my opinion , limited public spending on the aged enables the government to divert the money to other areas for country development for a bigger picture .
Money could be diverted to develop agriculture , medical and healthcare services , welfare program and others .
For example , the money can be used to support researches such as research on hybrid seeds plant .
This will promote economic growth and increase the national income as introduction of hybrid seeds plant can increase the productivity of the crops .
There are critics about the act of government spend more money on country development will set aside the welfare of aging group .
However , if the government spends more money on the aging group , the country development will become stagnant and imbalance as there is a lack of fund to run country development projects .
Whereas , if the public spending is diverted to other areas for country's development , the nation including the old aged will both gain benefits from the country development and economic growth .
Besides that , there are other groups of population who need more money than the elder which are the orphans , the handicapped and others .
These groups of people have to struggle for their living resources and cost of living as they are vulnerable in the society .
Often , the handicapped can hardly make a stand in applying for job if they are to compete with the others because of their physical weaknesses and lack of living skills .
The public spending will come in handy to support their living .
Some may argue that the old aged need more money as they are unable to earn income to support their living .
However , the old aged are still be able to involve in the work field by extending their working lives and accumulate wealth for their latter years .
In a contrast , the handicapped can hardly get a job not to mention that they can accumulate wealth through working .
Thereby , public spending should be diverted to other areas to help the needy and unfortunate .
Furthermore , limited public spending on the elderly can encourage the grown children to take up their filial responsibility .
If the government reduce public spending on elders , elders whose living cost depends on the public spending have to rely on their children support .
In the past , the elder have worked hard to raise their children and provide the best for their children .
Hence , the grown children should appreciate their upbringing and take good care of them in return .
There may be opposing view which claims that the grown children do not have much money to support the elderly as they have their own family living to support .
Nevertheless , the grown children can actually do some adjustment to their monthly expenditure by practicing cost saving to have sufficient money to support their own family and their elder's living cost .
This will increase the willingness of the grown children to take care of their parents and realize their obligation to their parents .
In a nutshell , government should change their mindset and policy in order to meet the modern challenges .
Policy maker should limit public spending on the aged and divert money to other country's development to maintain a balance development of the country .
Or else , the country development would be stagnant and the nation would not have to live in a comfortable life .
If the government helps the senior citizens with public spending by constraining the fiscal cost on other areas of country development , the government would actually put the country in a straggling condition .

Due to poor fertility rates and late marriages , the government is now confronted with the problem of an aging population .
This is a phenomenon with dire consequences , such as having to direct large amounts of money to take care of the elderly .
Examples include a need to build facilities that are elderly-friendly and heavy subsidizing of their medical fees due to their poor health and low income .
Although forking out a lump sum of money for medical fees is inevitable , the government should not neglect the economic growth of the country .
Thus funding for the elderly medical fees should be limited so as to divert funds to other areas which are more necessary for improvement .
We cannot deny the fact that what we have today is a result of the hard work of the elderly in their prime years .
It is only right that the government take care of them , and spend vast amounts of money on them with no questions asked .
Critics of this approach have argued that if the government continues spending , more tax will be imposed on each working individual and elder dependency will rise .
It would be very stressful for them , having to keep up with both the pace of work and tax expenses .
Furthermore , there are key areas such as tourism , education and technology which will produce significant results if enough resources are channeled to them .
Other than the government spending on them , there are other alternatives which can be implemented to remedy the situation .
Firstly , it is through stressing filial obligation and increasing the willingness of tomorrow's grown children , however numerous or productive they are , to support their own elderly parents through informal and familial channels .
This is a social responsibility for each working individual , and it is often easier to get people to be socially responsible than to increase their tax contributions .
The government should give incentives to children that live near their parents , such as cheaper housing , or give priority to them when allocating flats .
Secondly , it is by requiring people to provide in advance for their own old-age dependency .
They should be encouraged or compelled by law to save and invest more of their income earned while they are active in the work force .
Minor monthly contributions made during their working years will definitely accumulate to a substantial pool of wealth for their retirement days .
Diverting funds to other more vital areas of improvements has its benefits too .
Firstly , there will be economic growth and country prosperity .
Singapore has strived hard to achieve the status as a tourism hub , and the revenue that could be generated from it alone should never be overlooked .
Therefore , if more funds are diverted to it instead of the elderly , there is no doubt that the country will experience tremendous economic growth and be prosperous .
Secondly , the future workforce of the country will be very productive .
A productive workforce is often defined as one which possesses the best qualifications , and education emphasis is the only way to go about it .
Thus , expanding the current budget on education will surely result in a larger and more affluent generation in the future .
Spending on the elderly is necessary , but it could be done on a ration basis .
We've discussed the far-reaching effects of diverting to other more vital areas of improvement and it outweighs any existing issues .
There are also other available alternatives which could be implemented to deal with the medical needs of the elderly , such as the stressing of filial obligations and the introduction of retirement schemes .
The limit , however , should be duly considered by the government in line with its current policies .
In a survey conducted by Manpower Incorporated , 40% of global leaders felt that ageing population was to be one of the most crucial problems in the future  .
Thus it comes as no surprise that governments around the world have stepped up their efforts to alleviate the effects of global aging .
The social policies adopted have greatly introduced the older population into the workforce and the volunteering sector , thus keeping them actively involved in the community and easing the aging process to a large extent .
Firstly , governments have reduced the dangers of ageing population by encouraging retirees to participate actively in volunteering to increase their mental alertness and at the same time tap on their wisdom to aid the community .
However , critics argue that citizens are unaware of these volunteering opportunities .
Also , they contend that most would be unwilling to volunteer during their 'golden years' , thus wasting the government's efforts to increase volunteering opportunities for the elder population .
This claim is flawed as the government has been stepping up its efforts to increase awareness of elder volunteerism through public campaigns and functions .
Fairs have also been organised to encourage active ageing through volunteerism  .
As a result , there has been a rising trend of senior volunteers over the years .
The Retired and Senior Volunteers Programme is an example of an avenue that provides opportunities for retirees to volunteer and use their skills to help others and also nurture new skills along the way .
To date , it has over 500 , 000 volunteers  , thus proving wrong the notion that people are unaware and uninterested to volunteer in their 'golden years' .
The high membership is testimony to the fact that volunteering will give the elderly spiritual fulfillment in their later years .
Secondly , governments in affected countries have introduced incentives to encourage companies to hire and retrain older workers , thus boosting the workforce and easing the aging process .
This will ensure that the huge older population can contribute effectively to the workforce .
Also , they will be able to accumulate more savings and not be over-reliant on the government for pension benefits .
This policy has been effective as surveys have proved that with the retraining and incentives to hire older workers put in place , employers have been increasingly open about hiring older workers .
According to a survey conducted by Manpower Incorporated in October 2006 , 48% and 43% of employers had strategies to hire and preserve older Singaporean workers respectively , whereas in Japan , 83% of employers had strategies to preserve older workers .
This proves that the governments' strategies to promote the hiring of older workers into the workforce have been effective .
According to the Singapore's Ministerial Committee on Ageing  , employment of Singapore citizens aged 55 to 64 increased from 53 .7% in 2006 to 56 .2% in 2007  .
This shows that the retraining of skills have indeed helped older workers to become more productive leading to the increased willingness of employers to hire them .
Lastly , the Singapore government has been encouraging citizens to retire later to accumulate more savings .
As a result , Singaporean working males aged 60 to 64 increased from 49% in 1996 to 63% in 2006 , while those of females increased from 15% to 26%  .
This proves that the government's promotion of a longer working life have effectively influenced the mindset and convinced the older population to contribute to the workforce for a longer period of time .
Fiscal cost that was previously used to distribute pension benefits to retirees could now be diverted to funding retraining programmes and monetary incentives to companies to hire and retrain older workers , thus further boosting the economy .
As seen from the above , current social policies adopted by the government have indeed alleviated the ageing process significantly .
The elder population , equipped with better skills , now has greater ability to contribute to the workforce .
Companies , with increased cash grants from the government , can now afford to retrain and hire older workers .
Also , senior volunteer opportunities are abound to effectively tap on the skills of retirees and ensure their mental well-being .

Facing an ageing population , the Singapore government had done research and development to improve the ageing process .
This is so that we will be able to harness the social possibilities , while at the same time , prepare to tackle challenges arising from the ageing population .
The ageing process brings to mind deteriorating health situation which requires lots of medical attention .
To make matters worse , social problems such as disrespectfulness and the lack of filial piety among the younger generations arises .
This would lead to emotional problems , where elderly feels like the "leftover of society" .
Gerard Ee , chairman of Council for Third Age said , we have to deal with housing , health , financial needs and accessibility before older people can be fully integrated into society .
Singapore has looked into the development of infrastructures to create a barrier free society for the elderly .
The main areas of concerns were the Housing Development Board precincts and public transports island wide .
Firstly , the government had launched the Lift Upgrading Programme for the benefit of flat owners without direct access to lifts .
By doing so , elderly can then conveniently leave their HDB homes to access shops and services within the precinct  .
Next , new buses are now designed low-floor , step-free and wheelchair accessible .
According to the Committee of Aging Issues  , a barrier free environment is important to allow senior citizens live independently and move out into the community to participate actively in society  .
The newly designed buses complement the elder friendly Mass Rapid Transit systems , making Singapore an accessible city for all .
Hence , today's elderly has unobstructed access from homes to public amenities , communal and recreational facilities .
In recognition of what the government had done , people begin to ask if these improvements could really ease the ageing process .
Now elderly are given more access to the public , but the ultimate choice still lies with them .
What could be hindering the decision is their children's disapproval or even themselves .
This is the case as most people will agree that elderly are not able to take care of themselves outside .
We cannot deny that they require more response time and have certain constraints in physical movements .
A little carelessness on the road could cause accidents , thus creating more burdens to their love ones .
Also , they are usually the victims of crime .
However , the government has been creating awareness on looking out for each other especially the elderly in society .
For example , from young school teaches civic and moral education to educate us on how to take care of elderly , to be patient with them , to respect them and even offer help to them .
Television programs such as Crime Watch also increases the knowledge of elderly to be vigilant to conmen and to prevent crime by not wearing excessive valuables .
The second area of research and development is on dementia .
Researchers found that people who retired later are able to avoid Alzheimer's disease longer than people who retired earlier  .
The first way of tackling this issue is to raise the retirement age to 62 years old .
It not only keeps the elderly mind active , it also helps to cope financially with rising medical costs and brings in self-satisfaction for being able to contribute to the society .
Secondly , CAI emphasizes on having strong family ties across generations to ensure that the family continues to be the first line of support .
This is essential to the elderly as they will not feel so helpless and unwanted .
Lastly , the Government have also encouraged activities and interactions by setting up elderly corners under void decks with facilities such as chess tables .
The aim is to prevent elderly from shutting themselves out of the society resulting to mind-robbing Alzheimer's disease .
In conclusion , the current research and development approaches adopted by the Singapore Government are helpful to a large extent in easing the ageing process .
With the development of infrastructure and medical field as mentioned above , these problems are better coped .
The elderly can now move around independently and conveniently , decreasing the burden on working adults .
The aging population has been an ongoing problem on the countries over the world .
It is not much of a difference in Singapore as the Strait Times stated that there has been an increase in the aging population to about 300 ,000 people who are over the age of 65 today and this figure is expected to increase to 900 ,000 by 2030 .
This shows that more attention is required for the aging population so as to prepare the society in embracing these elderly in the near future .
Hence , the public spending on the aged should not be limited and to be spent on other areas of the country's development as the money is needed for the healthcare and financial aspect for the aged .
As one gets older , they are more vulnerable to illness which explains the need of spending on the healthcare industry .
In the CIA factbook  , the life expectancy for Singapore is 81 .98 years which is ranked fourth in the world .
This means that the aged would live longer and drain their families and their own savings as the hospital fees are costly and thus more subsidies are required  .
Moreover , money is also needed to provide the prevention and screenings programmes for the elderly and to educate them about the benefits of having a healthy lifestyle and ways to stay healthy .
These screenings can also help to identify potential health problems that they might have and get them to seek treatment before it worsens and disrupt their daily activities .
Hence , spending on elderly healthcare is necessary as it helps to educate the elderly on the importance of healthy lifestyle while reducing the burden on the elderly and their family for the costly healthcare services .

27 .3% of Singapore's GDP is attributed to the manufacturing sector  .
The manufacturing industry in Singapore is one of the important growth engines of the economy .
Large amount of money is diverted to the R&D sector to give Singapore a competitive edge over its competitors .
But this has resulted in uproars from the people and they claim that more resources should be diverted into the welfare schemes for the aged instead .
So , who is defined as the aged ?
Currently there is no fixed age group where the aged is clearly defined .
Regardless of how the aged is defined , no human is able to survive without money in this current world .
Therefore in order for the aged to be better off , the Singapore economy has to be constantly growing and this can be achieved by diverting more resources into our R&D sector so the local products will be greatly differentiated and value added .
There is a common misconception that most welfare states end up being in debt and the people have a higher tendency to be over-reliant .
However there are no statistics to show that higher government expenditure on the social welfare leads to lower growth and lower productivity .
Well known welfare states such as Germany and Denmark do not necessarily do better or worse off economically than countries who have limited social expenditure such as Japan .
Denmark's welfare expenditure contributes to 37 .9% of the nation's GDP and the GDP per capita is $37 ,265 whereas Japan's welfare expenditure contributes to 16 .9% of the nation's GDP and its GDP per capita is $38 ,559  .
From this statistic , we can draw that it is also possible for Singapore to learn from these success stories and increase welfare expenditure while achieving economic growth at the same time .
Singapore is different from the welfare states in Europe such as Germany and Denmark .
Singapore is practicing the open market policy thus being more susceptible to external factors .
A recent example would be when the United States's economy fell during the credit crisis , Singapore was badly impacted by the recession .
One of the major growth engines in the Singapore's economy is the manufacturing sector .
Unlike China who has abundance in labour , Singapore on the other hand has little natural resources and is unable to compete with China on a large scale .
distinguishing our manufacturing goods by investing more money to invent cutting edge technology , to increase efficiency , to make our products unique and competitive in the market .
In order to finance the current schemes in Singapore , the economy has to be growing first so that it could support its schemes .
Currently Government Health Expenditure has been limited at 0 .9% from 2005 to 2007 .
Since Government Health Expenditure is capped at a percentage of GDP regardless of boom or bust in the economy , therefore the amount of money diverted to Health Expenditure in a bullish economy is higher than when it is during a bearish economy .
As the saying goes "Give a man a fish and you feed him for a day .
Teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime" This is especially true for the senior citizens whose skills are outdated in the current society but has an able body to earn an income for themselves .
Instead of diverting resources to finance the welfare schemes , the government should instead divert resources into retraining and integrating the senior citizens back into the work force .
Senior citizens possess a large amount of experience which are valuable to the younger generation now , thus they are more of an asset than a liability .
"For every working adult in Singapore , He/She has to support 8 .4 elderly Residents aged 65 years and above  .
Therefore to ease the burden on the younger generation who has to support the post baby boomers as they approach their retirement years , it would be a win-win situation if we integrate senior citizens back into the work force .
As countries differ both ideologically and geographically , there is no one solution that solves the current situation of an aging population .
Thus with different government's goals , the solution will adjusted to suit the country .
But in Singapore's context , Singapore does not have any natural resources and dependent on innovation and creativity to gain an advantage over its competitors .
In order to finance these welfare programs , we need to divert resources to other areas in order to have continuous growth in Singapore .
However government intervention alone is insufficient to finance the welfare schemes alone .
Thus it has included private charity organization such as National Council of Social Service to attend to the needs of the aged and the needy together with the help of the government .
Most importantly , is the care and concern from the family which is vital to the well being of the elderly .
The aging process of the elderly is an on-going problem , as the first batch of baby boomers will reach 65 by 2012 .
"The number of elderly aged 65 and above is one out of every 12 Singaporeans .
By 2030 , it will be one out of five ."
In view of this growing trend , government agencies and local service providers came out with some very innovative and creative designs to ease the everyday life of elderly .
The BCA has acknowledged the aging problems in Singapore and released a series of Home improvement designs to cater to the needs of an aging population in Singapore .
Those designs include the manoeuvring space for wheel chair bound elderly , visuals and vibration door bells for elderly with hearing impairment and additional safety features like emergency bell in toilets .
All this features will enhance the life of elderly as they can perform daily duties with ease .
These also allow the elderly to be independent as they no longer need to rely on other's help with their daily life .
Bus service provider SBS transit took the lead to introduce the elderly and handicap friendly buses in 2007 .
The low floor and zero stepped bus is an initiative by the SBS to ease the travelling journey for the elderly .
"This means that the elderly and other less mobile passengers will be able to board and alight easily .
This is especially important given Singapore's ageing population ."
It is an important innovation by the transport company , as it showcases its determination to improve the local transport facilities to facilitate the transportation for the ones with special needs .
Land Transport Authority did their part by introducing the new elderly- friendly traffic system in March 2009 .
Making use of the new Radio Frequency Identification technology , "Traffic lights will open their eyes to keep a look out for elderly pedestrians"  .
With the new technology , traffic lights will detect elderly that's still crossing the roads and adjust the timing accordingly .
With this system in place , lesser traffic accidents involving slower moving elderly are expected , as it allows elderly to finish crossing before the drivers are signalled to go .
Preliminary rounds of test involving 30 elderly pedestrians shows that the new system is welcomed by the elderly .
In this economic driven society , taking too much of the public's resources to support the elderly does not bore well for the future of the country .
Therefore , placing a cap on the public spending to support the aged should be implemented .
By limiting the resources used on the aged , other developments of the country can be better financed in order to drive the country forward .
The public spending used for the elderly such as healthcare , pension and welfare programs can be diverted into development sectors instead .
For example , the education for our youths , the nurturing of the country's youth is more important as these are the people who will eventually be the ones to carry the responsibility of maintaining the economical state of the country and to ensure a brighter future for her people .
A total budget of $8 ,701 million has been voted to MOE in FY2009  , most of which goes into the subsiding of school fees for local students .
This ensures that Singapore youngsters get a chance at education despite their financial status .
By exposing every possible citizen to education , Singapore then , will she be able to continue in development .
Singapore being a resource scarce country , the only resource we can make use of is our people .
Therefore funds should go into the upbringing of the people whom are able to drive the country forward in the future .
On the other hand , as mentioned , in this economic driven world , it would be impractical to focus our finances on the people whom are no longer efficient in what they used to do .
The country will simply be burden by placing more funds into rewarding or simply sustaining the elderly .
They should have had savings in either the form of cash or CPF to sustain them , alongside with subsides from the government to helps loosen the dependency on others for help .
The rewarding of the elderly does not push the country forward , whereas it is the upbringing of our youth that will ensure a future for our country .
There is too much human factor involved when it comes to whether elders should get more funds to help them cope in their later days , which should not be part of any equation when other development sectors can benefit instead .
In sum , the limitation of public spending on the elderly and diverting them to other developments would serve well in driving the country forward .
On one hand it is only moral that they are well taken cared because of the fact that they are the ones who contributed to the society before a new generation took over , while on the other by allocating more public spending on them would hinder the growth of the country as a whole .
Trading the future for the past simply is not a practical choice .
