Security and External Relation .
Retrieved September 20 , 2009 , from Singapore Budget Web site: {http://www .singaporebudget .gov .sg/expenditure_overview/security_external_relations .html}
Singapore has one of the fastest aging populations in the world , with people over 65-year-olds estimated by 2030 to make up 23% of the population , making Singapore the country with the second highest percentage in Asia just behind Japan  .
With the growing number of the aged in Singapore , the government should establish its bottom line for financing public healthcare for the elderly .
However , the government should also plan and allocate its expenditures on other areas appropriately in order to fuel the country's development .
A country cannot afford to spend too much on the elderly because of practical realities .
Some people think that the government has moral obligation to do all that it can to support the elderly .
The high standard of living in many developed countries causes greater difficulties for working adult to support their parents' medical expenses and still take care of their children's needs .
In addition , rising medical cost makes it more imperative for elderly to receive help in order to support their medical needs in the future .
However this is not a practicable solution .
Other than the elderly , there are also other groups of people equally in need of the government support to help them .
People like the handicapped , intellectually disabled and single mothers also experience great difficulty in living in Singapore where cost of living is relatively high .
The government should spread out its public spending to the various groups of people in need instead of just focusing on the elderly .
The government's moral obligation should not be supporting the elderly only .
Technology is an important area of development that will benefit everyone in the country .
Increasing public spending on technology would lead to an increased activity in Research and Development and new advancement in technology .
Certain new innovations brought about by the rise of R&D activities would in turn help the needy people improve their living standards .
Some examples are the invention of robot that is able to do household chores and the modification of public buses that can accommodate the elderly and the handicapped .
Advancement in technology will also attract more investors and business opportunities to the country that will contribute to the country's economic growth .
Investing in technology would not just benefit the needy people but also the people as a whole in the country .
Military spending is crucial in maintaining an 'insurance policy' with no buffer zone against potential aggressors .
In 2009 , more than a quarter of the country's expenditure , or $11 .4 billion , had been directed to defence - an increase of 5 .6 per cent over previous year's budget  .
This has shown the importance the government place on the Singapore defence .
Singapore sees terrorism as one of the biggest threats to its security and economy .
Attacks in recent years in the United States and neighbouring countries such as Indonesia have prompted it to increase its vigilance against similar risks .
With the threat of terrorism intensifying , Singapore should never let its guard down but invest more on its defence in order to be more vigilant .
Military spending should strive to be one of the top priorities of the government as it concerns the safety and security of everybody in Singapore .
In summation , it is important that the government continue to provide financial assistance for the elderly due to the increasing number senior citizen .
However , this public spending should not be done at the expense of other expenditures that concern the country as a whole such as technology and defence .
Investing in technology and defence will eventually benefit everyone in Singapore including the elderly and other people in need in terms of better living condition and greater security .
Singapore government should continue to be cautious about how it allocates its expenditure such that it will bring the utmost profit to the country .

To begin with , the current global economic climate is not helping matters much .
Therefore , firstly , money should be diverted into the economic sector , namely stimulation of the domestic economy .
For example , the $20 .5 billion resilience package announced by the government of Singapore is intended to save jobs by helping valuable companies survive the recession , prepare for the near future , increase the competitiveness of the country and prevent a further slump in the economy  .
Assistant schemes such as the 'GST' offsets , rebates , service and conservancy charge rebates serve to act as a stimulus for the country in hope that the people will spend more to keep the economy afloat .
In the face of such a situation , spending on the aged is of least priority .

The second way in which money can be diverted into the economy is through spending on infrastructure .
Banking , communication and transportation are just some examples of infrastructure that a country needs to invest in to stay ahead in the age of globalisation .
Such investments will provide stability to the country in the long-run as it increases the confidence of potential investors .
Investments in communication and transportation make the country more 'accessible' , hence promoting both local and overseas investments .
However on the other hand , critics argue that the economic growth alone does not dictate a country's development .
They claim that spending on the aged is as important .
According to Peter G . Peterson  , "demographic changes such as the increasing population of the aged will have a serious consequence on healthcare issues in developed countries" and he also goes on to advocate ways to spend on healthcare .
But if this spending can be alternatively channelled into other sectors of the country's development , such as infrastructure and domestic economy as mentioned above , the country will achieve long-run success and stability .
Hence the demographics of a country alone , does not determine its destiny .
Therefore , public spending should be spent on a country's economical development .
Another way in which money can be well spent on the country's development would be to spend on societal needs such as education and general healthcare .
As the saying goes , "knowledge is power" and rightly so .
Singapore was able to pull itself out of the rut from a third world country to a first world country in one generation due to its focus on well utilised human resource .
And the main contributor was education .
Public spending on education accounts for 19 .3% of the total budget and is second in terms of priority in spending succeeding defence  .
A well educated society will always be at an advantage and this will act as a catalyst for further growth in several other sectors in Singapore's economy .
Hence a knowledge based economy will propel the nation into societal development .
The flipside to this issue is that , sectors such as healthcare play an important role in a country's societal development too .
Public spending on aged healthcare accounts for the bulk of the spending which is precisely why it should be limited .
Children of the aged should be given more responsibility for shouldering the financial needs of their parents rather than the government .
This allows money to be spent on more pertinent sectors such as education which has been a traditional source of growth for Singapore .
Hence , public spending on the economy and aspects of society outweigh spending on the aged as money can be better utilized elsewhere for a country's development .
A failure in proper public spending would therefore cripple the country and its development .

Response to "Economic growth fell well below expectations" .
Posted to http://theonlinecitizen .com/2009/01/economic- growth-fell-well-below-expectations/
The issue of graying population was highlighted in Mehta and Wee that one out of four Singaporeans will be 60 years and above by 2030 .  .
In other words , there will be a significant portion of the nation's populace being a senior citizen in the near future .
To facilitate the aging process , the Singapore government has since build on existing policies as well as develops new ones that are pertinent to the current society .
First and foremost , as Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports has announced , a law was revised in 1996 for aged parents to seek maintenance from their children , who are competent of supporting them and yet unwilling to do so .
In this aspect , the government is entirely supportive of children fulfilling the filial obligations .
The law advocates for adult children to care for their aged folks instead of leaving them alone by themselves to integrate with the society and figure about survival .
This was further supported by Peterson who has also brought up the concept of children's responsibility in sustaining elderly parents .
Secondly , the Central Provident Fund was wittingly devised as a social safety net for every Singaporean adult and his or her family members who are reliant .
Every month , a portion of the individual's income goes into the CPF .
The total sum will then be released to the individual on monthly basis once he or she is above 60 years old and is no longer working until the sum is exhausted .
This will then aid the retirement process .
In fact in Mehta and Wee  , when a minimum amount of money is used to buy a life annuity from an official insurance company or bank , the retiree will obtain a flat monthly income for life even if he or she outlives the balance in the annuity account .
A MediShield scheme is also part of CPF where money can be utilized for part of the hospital bills and costly medical expenses .
In spite of the CPF being in favour for retirees or to alleviate medical expenses incurred , not everyone in the Singapore population would stand to gain from it .
In the society , there is still a fraction who remain jobless or whose job do not have a steady contribution to the CPF .
This means to say upon retirement , there will be those who are not entitled to receive a fixed amount monthly or be subsidized partially for their health disbursement .
As age increases , chronic illnesses inevitably rise alongside and the burden of medical cost may simply be too much for one to bear .
To make things worse , treating of illnesses goes beyond long hospital stays , it stretches on to after being discharge as well as the need for rehabilitation , medication and the list goes on .
Unfortunately , amidst the other expenditures such as housing rentals and utilities bills , families usually opt to decline treatments or even ignore their chronically illed parents .
In fact , there are even cases where adult children abandon their parents in nursing homes to fend for themselves .
On the other side of the coin , as in Mehta and Wee  , PAP government has promised that no Singaporean will be deprived of basic hospital care even if he or she is incapable of affording it .
Thus , a MediFund scheme which is not part of CPF and is non-contributory was produced .
The fund is out from the government budgetary surpluses .
Additionally , Government has also provided a sum of $30 million for National Council of Social Services and those under its umbrella to execute a range of social services .
These finances will definitely relieve the burdens shouldered by individuals without the CPF .
Social workers are also plant in the society who can direct families to appropriate helpline for instance , the rent and utilities assistance scheme whenever the need arises .
Therefore , in any areas which individuals require assistance be it medical affairs or retirement issues , there is always a policy or two which one can turn to for alleviation of current situation .
Indeed , the government has come up with numerous policies and measures to help smooth the process of aging .
Fast aging in population is an issue that most countries including Singapore cannot avoid .
Several problems which relate to the issue include Health , Financial and Welfare of the elderly has come under the concern of the government .
Solutions such as having different subsidy frameworks for community hospitals to help patients to cope with the expensive bills and monthly Transport allowance for elderly who visit day-care centres were implemented to ease the tension that fast aging has brought to the low income elderly .
A decrease in the labour force due to retired workers and providing elderly with a place to stay are the issues that the Singapore government is working on now .
Fast ageing in Singapore has certainly affected its labour market as the level of retirement rate increase .
A research report done by the Ministry of Manpower Singapore in year 1999 showed that in year 2020 the old age will be increased to 32% compared to 16% in 1998  .
This implies that there will be a labour shortage of experienced workers who are able to contribute to the labour force after they have retired .
For example , new workers who are hired to replace the vacancy of the retired workers often lack experience and knowledge .
As a result , the workers might not be able to complete the task due to their minimum knowledge and skills therefore , the functioning of the company will be affected  .
One of the solutions to minimize the impact of labour shortage could be to re-employ the retired workers and allow them to guide the new workers on the job as well as sharing their working experience that will benefit the new workers .
Providing shelters to the single or low-income elderly is one of the priorities in the housing estate development program .
Single or low-income elderly could choose to rent a flat from the Housing Development Board or downgrade their current flat to a smaller one as this will allow the elderly to have extra cash for them to spend after their retirement .
HDB will also be building more compact and affordable 30-year lease studio apartment to cater to the demand for the elderly who aged 55 and above  .
Besides that , more HDB rental flats will also be upgraded with more Elderly-Friendly Facilities .
Facilities such as , having lifts on every floor , installing features like support handbars in the toilets and along common corridors to assist in the mobility of the elderly and installing an alert alarm system in the house when the elderly residents need to seek for any emergency help  .
No matter how many hardware facilities were installed to improve the staying environment of the elderly , they still feel empty and lonely especially if one has no family .
According to a health topic published by Changi General Hospital , elderly tends to be at a much higher risk of depression and ending one's life than the young as they are facing several changes in their life such as illnesses , losses of family member , life partners and friends as well as financial issues which include no income after retirement  .
Therefore , several voluntary programs have been implemented to serve as a helping hand to the elderly .
Program such as The Befriender Service , provided by Lions Befrienders is working closely with Central Singapore ComCare Local Networks in the aim of easing the loneliness , isolation and boredom of the single elderly and the homebound and also providing services such as advisory and assistance to the elderly  .
Coping with fast ageing in Singaporean is a slow and tough process which requires both the government and its citizens to work closely together .
Either encouraging retired workers to return to the work force or providing a decent shelter for the low income elderly will defiantly send a positive message to the elderly that they are not being abandoned and they are still recognised by the society .
Programs such as visiting the elderly or providing assistance to the elderly will also increase their confidence and accept the society again .
Singapore has a population of 4 .8 million and 8 .7% percent of them are aged .
The aged are part of the society we should also take into consideration their needs  .
With limitations , it will create more social problems and repercussions that result in higher costs that far outweigh the amount of money that was transferred to other developments .
Due to the decrease in healthcare aid for elderly , lack of community hospitals and housing homes , social problems would be generated .
The outcome would be homeless elderly turning into beggars and outbreak of diseases as healthcare becomes unaffordable for them to maintain and hygiene becomes an issue .
Investors and tourists would be deterred from entering Singapore as this does not reflect the branding of Singapore to be clean , green and having a stable economy .
The government might end up paying more for the aftermath just for the sake of transition of budgets in other developments .

This employment can help to spur economic growth and help in recession .

In contrast , public spending on the aged should be limited and routed for the less well-off section of the society .
With consumer price index for low income groups rising to 7 .5% in June 2008 and developments in globalization , it creates vast income inequalities in Singapore  .
The Department of Statistics commented that 14 .8% of households here earned $2 ,000 or less a month in 2008 , which explains the need for more money to be pumped into the social safety net .
However , there are initiatives such as Comcare Fund , which assists the less privileged group in Singapore .
The Comcare Fund's budget is $63 .7 million in 2008 and this amount is estimated to be $168 million in this financial year  .

The policies and investments on the aged for today is the preparation by the Government to mould a better future for tomorrow .

ComCare sets aside S$1m to help the needy cope with inflation .

Book
2 .
Tsung-hsi Fu , Rhidian Hughes .
Ageing in East Asia , Challenges and Policies for the twenty-first century .
New York: Routledge
It is an undeniable fact that our society is aging rapidly .
By 2030 , 20% of the population in Singapore will be aged 65 and above  .
Hence , several polices have been implemented by the government to help ease the aging process .
The upgrading of housing and encouraging later retirement age policies have indeed helped to ease the aging process to a large extent .
Upgrading of housing by the HDB , particularly the elderly households , has helped to ease the aging process .
Facilities within the blocks were enhanced significantly to aid in the day-to-day movement of the elderly  .
These include installing lifts at every floor as well as support hand bars in the toilets .
In order to allow the elderly to receive immediate help in times of emergency , alert alarm systems are fitted in every flat .
These changes have made the lives of the elderly more convenient leading to a greater sense of security instilled in them .
Voluntary Welfare Organization  , which is located below the block , will operate a Seniors Activity Centre to provide support services for the elderly living in the block  .
It creates a cohesive community where the elderly can integrate themselves into the society through participating in various social activities .
Consequently , some of the social and emotional problems that the elderly faced have been resolved .
In addition , encouraging later retirement has proved to ease the ageing process .
Working reduces the elderly reliance on their children as well as the society in terms of economic and social needs  .
As work keeps them occupied , they do not feel the need for their children's companionship .
On top of that , working provides the elderly a source of income enabling them to remain financially independent , hence reducing the financial dependency on the children .
The Government has been cooperating with employers and unions as part of the Tripartite Committee on Employability of Older Workers to enact re-employment legislation by 1 January 2012 so that employees can continue to work beyond the statutory retirement age of 62 , up to 65  .
Even before this re-employment legislation has taken effect , more than 700 unionized companies have committed to re-employ around 5 ,000 workers above the age of 62 .
In fact , working not only allows the elderly to spend their time meaningfully , it can also help to increase their self-esteem and find their own identity in the society  .
This helps them realize that they still stand a foothold in the society as they can still contribute to the nation and economic growth , therefore helping them to lead an enriching and fulfilling life .
However , critics have argued that the elderly might not possess the essential skills that are relevant and required in the workforce today  .
This is because the society is constantly changing , hence the skills possessed by the older generation becomes obsolete and no longer applicable today .
Moreover , it has been rebutted that they may face difficulty coping with the fast-paced society and technologically advanced workforce of today  .
However , there are retraining programs available for the elderly to upgrade their skills in order to keep themselves updated and constructive in the workforce .
For an instance , a $600 million Skills Programme for Upgrading and Resilience was launched by the government in November 2008 to retrain and upgrade both the employed and unemployed to prepare them for the newer and better jobs .
Hence , allowing the older generation to stay longer in the workforce not only promotes economic growth of the country , but also keeps them physically active , mentally alert , resilient and socially connected to the society .
Aging population is an unavoidable issue today that needs to be addressed urgently .
It is therefore important to make sure that policies implemented are useful in helping to ease the aging process .
With the current policies such as upgrading of their residences' facilities and longer working lives , the aging process has been eased to a large extend .
According to Singapore Department of Statistics , the average life expectancy for a boy and a girl born in 2006 is 78 .0 years and 82 .8 years respectively .
As compared to 2003 , it shows an increased of 1 .4 years and 1 .2 years correspondingly  .
Increasing life expectancy has inevitably led to the growth of aging population .
Aging is a complex and continuous process that begins with birth and ends with death .
Every person will experience the effect of aging process when they age .
In order to help ease the aging process , efforts have been made in the research developments and policies implementation to meet the physical and financial needs of each individual .
It is crucial to meet the physical needs of the people so as to ease their aging process .
As people become old , their physical health will deteriorate .
Moreover , their body immune system usually weakens .
Hence , efforts have been made in development to minimise the physical problems and vulnerabilities of the people .
One such effort is to make commuting more convenient for the aged and wheelchair-bound through the introduction of Wheelchair Accessible Buses .
With low-floor and steps-free design , these new transit buses have made boarding and alighting more manageable for the aged and disabled  .
Furthermore , the Lift Upgrading Programme has also aided the elderly by having lifts landing on every floor  .
These developments have created a living environment that is more barrier-free for our seniors and people with disabilities .
As such , they can fully participate in their everyday activities .

In addition , much has been done to provide the essential financial assistance for the elderly .
The inability to pay for expensive medical treatments has revealed the need to provide healthcare support for them .
For example , Prime Minister Mr Lee Hsien Loong had introduced a step-down care policy during the 2009 National Day speech .
This is to link up acute hospitals , such as Tan Tock Seng Hospital , with community hospitals , such as St Andrew's Community Hospital , to provide skilled and suitable healthcare especially for the aged  .
When patients are sick , they will go to acute hospitals for treatment and recuperate at the community hospital .
This way , proper healthcare at a reduced medical cost is made available for them .
Another example is the introduction of Medisave .
It is a national medical saving policy designed to help Singaporeans build up sufficient savings to meet their hospitalisation expenses .
Hence , healthcare needs can be met without increasing the financial burden faced by the people .
On the contrary , critics pointed out that the current policies and research improvements have only helped to minimise problems on a superficial level but have not fully met the emotional needs of the individuals when they grow old .
When one ages , he may be less optimistic and feel disconnected from the society .
Hence , emotional support is an important psychological factor in helping them to forget the negative aspects of their lives  .
However , we cannot deny the recent efforts that had been made to help to satisfy such needs .
For instance , Government Organisation has moved from seniority-based to performance-based wage structure .
Senior workers , with their rich working experience may be able to contribute greatly to the organisation and are encouraged to be re-hired .
This wage structure ensures employability and job security for the elder workers and it prevents them from feeling detached from the society  .
In addition , under the Central Provident Fund's Housing Grant Scheme , the government provides a grant of $10 ,000 to $40 ,000 for families buying flats near their parents' residences  .
This allows the elderly to be closed to their children and some may even undertake the responsibilities of taking care of their grandchildren .
This helps them to feel valued and thereby , aids in the re-discovery of their identities as a senior citizen .
In conclusion , in order to help ease the aging process , the Singapore government has been improving and implementing various policies and research developments to meet the physical , financial and emotional needs of the individual .
These efforts have proven to be effective .

Over the years , an aging population has become an impediment at hand as many countries have been experiencing it , especially in Singapore where statistics have shown that 11 .3% of the population will be aged fifty-five years and above in 2015  .
The younger generation is more career-oriented , which has resulted in later marriages and also lower birthrates .
This burgeoning trend ultimately leads to an aging population and the Singapore government has come up with several policies and development in different fields such as ameliorating the CPF scheme and inventing elderly-related products to cater to the elderly needs .
In light of the many policies and development that have been devised by the Singapore government to address elderly concerns , the aging process will be eased as most of their problems have been addressed .
Some would argue that policies implemented by the Singapore government might not be fully utilized as some companies find it troublesome to comply with it to employ older workers due to several factors .
Critics have claimed that some companies refrain from hiring seniors to avoid spending more time , money and effort in retraining them  .
However , this is not a plausible reason to deter the companies from hiring the elderly as the government has improvised a scheme known as the ADVANTAGE fund to encourage more companies to shift towards automation that facilitate the older populace and to re-employ the elderly by giving out incentives and subsides for retraining programmes of the elderly  .
For example , Sheng Siong Supermarket , who hires senior workers , was able to buy machinery that helps to expedite the production process from one month to ten to fifteen days and increase their productivity by using the government subsides  .
Therefore , social policies , such as the ADVANTAGE scheme , are pertinent to facilitate the elderly in working in a less physically-demanding environment and stay productive .

It is mandatory for everyone in Singapore to have a Central Provident Fund account .
This initiative by the government helps to ensure that all elderly will have a means of income that will provide them through their golden years .
Recent adjustments made to the CPF on 3 September 2009 have played a significant role in reducing the working-age population's tax burden and also in increasing the elderly's CPF .
For instance , the interest rate of the CPF for savings in the Special , Medisave and Retirement Accounts will be maintained at 4% floor rate instead of the current 3 .40% for the next two years  .
This eases the economic aspect of an aging population as the elderly can benefit from a higher interest rate and therefore alleviate the deterioration of the aging process .
With an increasingly aging population , many innovative companies have invented several elderly-related products such as hearing aids and automatic wheelchairs to support their large demand for health-care products .
The government has also developed property such as studio apartments with barrier-free accessibilities for the elderly .
All these helped to lessen the elderly's problems of hearing , seeing or moving properly .
For example , two students from Temasek Polytechnic have developed a wheelchair that automatically engages the safety gear whenever it slides backwards .
This helps to ease the inconvenience for those who are incapable of engaging the conventional brakes or holding on to the wheels manually  .
Such innovations ease the problem that the physically restricted are encountering in the process of aging .
In conclusion , it is true that the current research and development or policies have helped to ease the aging process due to the proper and effective planning adopted by the Singapore government .
Issues such as the reluctance of companies to hire older workers are ameliorated due to the ADVANTAGE scheme whereby subsides encourage them to re-employ the aged .
The changes made to the interest rate of the CPF for savings in the SMRA will provide a social safety net for the elderly , while the increase in elderly- related products and studio apartments further eases the physically restricted aspects of an elderly .
However , these policies and development can help to ease the aging process only if people abandon their social stigma on the elderly populace .

Sheng Siong gets a lift from machines .
