Singapore Minister Articulates Government Thinking on Addressing Issues of An Ageing Population http://www .egovmonitor .com/node/28185
"As Singapore becomes accustomed to being an affluent and rapidly ageing society , the issue of financing the aged has become more pressing requiring reassessment of the existing arrangements ."
Should the Singapore government spend more on the aged or should the money be diverted to other areas of the country's development ?
By generating economic growth for the country , the aged would also benefit .
Public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
Public spending refers to expenditure by government .
A principal source of revenue or income to pay for public spending is taxation .
Some of the other areas in the country's development that require public spending are like social services and benefits , education , infrastructure and development projects like transport , housing and employment .
It is important for the government to spend in this area so that the country's economy and social condition will improve .
Many argue that limiting public spending on the elderly would only leave individuals and their families to face issues pertaining to education , housing , social services and transportation .
By cutting expenditure on welfare programs for the elderly , individuals and families are more responsible for a larger share of the elderly costs .
They would need to provide the cost for their own old age dependency , according to Robert B . and Laura S . in Doomsday .
Besides , such costs may even be bigger than the original cost of running welfare programs for the elderly .
In addition , limiting public spending on the aged would mean that individuals have to provide the cost for their own old age dependency .
This is a beneficial for the country as people learn to depend on themselves .
They would be able to able to work better , attain higher income so as to help support education , housing , social services and rising cost of transportation for themselves .
It would be more practical in a case when there is economic downturn and the government is not able to spend on the aged .
"An aging population will push up pension and healthcare costs , forcing major increases in public spending that could slow economic growth in rich and poor countries ."
Clearly , as Singapore experiences the problem of ageing population , it is important to generate economic growth for the country and benefit the aged .
Higher expenditure on areas like infrastructure and education , allows the country to achieve greater economic growth which this in turn solve the problems of aging population .
With better economic and social condition in the country , people would become richer and affluent .
This would then reduce the worries of individuals and their families about issues pertaining to education , housing , social services and transportation .
But even though there are schemes to make people save for their aged now , the older generation who have little or no education , are not able to comprehend what these schemes are about and what benefits do they get .
Therefore they need the aid of the government to help them cope with their medical issues and their daily lives .
More elderly friendly facilities along neighbourhood should be built and good values such as giving up seats to the elderly should be taught to the public to help the elderly get along with their daily lives .
Like in Singapore , there are priority seats for elderly so that they do not have to stand for long distances .
If money were to be diverted to other area of developments , the problem of ageing population will still persists , the situation might worsen as they may not know how to support themselves and cause even more social problems .
Therefore public spending is essential , it should not be limited to assist the developments of other areas of development and neglect the major problem of ageing population that many countries face .
However , many social problems caused by the elderly are mainly due to the lack of education .
More resources should be allocated to develop the country's education system so as to ensure the continuous supply of good labour and also to educate the public the importance of self-reliance .
With more people receiving education , they will understand the importance of planning for their future and develop the culture of taking care of themselves and their elderly .
Therefore , funding for the aged should be limited so as to allow the other areas of development such as the education sector which have a greater impact on society to thrive .
The most prominent demographic trends in the world today would be the aging of population , which can also be known as demographic aging which simply means the shift in the age distribution of a population toward older ages .
, The Encyclopaedia of Population .
New York , Macmillan Reference USA) .
An aging population have many social , economic and health implications to a country and this common occurrence is not just a short term resultant but a long term problem caused by the falling of fertility rates and high mortality .
Aging of a population has become such a natural process that is happening among most of the developing countries and Singapore is not being spared too .
In fact , Singapore is one of the fastest aging populations in Asia and therefore , there is a need for the government to develop and implement new public policies to accommodate to this newly emerging group of people in the near future .
Hence , with a need for new public policies would mean a need for greater public spending on the aged so as to cater for this newly emerging group who is age 65 years and above , this would make up nearly one-fifth of our population by 2030 .
"Over the past two decades , journalists and scholars have periodically commented on how rising public spending for older people is expected to threaten if not erode public commitments to other deserving groups ."
said Paul W . Newacheck  .
Public spending is money expended from the government to pay for the country's expenses  .
The money can come from different sources , with the majority coming from taxation .
For instance , the tax policy in Singapore is drawn out based on the notion of guiding desirable behaviour towards different economic and social goals .
Therefore , public spending should not emphasize only social , but also economic development of the country .
However , there are many emerging concerns about the ageing society in many developed countries .
Limiting public spending for the aged may in turn bring about social problems major issues regarding family responsibilities and dignity .
As the percentage of the aged increases , the percentage of people generating income in the country diminishes .
Without the government to shoulder part of the burden , most immediate families of the elderly will find it financially taxing on their part .
In worse cases , cash-strapped children will be unwilling to take care of them due to the high standards of living and healthcare costs increasing each year .
This problem falls back on society , as abandoned parents will be left to fend for themselves  .
A research in Singapore shows that the Geylang East Home for the Aged , a shelter for elderly abandoned by their family , said that its 37-bed home is always full .
In many cases , the families of these abandoned aged just passed their responsibility to another institution .
Also , I feel that most elderly people have a strong sense of dignity and self worth , considering their lifelong achievements and efforts throughout the years  .
These people are most probably not going to turn to government's aid even if their own families reject them .
Without the government's initiatives , the elderly people are going to go through a hard time coping in the society .
Nonetheless , it still can be argued that directing public spending to other areas of the country's development can indirectly offset these social problems .
With the flexibility to invest in other areas , we can empower these three groups of people: Employers , families and the elderly .
Firstly , this amount of money can be used to help businesses and individuals struggling from the recent economic crisis .
For instance , the government implemented the Job Credit Scheme in Singapore .
This scheme was introduced to preserve jobs during the economic downturn .
Basically , participating employers will receive a cash grant based on the CPF contributions they have made for their existing employees .
It serves as a winning tool as the employers get to bring their businesses to a higher level , and the existing workers in turn retain their jobs .
In this way , these benefiters can fulfill their basic responsibilities better , in taking care of their own families with the higher purchasing power they have .
Secondly , education and learning are important factors attributing to one country's success .
With the society changing constantly , the monetary support which the government can provide is only temporary .
Often , people need to improve themselves to keep up with the demands and needs of their surrounding milieu .
For example , investing on current employees to advance their expertise in the workplace can land them with better promotion prospects and job security .
Equipping the younger generation with relevant skills can also allow them higher chances of securing better jobs of their preferences in the future .
Also , the government can educate these people about their responsibilities by emphasizing the role of the family in caring for the elderly  .
With better jobs and increase in income , they can help the families in coping with the high standards of living and spiraling healthcare costs for the aged .
As a result , social stability can be fulfilled while economic growth is being spurred .
Lastly , investments can be made on healthcare to empower the aged to take charge of their own health .
Research studies in New York showed that living a healthy lifestyle is very important to the elderly people in their journey of conquering new physical , emotional and mental challenges  .
The level of physical activity needed to be exerted for beneficial results is attainable by majority of the aged  .
The government can also hold "Healthy Lifestyle" campaigns to encourage the aged to engage more actively , and promote healthy aging .
On top of that , the involvement of their immediate families in the process will be a bonus in helping them cope with ageing .
With a blissful mind and a healthy body , these elderly will be less likely to seek emotional and social help from the government .
All in all , limiting public spending on the aged and directing on other areas of development such as businesses , education and healthcare is more rewarding then just focusing on the needy groups .
Although the help is theoretically superficial , it is indirectly helping the society to deal with the ageing society more effectively than using the monetary support , which is a temporary solution .
This solution is made much easier when we understand the bigger picture .
If we do not pay attention to the long term effects the problem is going to cause , we will risk the possibility of allocating the limited resources for the wrong usage .
The aged might have devoted their youth and even their whole life to serving the society , public spending on the aged is therefore necessary .
In fact , every one of us either doing mental or physical work , have made a significant contribution towards the development of society .
One's life to go through a juvenile , youth , middle-aged and older period is an irresistible law of nature .
Hence , as long as a person has sacrificed for the social development , then , when he is old and no longer contribute his own force in his area of work , the state government should give him his deserved rewards by taking care of their future .
If the public spending on the aged is limited , the burden on the children or younger generation will be much heavier since they have to bear more expenses of their parents .
It was claimed that families and individuals will face many issues if welfare programs are cut or restructured  .
A survey in China showed that "living and working pressure makes people powerless to take care of their parents" has become a great difficulty for young people now  .
In today's society , many people of working age , with their own careers and families , withstand considerable economic pressure .
Once the elderly reach their old age , it is followed by a variety of ailments .
Expensive medical and health care costs other than the very high daily cost indeed cause a more serious difficulty .
So when the children have to bear the medical expenses and the costs of everyday life of their parents , they tend to live beyond their income .
The gap between the rich and the poor in the present society is still apparent that when the government subsidies reduce , high-income groups of retired people may still have an easy life , but the relatively poor people will face even tougher difficulties of livelihood .
Higher income people tend to have more savings , so that they can enjoy a carefree retirement .
However , low-wage sectors of the population in general do not have much savings since they even face insufficiencies of money during daily life .
To the later years , if they encounter ungrateful children who are unwilling to take care of them , then how do they spend their remaining days ?
Many people today spend money on their own organized families , to meet the needs of their children , as well as the pursuit of material comfort of their own instead of taking out money to supply their parents .
At this point , a notion of "Parental Support Law" has been suggested to force the children to be filial to their parents  .
However , children' support for their elderly parents is a kind of moral value and the performance of the human behavior norms under the education system .
If law is to require people to support their parents , does it mean that our moral values have to deteriorate to such an extent ?
Clearly , the public spending on the aged should be conserved to protect the rights and benefits of the aged .
The aged have dedicated so much to the development of country that they should be thanked .
Reduced public spending will increase the burden of the children and furthermore , poor people will become poorer .
We should care for the aged despite only considering for the sake of economic interests .
In fact , we all grow old one day .
According to Singapore Department of Statistic , the life expectancy of Singaporean has increased noticeably to 78 .0 for male and to 82 .8 for female  .
Although that is good news proving for Singapore's success as other developed nations , it also leads to some unpleasant consequences for Singapore such as raising the financial burden for elderly-caring .
From my perspective , economic development is not only the key factor easing the aging but also is the key solution for some serious problems caused by this process .
First of all , judging this issue from one particular angle , it is commonly believed that well-funded life which rises from economic success will help people to be able to purchase sufficient food for their own demands .
At the same time , there are more facilities supplying for human needs on physical exercise , such as pools for swimming , courts for playing tennis , indoor gyms for various kind of sports .
With the financial sufficiency , people can ease their life and avoid dangerous work by using some helpful equipment .
For instance , living in air-conditioning building helps us confront with hot summer and cold winter or using remote robots reduces the cost of lives in some high-risk jobs .
In the other words , as a result of the spreading of economic , we have been enjoyed a better physically-healthy life .
At the second point , economic development also encourages the improvement of services which support human life .
Among of them , entertainment industry should be mentioned as the most noticing one .
Together with its urging , more and more entertainment parks , visual and virtual products such as films and games come into our life .
Moreover , the expansion of consultation services and the growth of tourism have considerably contributed to satisfying our mental demands .
For example , a typical citizen in a globalised city , such as Tokyo or London , now can enjoy the weekend-time in a hundred destinations for recreation and some of them are world-wide known .
Alternatively , they can stay at home and choose among tens of local and international channels to watch or can surf internet to visit millions of websites .
Indeed , it is no doubt that they all have been enriched the human mental life .
What is more , a prosperous economy can also foster further technological invention , medical innovation as well as educational improvement which all are considered as important factors alleviating the aging process .
Once government sufficiently finances medical research , more diseases can be cured or prevented more effectively .
In the same pattern , once the educational level is raised , people can be more aware of how to take care of themselves as well as to live long and healthily .
In conclusion , today developed countries have been increasingly confronted with the aging process and its consequences .
In the common thought , all economics , science , social policy contribute to easing this process but economic factor attracts most of our concerns as it should be viewed as the most important one .
All things are considered , a prosperous economy not only lengthens the life expectancy but also make people live more healthily and lighten social burden on elderly-caring .
While the population is shifting towards a greying one , many would start to worry about the ease of aging in the current society , especially amidst the time of financial crisis and difficulty .
Current research and development such as medical advancement and barrier free housing estates are examples that have helped ease the aging process .
However , more emphasis should be placed on the development of social policy helping to alleviate and address concerns such as the lack of financial support and social care , as it affects the elderly more directly .
Meanwhile , there are already policies in place , such as the Central Provident Fund  , Lease Buy Back Scheme and housing grants for married children staying near parents , which are all structured to aid the aged in terms of financial and healthcare issues .
Central Provident Fund is a savings account for all workers in Singapore to set aside a sum of 33 percent of their wages for retirement purposes while working .
This sum of money will serve as a source of income when one cannot work in the future due to old age .
On top of that , a subset of the CPF called the Medisave account , will serve as a backup sum to pay for any medical bills should the need arises .
Thereby , they would not have to strain their pockets to pay for healthcare when they have already stopped working .
At this juncture , one may wonder how could the Medisave account be sufficient when medical fees these days are so steep .
Common illnesses such as stroke would already chalk up thousands for treatment and things could be a lot worse , should there be more than one illness to treat .
However , this could be solved by purchasing Medishield or third party healthcare insurance using the Medisave itself .
The insurance will serve to cover most of the medical expenses , if not all .
In the event that an individual is not able to pay the minimum amount , they can apply for the Medifund , which is an endowment plan funded by the nation's economic growth , targeted to help those who still cannot afford to pay the bills despite already being heavily subsided .
With these in place , the aged will be well taken care of and have a peace of mind , in monetary aspect , living in a more comfortable environment during old age .
For those elderly who have funds but are locked in the area of housing assets , have a solution too .
Just recently in March 2009 , the government has introduced the Lease Buy Back Scheme for elderly to sell off their tail end thirty years lease of their flats in return for life-long monthly retirement income .
These elderly will stand to enjoy a supplement to their retirement income on top of what they are receiving from CPF payout .
Depending on the age group , an amount ranging from $500 to $800 will be issued to them monthly after an upfront sum of $5000 .
Again , we can see how public policy has shaped to help the elderly have a less financial taxing aging process .
Apart from being well taken care of in medical bills , the social well-being of the aged is taken into consideration as well .
It is in the government's interest that these elderly do receive an appropriate amount of attention and care so that they will not be deprived of company at old age .
This is why the Housing Development Board came up with a housing grant of forty thousand dollars to encourage the housing of nucleus family members near their parents .
The policy will not only benefit the purchaser in cutting cost but will also help to propagate the importance of filial obligation in the society .
When the married children are housed near to their parents , they are more likely to visit them frequently due to convenience and simultaneously , the elderly will be taken care of physically as well .
Opponents of this position may argue that the opposite may take place instead .
Rather than having the married couple to look after their parents , it might be the children exploiting the convenience of their parents , living off them or even increasing the burden on them such as treating them as babysitters for their own children .
Nevertheless , taking this situation from another point of view actually aligns with the government's aim: fostering mutual care between the young and elderly .
By housing them in vicinity , it actually adds livelihood and purpose to the lives of the elderly as well .
"That's why fitness facilities , children's playground and elderly exercise equipment are put together" quoted Mr Mah BT in a housing speech .
All this contributes to making the aging process a more fruitful and meaningful one .
In the presence of these numerous social policies , many aspects of the aging process have been well covered by the government and this has served to mitigate some of the most common concerns among the elderly .
These policies have benefited the elderly and will continue to provide assistance to them in the future .
Therefore , it is evident that current research and policies have helped to ease the aging process and make retirement a less burdensome one .
The growth of the aging population is increasing at an alarming rate .
From research , in developed nations , people born in the twentieth century can live 35 years longer than people who were born in the nineties .
The increase in aging population reflects the need of better healthcare and social services .
This is because as people aged , their health will deteriorate and results in the increase of healthcare and social cost .
To ease this aging process , government and other industries initiated various efforts to reduce spending on healthcare and elderly dependency on the younger generation .
With continual advancement in the medical industry , current research and development in better healthcare services and facilities like building new community hospitals , providing long-term care services and developing electronic health record system can help ease the problems of healthcare cost and elder dependency .
Therefore , I agree that current research and development in the field of medicine have eased the aging process .
Firstly , building of new community hospitals provide intermediate healthcare for elderly who do not require consultation from the general hospitals .
With such developments , elderly can save cost and receive appropriate healthcare treatments more conveniently .
In contrary , convenience does not mean it is affordable .
Healthcare cost in Singapore is constantly rising with the advance in technology .
A single hospitalization can cost up to thousand of dollars .
If elderly do not have enough savings to support , they may depend financially on the government or their children .
However , Singaporeans enjoy healthcare subsidies .
The amount of subsidy on hospitalization will be determined by means-testing .
This way , the government reduces the financial dependency of elderly by providing help based on their financial needs .
In addition , there are also other financial subsidies available like the Medisave , Medishield and Medifund to keep healthcare cost affordable for Singaporeans .
Secondly , Long-term care services like home care and rehabilitation can allow patients to recover in surroundings that are more comfortable or with their families .
These Long-term care services involve two board categories , residential healthcare and community healthcare managed by voluntary Welfare Organizations or by Private operators .
These are cheaper support alternatives to leaving elderly patients in hospitals .
In cases where family cannot provide attention or support for the needs of the elderly , they can seek for community healthcare services carried out at home or in a centre .
Such services can help to reduce elderly emotional dependency on their children too .
On the other hand , some volunteers for elderly home care or rehabilitation centre may lack of profession skills provided in hospitals .
Elderly may not be receiving the most appropriate medical help .
Fortunately , the government had already recognized the importance of such services to ease aging process .
In the 2009 budget speech , over $500 million will be spend in the next five years on training staffs and improving this long-term care services for elderly Singaporeans .
Thirdly , the development of electronic health record system helps to increase efficiency and accuracy of a medical diagnosis .
Elderly with chronic illnesses may have complex medical backgrounds .
With this system , medical information of the elderly will be stored in the database and it is accessible to medical institutions island wide .
As a result , doctors and staffs can reduce time in gathering healthcare background of elderly and reduce the amount of complicated paperwork .
There are arguments that implication of this system involves excessive costs .
Just by setting up the system nation-wide , the government will be spending about SGD$200 million over the next two years .
However , base on research , usage of the Electronic Health Record system can help to reduce duplication and error in medical prescription resulting in a cost reduction as much as USD$50 billion per year .
Therefore , we can conclude that this research and development can help to decrease healthcare spending and improve quality of service efficiently .
Today , as our society faced with the issue of ageing population , the needs of better healthcare and social services increased .
Advancement in research and development within medical industry has helped to ease aging population .
As a result , better healthcare services and facilities are created and have effectively reduced healthcare cost and elderly dependency .
With the constant advancement in healthcare system , people can enjoy a longer life with better health without putting the society in threat of aging .
To a large extent , I strongly agree that medical advancement have helped to ease the aging process .
In Singapore context , it states that 8% of the Singapore's population is over the age of 65 and by 2035 it will increase to 20% .
Hence , medical advancement will prove to be beneficial for the aging population in Singapore .
Despite the above mentioned , I would like to stress that not the entire aging population can access to the medical advancement .
The reason is because medical advancement is too costly in Singapore .
As such , a lot of aging population in Singapore will not be able to afford the high fees for medical advancement that includes the use of advance technology in medicine and treatments .
This might also lead to the sign of withdrawal from part of the population who would choose not to seek any medical help due to their affordability of the fees for medical advancement .
On the other hand , this arising problem has alerted the government to offer financial aids for the needy aging population in Singapore .
The Singapore government has been actively promoting awareness of health care issues among the elderly population in general .
The Ministry of Health has recently launched insurance financial plans for elder care .
The names of the insurance plans were called Eldershield and Eldershield Supplements  .
These programs will help provide helping hands for all needy aging population in Singapore .
This also encourage all the needy aging population in Singapore to sign up this insurance plan for them .
The reason for doing this is because the needy aging population in Singapore will be covered by this insurance plan .
Thus , when they want to use this insurance plan for any emergency uses , they can use it anytime .
Premiums for this insurance plan can also be made from Medisave .
Thus , all the needy aging population in Singapore will be taken care of by the Singapore government .
As such , families from aging population can also go to the respective hospitals to seek for financial aids for the medical advancement .
The Singapore government will be providing subsidy for all the elderly when they seek for medical advancement .
Thus , with the solutions given by the Singapore government , it will help all the aging population to gain an equal entitlement to the medical advancement .
In order to solve this high medical advancement expenses , Ministry of Health has been reaching out to the senior citizen in Singapore by implementing mobile screening buses for the monthly health check  .
Ministry of Health has decided to make the efficient accessible screening more affordable and convenient for all the needy aging population in Singapore .
All the needy aging population just need to pay less than $10 for the blood test for their health check comprising of diabetes and high cholesterol .
This also resulted that all the needy aging population in Singapore were given a chance to receive certain treatments of the medical advancement in Singapore .
Not only that , all the residential committees and community centres in the neighbourhoods were promoting this meaningful and encouraging health program to the needy aging population in singapore  .
Thus , this will be beneficial to all the aging population in Singapore who could not afford any medical fees .
Last but not least , I strongly agree that medical advancement have eased through the aging process with the help of the Singapore government .
Thus , this also shows that all the aging population in Singapore is being well taken care of by the Singapore government .
With the budget given by the government , the aging population in Singapore will be given an equal entitlement to the medical advancement so as to maintain a healthy lifestyle .
"Public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development ."
Do you agree ?
Introduction
It is always a thorny issue when it comes to allocation of the budget pie for the country's development .
Whether is it for educational , economical , societal or military advancement , it is of paramount importance that policy makers make suitable decisions in the best interests of the country and its people .
In my opinion , channeling too much government funds to taking care of the aged can have detrimental effects on the country's development .
Therefore , I am for the statement that public spending on the aged should be limited .
Uncontrolled government spending on healthcare or infrastructure for the aged could result in other groups of needy people not getting their share of the government's financial aid .
These include the handicapped , juvenile delinquents and low income families .
These less privileged groups of people are also members of the society who require our assistance .
Not attending to their needs may have serious impact on the society .
People from low income families struggling to make ends meet may be desperate and might resort to robbery and burglary to ease their financial burden .
Teenagers who engage in unlawful behaviours that defy established criminal codes or deviate from societal norms may continue with their misbehaviours such as running away from school or home , or even petty crimes , if they fail to receive help from respective government bodies and the community .
These are complex social problems that might significantly impact other members of the society , and hence , development of the country , if not handled appropriately .
Public funding is also required in the development of our education sector as Singapore continue to establish herself as an education hub .
In Singapore , the importance of education cannot be over emphasized .
Large amount of funds are pumped into the education sector so that the younger generation can receive the best education .
These could be in the form of better school sports and laboratory facilities , more funding for enrichment courses or even upgrading of school compound to accommodate more students .
On the hindsight , funding could also imply subsidies for needy students .
Students under Finance Assistant Scheme could be provided with school uniforms , school shoes and basic school materials .
Merit bursaries and scholarships can be awarded to students who excelled in their academic and exhibit positive traits and qualities in other aspects of their life .
Singapore also has a mandatory six years Primary Education for all Singaporean .
Financial aid will be needed to ensure that poor families , who cannot afford to send their children to school , could do so .
The ministry stands by the notion that no deserving student should be deprived of education .
As former president of the United State of America once said , "Our progress as a nation can be no swifter than our progress in education .
The human mind is our fundamental resource ."
It is clear that education is one of the key aspects for the progress of a nation .
Without sufficient funds from the government , these plans cannot be implemented to the fullest extent .
People often mention that Singapore only have got human resource .
Not developing our resources' full potential through education will indeed impede our country's development .
If significant amount of funds are needed in the education sector , there is then a need to limit expenditure on the aged .
It is difficult to draw the line as to who should be given how much of government's budget .
But it is important to realize that , channeling funds into the education sector for example may bring about more productive future generation who would in turn help to support the old aged in time to come .
In comparison , diverting funds to support the aged would appear to have no returns .
Diverting funds to other areas can be regarded as a better "investment" by policy makers and would aid in the country's development .
In conclusion , the government has to carry out careful planning on public spending .
Channeling excessive budget or limiting any one of the areas is not beneficial to the country's development .
The Government has to make critical decisions , reviewing their decisions regularly , so as to determine which aspects of the country's development should be the main focus at different period of time .
In the long run , the government must seek to make aging more secure for the older generation , at the same time less burdensome for the younger generation .
Perhaps government should introduce policies which could add value to the aged workers , in turn increasing their productivity .
Not try to accommodate the aging issue while limiting public spending on the aged .
With their vast knowledge and rich experience from the many years of contributing to the society , the aged would definitely be an important resource the country could tap on .
In the highly modernized world , most democratic countries depend on their government for support in an array of areas , usually in the form of monetary support .
Such financial supports by the government are termed as public spending .
A principal source of income for public spending comes from taxation .
As widely known , taxation is very limited and thus public spending has to be circumscribed .
Hence the efficient allocation of funds on public spending is deemed important as there public spending is definitely not able to cover the amount of funds required by the entire society .
Hence , the question as to how much we should spend on an area compared to another emanates .
Public spending are funds that are used on the society and the aged certainly has a share of it as well .
Diverting much of the public spending to different areas of the country's development is certainly abominable as we would be leaving the defenseless aged to fend themselves against the numerous problems that surface while aging .
Hence , we should limit the spending on the elderly , but only to a small extent so as not to create another problem to the elderly which adds on to their already heavy burden .
In a pragmatic view , channeling large amounts of funds to the developments of the country such as research and development and education would in the long run benefit the country's economic growth .
However , it would be morally wrong to leave the elderly who are part of the society alone .
The elderly did contribute much to the country in their younger age and the society should be obliged to look after them when they are older and not cast them aside .
Furthermore , public spending is made for everyone in the society to enjoy and seek help from and we cannot limit the funds for the elderly just because they are not able to produce any returns after enjoying the funds .
Therefore we should not limit public spending to a large extent .
With changing values in the developed countries , people are giving birth to fewer children .
This change in mindset changes the percentage of young against the old .
As a result , the percentage of old is certainly rising rapidly .
With increasing amount of people turning into old age , the portion of the public spending on the aged should not be decreasing instead .
Nonetheless , the focus of a country is to grow and prosper and developments on other areas are seemingly more important .
Therefore , the society has to maintain a high standard of living as a developed world and since elderly is the bulk of the society we should spend more to help improve their live so as not to lower our overall standard of living .
Hence we should spend on other developments but not to the expense of forgoing that for the elderly .
The aging process is an inevitable part of life .
It brings about physical , emotional and social changes that affect individuals significantly .
Following developments and advancements around the world , governments of developed nations are faced with the challenge of a fast aging population .
For example , in Singapore , it was reported that by the year 2030 , one in five residents will be 65 years or older , a significant shift compared to one in twelve residents in the year 2005 .
CITATION The04 \l 1033  .
As Singapore has limited resources , there is much concern about how much of the resources the government should spend on the aged .
However , public spending on the aged should not be sacrificed even in the face of practical realities as society has a moral duty to take care of the elderly .
The significance of limiting public spending on the aged is the shift of financial burden to the individuals and their families .
When government spending on the aged is cut down , it leaves the individuals and their families to shoulder a larger portion of the costs involved .
The financial allocation for the different usages and needs in the family have to be reconsidered as a result .
Adult children face with the dilemma between providing for their aged parents or supporting their young children education .
In most cases , the aged would be neglected or a few may even be abandoned in nursing homes .
CITATION Sal09 \l 1033  .
This gives rise to the social implications like the issue of filial piety that would have a negative impact on society .
The elderly had commendable contribution to the society when they were younger and active in the workforce .
Being an active part of the workforce in their earlier days , the elderly had contributed to the country's economy in a way .
They had played their part in the economy by being a tax payer in the country and bringing investment to Singapore by being productive and efficient members of the workforce .
Furthermore , the elderly had undergone experiences that differed significantly from the younger generations .
The lessons , skills and knowledge learnt through these experiences could be important and useful to the younger generations in dealing with the present and future challenges .
Hence , the elderly has significant contribution to the country even as they aged , which provides a strong background for the government and society to provide for the elderly .
The Asian moral values provides for individuals to help and respect their elders .
The elder population is seen to be knowledgeable with the ability to impart valuable lessons and experiences to the younger generation .
Furthermore , the elderly had worked in bringing up the younger generation .
Hence , in Asian culture , there is moral obligation to care and provide for the elderly .
While there is strong presence of moral obligation to care for the elderly , it cannot be denied that there are other groups of people who are similarly in need of government financial help .
For instance , the physically impaired population requires extensive medical needs which require government funding .
However , the elderly make up a large part of the population and is estimated to be on the rise as the years progress .
CITATION The04 \l 1033  .
Whereas , the physically impaired make up a relatively small part of the population in comparison and is present in different cluster of people .
It would thus , be more feasible for the physically impaired to turn to communal help from charitable organization than for the elder to turn to these organization for aids .
Hence , it would be a wiser choice for the government to provide for the elderly population as the huge population will require a significantly large amount of funding .
The challenges of an aging population will continue to increase as the years progress , and the issues arising from it are multifaceted .
However , this does not mean that we should limit public spending on the aged on the basis of their decreased efficiency and productivity to society .
Instead , moral responsibilities should be taken into consideration in policy planning , in order for planners to make acceptable policies for the community .

Allocation of the state's budget has to be justifiable .
With competing interests that necessitate public spending , public spending on the aged would most likely be restricted .
Our government needs to be pragmatic in its allocation of financial resources .
Areas of country's developments such as expanding on economic capability through business investment , allocating financial resources on infrastructure and technology , and investing on human capital place greater importance than providing to the financial needs of aged .
In fact , a more prosper economy should provide the economic means to support the public spending on the aged .
Thus , managing the economy should come first .
A pragmatic government would rather channel resources to other areas of country's developments .
Therefore , public spending on the aged should and will be limited .
Economic growth is the basis to substantiate the monetary and social welfare benefits for the aged people .
In most countries , a large fiscal budget is on the engines of economic growth .
In Singapore , the engines of growth are from the tourism sector and knowledge and research intensive industries .
In tourism sector , the focus is on two integrated resorts which are currently being developed .
It is critical for such investments to establish as it provides employment opportunities .
Increase in tourism arrivals and the attraction of high end consumers will result in generation of high tourism revenues and revenues from high end retail shops .
On the other hand , knowledge and capital intensive industries have started up quite recently in Singapore .
Fusionpolis , Biopolis and business hubs are set up in various parts of Singapore .
With all these economic developments , our economy can be expanded and sustained .
A stronger economy leads to higher household income .
Consequently , a larger tax base should then sufficiently provide a larger portion of public finances for the aged .
History reminds us of the contributions by our forefathers .
It is thus the responsibility of the society to look after them .
In countries such as United Kingdom , welfare system and pension scheme are in place .
In contrast , public spending for the aged is limited in Singapore .
We can increase public spending on aged , but it will compromise financial resources allocated for the general population .
In fact , investment should be on nurturing of our people as they are contributors to the economy .
Through training , re-training and investing on quality education , it nurtures the people .
Educational institutions provide quality teaching while re-training centres impart new skills so that skills do not become obsolete .
More public finance on aged will compromise the investments on human capital .
In addition , it only satisfies the social and moral obligations to the aged .
Being pragmatic , we should look towards creating a future for ourselves and the future generation .
In addition , the aged are not the only ones who require monetary support , other needy groups , such as handicaps , also require monetary support to fund their healthcare needs .
Therefore , the emphasis is not just on the aged .
Nonetheless , the aged will also benefit monetarily when the economy prospers and tax payment has increased .
Most countries have embraced the wonders of technology .
Like the rest of the countries , Singapore has infused huge financial resources on investment for technological upgrades and infrastructural developments .
The installation of an islandwide wireless broadband service is one of the recent technological upgrades .
With this service provision , it enables everyone to stay connected .
Apart from the improvement in telecommunication , our transport network has recently been extended , with an addition of Circle Line route , which doubles the MRT stations by 2020 .
With greater accessibility on public transport system , it improves efficiency and reduces travelling time for most people .
Although these projects have huge cost borne by the government , the benefits still outweigh the cost .
Society benefits as these developments can be accessed by the public .
In addition , both of these long term provisions will reap in profits .
In comparison to public funds on aged , government only serves the social responsibility of looking after the aged .
In conclusion , aged people cannot rely on government to take full responsibility for their needs since there are other priorities in country's developments which will create job opportunities , greater economic revenues , convenience and efficiency .Though Government has a social responsibility to look after the aged , families should take up the bulk of responsibility for caring and providing essential needs .
With more competing interests for financial resources , public finance on aged is least of a concern .
it will definitely put a strain on the economic budget and reaps no economic returns if public spending on aged has no limits .
In many countries , there is a common similarity , a baby-boomer period .
Now , another similarity that most nations are facing is the ageing population .
Countries are aware that this issue is pervasive and it will have profound implications to the facets of the society if they are not responding fast to it .
However , the question is , how much of a focus should a country place in it when there are other important areas to look at as well ?
With the stiff competition amongst nations , public spending on the aged should be spend only if necessary , but more focus should be place in other aspects like for example , education , tourism and security which are the key factors to a country's economy and thus the survival of it .
Funds placed in these aspects can help ease the ageing process in the long run , critically looking at minimizing the dependency of the aged on the governments .
I believe that measures to ease ageing issues can be done at low cost and effective at the same time .
There are several viable methods .
Strong emphasis of family support and educating the aged about taking responsibility of themselves for example like filial obligation , insurance , healthy lifestyle , financial planning and ensuring they have enough retirement fund .
There are more private sectors dealing in health and nutrition , financial consultants to help in the management of assets .
More support could be given to all these sectors from the government .
It is more of a one time method , when inculcated to become a habit and trend .
To those who are not educated , information may not reach out to them funds still has to be allocated to help them .
These are necessary spending that is unavoidable .
The aged should not be forgotten but spending on them needs to be limited , spend only if needed .
However , this will require the whole community's effort to make sure that cultivation of moral values virtues are deeply rooted in them .
This is to ensure that the future batch of elderly are well-prepared for their own ageing process and not just wait for the government to take care of them .
Public spending on aged can then be reduce much more and more must be placed in other developments that can bring prosperity to the nation and minimize social issues .
With much credit to swift medical advancements , average life span of a human being in America has shot up by 5 years in just a decade to 82 years today .
Such increase in longevity and the reduce in birth rates , will no doubt lead to an inevitable rise to the problems of aging , as there are fewer and fewer young people to support the rising number of elderly , whether financially or socially .
Aging is a big issue , governments from all over the world are pushing forward policies and Research and Developments to stem its economical and social impacts to a country .
The number one killer of elderly is heart failure .
For instance , in Australia , 5% of all the people aged 65 and above suffers from heart failure .
Although some elderly who suffers gentle heart failure could still maintain a relatively normal life , those who suffer to a severe extent have their day-to-day activities affected .
They no longer have the ability to pursue a normal and perhaps happy life .
However with R&D in the area of heart-related diseases , led to the developments of new drugs and treatments to control and reduce the effects of heart failures to their everyday life .
Hence our current R&Ds have no doubt helped elderly by increasing their quality of life .
All in all , aging is part of the natural life cycle of an organism .
Everyone has a role to play to solve the persisting aging problem in many developed societies .
Policies to upgrade housing in Singapore have improved the living conditions of the elderly , together with the setting up of the senior citizens' corners , I am convinced that the elderly can now participate more actively in the society and live off with a higher social well being .
As for the improvements in current R&D , we can all anticipate more ground-breaking inventions to relief elderly of pains from illness .
Also , having the elderly joining into the workforce can increase the total productivity and reduce the burden piled on family members .
Nonetheless , I am convicted to feel that current research and developments/ policies do play an important role to help ease the arduous aging process .
In this ever competitive world , the idea of the weak being more susceptible to elimination and the strong emerging victorious is not unfounded .
Indeed , this concept is applicable to a real life context in our society - the old versus the young workers .
The society now has this notion that the old would eventually become obsolete , exhausted and unproductive .
However , the aged has come a long way before they hit the supposed end of their economic lifespan .
Without their contributions , the modern society might not even exist .
The State has a certain responsibility to provide for the old .
To simply cut back funds on the grounds that the elderly could no longer yield any economic profits is an irresponsible act .
The old is worthy of every resources spent on them as they are still important assets to the nation .

In fact , the resources allocated do not have to be solely for the old as other sectors could also seek betterment from it .

The society must avoid the pitfalls of classifying and relating old age to low productivity .
Ageing does not equate to redundancy .

Instead of seeing them as a sector that would yield no returns , the old should be considered as an investment where providing them opportunities to share their experiences would enable the young to gain precious knowledge and learn from past mistakes .
This would pave the way for a more meaningful future for the subsequent ageing generation .
For countries with small population such as that of Singapore , there exists the need to recruit foreign talents to fuel their economy .
Reduced tax rates , solid infrastructure and business-tailored policies are some of strategies utilized by the local government .
However , this would not sustain the interest in foreigners if the country lacks an appealing living condition .
One way to retain these foreigners is to improve on the welfare system for the aged .
This is not a totally farfetched approach based on the previous case where Singapore established a comprehensive child care system that resulted in many expatriates moving their family over to work and dwell here .
We could similarly use an impeccable retirement scheme to entice them to settle down permanently .
By making Singapore a better place for old age , it could resolve the issue of a diminutive pool of human resources as well as boost the State's economy .
All in all , the elderly should not be viewed as incapable of providing any further services to the nation .
Rather than condemning their low productivity , we should incorporate the old into our community for they had garnered experiences which are of practical use to the young .
The State share a part in supporting the elderly for these are the people who had have a hand in nation building and morphing the society which we lived in now .
Spending on the old does not denote an economic dead end .
To the contrary , the old has the potential to open new doors and bring about more opportunities both within and into the country .
Taking care of the aged is now a global issue that no country can steer clear of .
Some people might think that we should take a pragmatic approach and ignore the needs of the elderly as they can no longer serve the society .
However , who can deny that our older generations have contributed immensely to our society ?

It is true that by doing so , a country's development and productivity will suffer .
Nevertheless , I believe that as long as the government is able to obtain a balance in the areas of public spending , the country's development can still progress without limiting public spending on the aged .
It is only right for us to take care of the aged as they contributed a great deal to what we have now .
Without the hard work of the older generation , we would not have the fundamental of our society .
We can only prosper with a strong foundation , which the elderly had given us .
As a result , when they become feeble and require assistance , we should lend them a helping hand .

The Maintenance of Parents Act is one good example of government intervention to make taking care of elderly mandatory when necessary .
Under CPF Hosing Grant , there is now an incentive to live near parents too .

On the whole , a country's public spending requires very delicate planning .
Since the aging population is one big issue now , necessary spending on the aged cannot be stingily kept away .
Not only is it due to moral obligation , ignoring the aging population would also result in other social problems that might be even more difficult to solve .
As the government wants to maintain a country's development , public spending on the aged should be limited but not to the minimal .
It should be at the maximum limit where the government can still withstand so as to help as many elderly as possible .
A nation's success does not solely depend on economic growth but the welfare aspect too .
Therefore with careful planning of expenditure , solving aging problem generously would benefit the country in long run .
The aging process is not a pleasant process for humans to go through .
However , the Singapore government had come up with some policies to help make the aging process a more comfortable one .
This is especially important , considering that Singapore had got one of the fastest aging populations in Asia , according to reports by the Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports  .
Some of the developments and policies are the construction of studio apartments specially for the elderly , the upgrading of the Housing Board lifts which helps to improve the elders living area , increasing the retirement age to allow the elders to be more self-dependent and implementing more healthcare benefits and subsidies for the elder Singaporean such as subsidies for community hospital stay .
All these developments and policies have contributed towards easing the aging process in Singapore .
One of the many important points to take note for an aging society is the fact that the elders' physical ability , such as walking and bathing , would tend to deteriorate over time .
Therefore attention needs to be paid , to ensure a safe environment for the elders to live in .
The Singapore government acknowledged this requirement by introducing the studio apartments and the HDB lift-upgrading projects .
In January 09 , HDB stated that they would be building more studio apartments for the elderly .
These studio apartments were equipped with elderly-friendly features such as non- slip toilet tiles , grab poles and they are small , easy to upkeep while being offered at an affordable price .
The upgrading of lifts in the older flats , so that the lifts stops at every floor of the HDB flats also helped to ensure barrier-free accessibility for the elders .
However , some problems cropped up for the lift-upgrading projects .
Mainly due to the fact that not every flat was suitable to undergo lift-upgrading project and money were needed from the elderly in order for the projects to take place .
To minimize these problems , subsidies were given out for the projects .
Overall , all these facilities would help to create a safer environment for the elders to live in .
During the aging process , it is easier for the elders to fall sick as we can see from the statistics shown by the Hospital Admission Rates by Age and Sex in 2007 .
The government have thus planned healthcare subsidies and benefits for the elderly .
This is important as not every elderly is able to pay for the heavy medical bills .
These healthcare subsidies would help to offload certain percentage of the community hospital's fees .
There is one problem with this policy that is there are quite a few criteria that need to be fulfilled before an elderly could enjoy the healthcare subsidies and benefits .
However , these criteria were meant to sieve out the elders who truly needed help as compared to those who were actually able to afford their own medical bills .
The Singapore government had inputted many measures to help ease the aging process .
The construction of the studio apartment , lift-upgrading project , extension of the retirement age and the implementation of healthcare subsidies and medical benefits have all gone a long way to help ease the aging process .
All these developments and policies have helped to ensure that Singapore will be prepared in both the short run and long run against the problems of an aging population .
However as the aging population in Singapore becomes bigger in size , more research and development/ policies will need to be carried out to slow down the rapid growth of the aging population instead of easing the aging process .
