"Public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development ."
In my opinion , I do not totally agree with the statement .
An all-rounded country's development is crucial and important but it should not be achieved at the expense of the health care for the elderly in the society .
First and foremost , the elderly remain financially vulnerable in the society and need the public funding for their health care .
Though Peterson in The Graying World maintains that the elderly could depend less on the public spending by seeking employment or depending more on their family , such a notion at reducing and limiting elder dependency is not feasible .
Being old does not come with the loss of health but there is a social prejudice against the elderly when they seek employment at their age .
In this competitive age , employers will tend to favour the non-elderly over the elderly as the latter is nearly retirement and often associated with old diseases .
In addition , people are having less , if not , no children these days .
In 2008 , Singapore's birth rate was 1 .28 , well below the 2 .1 mark which is needed to meet the future requirements of the Singapore's development .
Such a societal trend reduces the possibility of the elderly tapping on filial obligation for support in the future .
Therefore , such unfavourable factors continue to place the elderly in need of the public support for their health care .
Public support for the health of the aged is for a real cause , for the elderly who have difficulties in affording it .
Hence , the public spending on the healthcare of the aged should be practised flexibly and should not be viewed as a hindrance to the development and progress of a nation .
Public spending on the aged has been the topic of argument in parliaments across the world as it occupies a significant sum of a developed society's annual budget .
It is mainly a question of how much healthcare provision , grants and subsidies , regardless medical or other forms , should be given to help the poor aged to survive .
It interferes with the sum of money allocated to develop the country in other ways .
Should public spending on the aged make way for the country's development on all other areas ?
However , regardless how much the economy is growing , not every people are going to accumulate enough wealth for their old life .
There is a gap between the rich and the poor .
The rich is going to have a wealthy and comfortable life in their post-retirement but the poor is going to struggle with their daily lives- to pay the necessary service bills , medical bills and for food .
Poor elderly who have no children or whose children have deserted them are only going to live on their depleting savings .
If their savings runs out , they would face difficulty acquiring income as their abated bodies limit them in finding a job .
They would end up living on the streets if no help is given to them .
Furthermore , poor elderly cannot afford expensive medical bills , but they should not be disqualified to receive medical treatment as it is needed to sustain their lives .
Hence , help is heavily needed from the government to keep the poor aged to survive .
Grants and subsidies should be given for health check-ups and medical treatments .
Everyday provision of living facilities and food is also needed for those very poor as we should not leave them on the streets .
Hence spending on the aged should not be severely limited .
The aged have work very hard to develop our country in all ways and they deserve a well rest for the rest of their lives .
It's ethically not right to leave them on the streets or not to relieve them from the unaffordable medical fees just because they have turned incapable of contributing to the society , especially those who are not well educated to begin with .
It is also against human rights to leave a helpless person to be tortured by illnesses and die .
Selfishness and cruelly will develop when we decide to leave the aged on their own .
Selfishness undermines unity and cooperation which ultimately leads to failure of a society .
Cruelty leads to insensitivity towards death and violence , which links to crime rates .
Hence , if we focus too much on pushing too much forward our economy and progress and neglect taking care of our aged , we might just lose the ethic and moral values that keep us living in a community and we would eventually fall .
By limiting public spending on the aged , there is most likely to be poor elderly lying on the streets and more old people struggling with medical fees .
It is ethically not right and impractical to lift off public spending on the aged to spend on other areas of development .
"Public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development ."
As each year passes , there seems to be an increase on public spending towards the aged .
This seems to be a very popular trend , as a lot of developed countries , such as Spain and the United States of America , tend to increase the public spending on the elderly .
Public spending is very essential to a country's development , and should be divided sensibly .
The spending on the aged should be limited so that the money can be diverted to other sectors of the country's development like public transportation or the army .

Public transportation is one area that could be improved if the country limits its spending on the elderly and raises its spending to the former .
The major problem with public transportation in this country is that it is privately owned and the fares are ridiculously high .
"The privatization of public transport has not delivered the improved service standards nor shorter arrival times , while fares have been increasing based on the justification that being private transport operator , they are not charity and need to make profit for their shareholders ."
According to a Singapore census made in 2000 , around 52% of Singaporeans go to work using public transportation .
That is staggering , over half the population uses public transportation , yet the conditions are still poor and fares are high , which seems very unreasonable .
The Government can play a major in creating a solution to this problem .
If they limit the amount being spent on the elderly , they can use their money to better effect through buying back the public transportation , and give reasonable fares to the public who deserve it .
Another thing they can do is improve the conditions of the busses .
Pollution is a growing concern to the environment , "small land area of the central business district led to severe traffic conditions including congestion , reduced traffic speeds , and environmental problems ."
Some of the busses used outside the city are fairly old , and unless they are disposed and substituted by less polluting busses , then the environment is in danger .
These are some reasons why limiting public spending on the aged could contribute to the development of the country .
Another way the government could use the public spending more effectively is to spend more on the Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports , which is also known as the MCYS .
By limiting the money being spent on the aged , the government could help a very important sector in the MCYS .
The Ministry's main mission is "to build a cohesive and resilient society .
MCYS seeks to fulfill its mission by fostering socially responsible individuals , strong and stable families , a caring and active community , inspired and committed youth , and a sporting people ."
The main thing here is that they support families .
The most important aim here is to build strong and stable families .
That way the elders have their families to look after them , which could render the public spending on the aged useless .
And if for some reason the younger ones in the family don't help their elders , then they can be sued under the "Maintenance of Parents Act , which allows parents to sue their children for financial support ."
This policy clearly shows why the Government should limit its spending on the elderly , and spread it around to other more useful sectors .
To conclude , it would be very wise of the government to limit its spending on the aging , and to divert the money to other areas of the country's development .
There are a lot of sectors more deserving of the money , and could be beneficiary to both the young and old , like improving the public transportation in the country .

In the recent years , global aging issues are an uprising concern .
The population in many developed countries is aging , and Singapore is no exception .
If fertility rate does not increase , these issues will worsen , as the average age of the population will increase .
If this maintains , by 2030 , the ratio of one out of every five Singaporeans will be aged 65 or above .
The aging population will definitely cause a great impact on the society .
Thus over the years , the new researches , developments and policies in Singapore have definitely helped to ease the aging process to a large extent .
And as far as these developments and policies are concern , ageing workforce and the cost for elderly healthcare are the important factors that the government has looked into .
By looking into these factors , the country can greatly decrease the impact of the liabilities these elderly has on the country .
To prevent older generations to be a burden to younger generations , the Singapore government has come up with several policies and acts which allows the elderly to stay in the workforce for a longer period .
One of the acts enforced is the Retirement Act .
Under this act , the minimum retirement age in Singapore is 62 years , thus allowing them to stay longer in the workforce .
This can be beneficial to them in several ways .
Firstly , they can accumulate more wealth through their work , which they can then use to support themselves in their old age .
Secondly , working provides them a good environment to maintain and even build up their physical and mental health .
This is possible through communication with their colleagues , which can help them to stay optimistic .
Thirdly , by working longer , they also help to ease the financial stress of their family members .
Another worry arising is the cost for health matters .
An ageing population with higher life expectancy is also associated with higher numbers of chronic and other medical conditions .
To help families in Singapore cope with the extensive treatment cost , the Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports  , has come up with services and programmes that provides affordable healthcare and eldercare services .
MCYS have both intermediate and long-term healthcare facilities .
Intermediate healthcare facilities include community hospitals , day rehabilitation centres for the elderly , and long-term healthcare facilities include hospices , home medical , nursing or therapy services and nursing homes .
These facilities mostly cater for families who have financial difficulties .
On the contrary , some Singaporeans have the mind set that these services and programmes are not of utmost importance to them as they each have their own medisave account to pay for their hospitalization bills .
Apart from this , some other Singaporeans might not think that later retirement is a good idea .
For example , companies might think that it is a more of a burden to hire an elderly worker , as they might not be able to cope with the stress and workload five .
There are also worries about the elderly workers' health status .
Therefore , they would rather hire a worker with higher qualifications , who is more competent , and most importantly , younger .
However , little did they know that medisave account might be exhausted after a week .
Associate Professor Paulin Straughan said "One hospitalization , for example , a stroke can set you back at tens of thousands of dollars .
Where are you going to get that money ?"
Therefore , without the help and support from welfare organizations such as MCYS , majority of Singaporeans might not be able to handle high cost incurred for taking care of the elderly .
Also , when companies hire a worker , have they ever taken into consideration that experience does play a part in the working society ?
Without the past contributions from these elderly workers , these companies might not be able to stand wherever they are today .
Therefore , it is important that companies try to retain elderly workers , especially when the Singapore government do provide incentives for them when they do so .
Infrastructure is one of the areas that the government can develop on .
More railway lines can be built to allow easy accessibility of people from one location to another .
Expanding the railway line will allow the reducing of time spent on traveling and to be more convenient .
It focuses on the general public as a whole , ranging from the young to the elderly and handicapped rather than mainly on the aged .
However , as constructing is in progress , it often causes high pollution level and is unsightly .
But , the ultimate aim of investing expenditure on such a large scale project was to increase the standard of living of people .
Another instance could be the upgrading of roads to cater to the increasing amount of vehicles , to reduce road congestion .
It also facilitates the driving within Singapore by making it smoother and providing alternatives road which were lesser as compared to the past .
We may also have notice that our buildings are often undergoing maintenance and upgrading as it is part of the government scheme to maintain the condition of the building , minimizing the wear and tear after years and most importantly meant for the public to have a better environment to live in .
The above mentioned could be another area in which the government can divert their expenditure to .
Education is another area that the government should focus on as it aids in the development of the country .
The government can invest on having additional amenities in school such as gymnastics swimming pool and indoor sports hall as a form of relaxation , providing a conducive environment for the students .
Besides that , expenditure can be channeled in increasing the subsidies in education to encourage people to take up more studies , removing barrier due to insufficient cash flow .
As people are educated , they were able to contribute to the workforce in the near future .
In conclusion , although money spent on the elderly can ease the problem of aging population , it is only for a short term and is not a feasible solution .
It will only create a reliance on the government .
Therefore , we should take into consideration the effects that we will encounter in the long run .
By investing largely in the aged , other areas of developments for the country will be neglected which will result in more social problems .
Hence , spending on the aged should be restricted to a certain amount so that the resources in terms of financial can be divided equally based on the needs of the various sectors .
There should be a limitation for the public spending on the aged .
Over the years , the expenditure on the aged has relatively increased due to the shift to an aging population .
This is mainly due to the increasing needs of healthcare and welfare services for the elderlies .
Should more public spending be used for catering the implications of the ageing population ?
We need to consider other various sectors that the government is concerned , for the economic and social development of the country .
Providing better healthcare and welfare services has been regarded more important than before due to the ageing population we are facing today .
Policies have been changing according to the needs of the elderlies over time .
As people are having a higher life expectancy today , more spending is expected to provide better healthcare facilities and other services for the aged .
It is observed that in certain countries that faced with aging population problem , there is an significant increase in hospitalization rates as well as physician services over the years .
However , the increased health costs should not be depended solely by the government .
People are more educated and can work longer to better support themselves today .
Furthermore , to stimulate economic growth , the government needs to work out carefully on the national budget for different sectors in the country .
Therefore , we need to consider other government expenditure such as Education , Infrastructure and Research and Development  .
Developing infrastructure is also another important expenditure that the government is focusing on .
The Government will increase public sector construction spending to between $18 billion and $20 billion in 2009 .
This is significantly higher than the $15 billion contracted in 2008 and $6 billion in 2007 .  .
As economy is thriving continuously , infrastructure such as commercial buildings , bridges , roads and rails are developed constantly .
Infrastructure can reflect on how developed a country is and also to make sure people and goods can move about quickly .
For instance , the transportation network in Singapore are always developing to provide citizens with top graded transportation as far as possible .
A recent development will be the introduction of circle line to the existing MRT networks .
Iconic infrastructure developments would be the building of Integrated Resort and casino that are aimed to attract foreign investment and tourist attraction .
Remaking of housing estates are established through various estate renewal programmes such as Home Improvement Programme and Lift Upgrading Programme  .
Expanding infrastructure spending reflects a country's economic status and helps bring in more foreign investment .
The focus on Research and Development has become more prominent today .
Many countries set aside huge amount of government funds for R&D activities .
For example , the south Korean government plans to increase investment in research and development by more than 10 percent on year in 2010 .
People see science and technology as a longtime investment and thus expenditure on R&D was not affected even in the current economic crisis .
Singapore is becoming a biomedical hub that is globally competitive and is turning into a trusted centre for scientific and related commercial activities .
Investment in R&D boosts economic growth , increases productivity and generates new product to improve quality of people's live today .
The needs of a country will be constantly changing with regards to the fluctuation of the economy .
Even though public spending on the aged has been increasing due to the shift to an ageing population , there should be a limitation on this spending so as to divert the assets for developing other areas .
The educated aged group today should also be able to support and plan for themselves with regards to their healthcare and social services .
In all , the proportion of public spending on the various sectors should be divided properly in order to promote economic growth and maintain a sustainable development .
As fertility rates remain stagnant , many countries are experiencing aging populations .
Governments have thought of many measures so as to help improve the aging population situation .
They have invested time and money into research on policies that can help solve the aging population crisis .
Moreover , since such a trend is only likely to happen in the short run , much has been done to buffer its negative impact on society .
Therefore , I agree to a large extent , current research development/policies have helped to ease the aging process .
Demographic changes such as a growing population will have a serious consequence on health issues in developed countries .
National budgets and economies will come under pressure as growing numbers of elderly persons are supported by relatively fewer younger persons .
To deal with such challenges , governments have only two options , one of which is to reduce the future old-age dependency burden by increasing available resources .
This means coming up with policies that can increase the size and productivity of the current and next generation's working-age population .
Alternatively , governments can reduce the amount of money spent on welfare benefits for the elderly .
Firstly , elderly dependency should be reduced by encouraging the elderly to retire later , and by lowering barriers to elder employment .
This can be achieved by increasing the eligibility age for public pensions and government incentives .
As people work longer , the amount of wealth generated would be greater .
If they retired at a younger age , the amount of people left in the work industry would be lesser , resulting in a higher dependency ratio .
By lowering the barriers and making it easier for the elderly to be employed , more elderly people would have jobs and be able to generate income for the country .
For example , the retirement age in Singapore and Britain used to be 60 and 65 respectively .
However , as of today , the retirement age of Singaporeans has been increased to 62 , and that of Britain is expected to be increased to 68 by 2050 .
This would lead to smaller dependency ratios for both countries , thus lightening the burden on the working class .
The size of today's economy and tax base can also be increased by encouraging greater productivity among the non-elderly .
This can be achieved by sourcing foreign talents from other counties to immigrate to Singapore to contribute to our labour force .
The revenue of the country would in turn increase and the government can use it for other investment and research purposes .
Therefore , the government has been granting PRs and citizenships more freely than before , as well as providing incentives such as tax rebates to attract foreign companies to invest in Singapore's economy .
The Foreign Talent Policy would thus result in a larger workforce and ultimately lead to increased revenue for the country .
Secondly , the healthcare of the society is very important .
As the society is facing an aging population problem , the retirement age would increase .
Older people tend to have more health problems and need more medical attention .
They tend to see the doctor more often .
By providing medical benefits and asking them to go for checkups every year , the number of elderly with severe health problems can be reduced .
The government should also spend more money on finding cures for common illnesses that old people are inflicted with .
These measures would ensure that medical problems are treated early and more effectively , thus contributing to a healthier workforce and ultimately , a more productive labour force .
For example , in Singapore , citizens are encouraged to go for medical checkups every year and various medical benefits are provided so as to ensure that our workforce stays healthy and efficient .
However , some may argue that 'Health' is very subjective as everyone's body condition is very different .
It is very hard to predict when your body system will malfunction .
The check up could only allow you to have early detection of your illness .
It does not guarantee the recovery from the illness .
Therefore they argue that more and more money would be spent on researching on new technologies to cure the illness .
However , research has shown that for many diseases like diabetes , kidney failure , heart diseases and so forth , the chances of recovery are much higher if the disease was diagnosed in the early stages .
Therefore , the opponent's argument does not stand .
In conclusion , I feel that no matter how much research is being done , it will not completely solve the aging population crisis .
It only helps to alleviate the problems caused by an ageing population .
The only way to really solve this problem is to increase the birth rate of the country .
Only by providing more children will the cost burden be spread over a larger and more affluent future generation .
Therefore , I conclude that although current research and development/policies have helped to ease the aging process to a large extent , but they have not managed to fully solve the problem .
With the decline of fertility rate in recent years , statistics have shown that in Singapore , the number of younger persons age 15-64 to every resident aged 65 and above fell from 10 .4 in 1998 to 7 .5 in 2009 .
This would suggest an imbalance in the population ratio of number of young person to the number of older people .
As a result , Singapore will be facing the dangers of an aging population .
Hence , the public spending on the aged will increase .
At the same time , with the rising economy , the national expenditure would eventually increase .
However , solely focusing on the aged population would not be the best approach .
The government should also focus on other areas that contribute to the development of the country , such as education , technology , military and research and development  .
This is because there is still a need to contribute to the country's economic growth in order to be able to sustain the well-being of its people .
The government can limit its expenditure on the medical fees for the older population and use the money to invest in the education of the younger population and develop the country .
Community centres can organise more activities to encourage the older generation to exercise and stay healthy .
In psychological term , this would not only be able to decrease the percentage of them being sick but also lead them to a healthier and happier life .
However , too much help from government can lead to its people being too dependent on the government .
This would result in arising problems including the lack of motivation to work .
Henceforth , the government can introduce policies to encourage its people to invest for their future during the early stages of their life .
This is to ensure that when they do not have the ability to work anymore , they will still be able to support themselves without much help from the government .
In conclusion , public spending on the aged should have a limitation .
This will allow the people to learn to be more independent in supporting themselves when they retire .
This would not only benefit the nation's development but also improve its people well-being .
Furthermore , better education for the younger generation would lead to the spread of cost burden of the nation .
Even though there is a need to support the aged , the efficiency of the country should not be compromised .
Due to the advancement in technologies and the implementation of efficacy policies by the Singapore government , these have helped to alleviate the problems that are accompanied by the aging process to a large extent .
Take for instance , in the past , due the lack of current research and developments available , most elderly who are diagnosed with illness were unlikely to recover and in most cases , they would have to stay in bad for the rest of their lives .
Furthermore , in the past , elderly especially spinsters and bachelors whom they have no family members to turn to in their old age often faced financial problems after they stopped working .
However , unlike the past , most elderly now are coping well with the aging process in terms of physically , economically and mentally .
As indicated in the statistics pertaining to the health status of the senior citizens  , it stated that "among senior citizens aged 55 and above , only 35 .8% reported a clean bill of health ."
As such , it would seem that despite the great advancement in the area of medical technologies , a substantial percentage of the elderly are still suffering from medical ailments such as high blood pressure , bone or joint problems , diabetes and sight problems .
This may suggest that the current medical technologies have not help to ease the aging process .

Although , in today's context , around 66% of the senior citizens aged 55 and above are provided with regular cash contributions from their children , there is still a significant number of senior citizens that faced financial difficulties in their old age , especially if these senior citizens are retired singles .
Hence , in order to aid the elderly through the aging process , the Singapore government has implemented several policies and measures to ensure that there is adequate protection for the elderly .
One good illustration would be the new CPF LIFE scheme that will be launched in September 2009 .
Under this new scheme , it will offer members with a life-time income whereby the members will receive a sum of money monthly for as long as they live and the amount will depend on the cash savings they have in their Retirement Account .
Furthermore , besides ensuring that the elderly will have sufficient funds for their living expenses after their retirement , the Singapore government has also ensured that the elderly will be able to cope with the hefty and long term medical expenses in their old age through the implementation of policies such as the Eldershield  .
As stated from the source , "ElderShield is an affordable severe disability insurance scheme which provides basic financial protection to those who needs long-term care , especially during old age ."
Thus , the elderly will be able to draw on the monthly payout to aid in paying for his or her long-term care expenses .
Hence , with the implementation of such policies , majority of the financial difficulties that the senior citizens faced in their old age would be alleviated .
The elderly would be able to rely on the monthly payouts from the various schemes to cope with their everyday lives even if they had stopped working .
Lastly , the grieving process is part and parcel of the aging process whereby for the elderly , it is more common for them to lose their family members and friends in their old age and thus , this makes each single loss even more unbearable .
However , with the current developments and advanced medical help available , it would be able to aid in reducing the sufferings that the elderly would be experiencing during the grieving process .
The healing process will only start if the elderly are willing to seek and accept support from various sources .
For instance , one such facility development which the elderly would be able to seek help from would be the REACH Elderly Care Centre where the elderly would be able to receive day care , supervision and supportive help .
In addition , the place also serves to offer ample opportunities for the senior citizens to mingle with other people and take on meaningful activities so that they would be healthier in terms of both mentally and physically .
Furthermore , with the advancement in medical sciences , if the intensity of the grief does not fade off after a long period of time , the elderly can also seek professional help such as consulting the therapists and psychologists to assist them in getting over the grieving process .
As such , with the different types of facilities and medical developments available , the elderly no longer has to suffer in silence .
This further substantiates the fact that current research and development have indeed helped to ease the aging process .

Singapore population comprises of the citizens and permanent residents .
In between the year 1947 and 1964 , there are approximately 1 million babies were born .
This made up of 30% of the resident population in the constitution .
The batch of these baby-boomers will reach 65 years old by 2012 and form the largest aged population that Singapore has ever experienced .
Therefore , the government of Singapore should not limit public spending on the aged .
Singapore is a developed country where the government had already spent millions toward the country's development .
Having established that public spending on the aged should not be limited , other aspects of government spending , however , should not be neglected just to maximize spending on the aged .
Money could be diverted to tourism and military , for instance , as these may be other crucial areas of a country's development that requires public spending .
Money could be diverted to the tourism industry where it plays a key role in contributing to the country's income .
According to Singapore Tourism Board , Singapore achieved a record of 9 .7 million visitors in 2006 , from 8 .9 million in 2005 , and is hoping to achieve a target of 17 million visitors by 2015 .
In order to achieve the target , Singapore has recently invested a substantial amount of money into the major development of the two integrated resorts in order to remain competitive among Asian countries and other popular tourist attractions .
The Integrated Resort is one of the many strategies that Singapore adopt to generate more economic growth and boost the country's Gross Domestic Product  .
Other than the many areas money could be diverted to , military defense is among one of the important aspects because it serves as a deterrence to protect a country's sovereignty .
Money spent on purchasing weapons and armours is necessary to ensure that the warriors of the nation are well-equipped in an event when war occurs .
In addition , money could also be expended on local or overseas training to ensure that the warriors are trained with relevant knowledge to defend the country .
There are many areas where public spending should be used for a country's development .
In developed countries like Singapore and Japan where ageing population is an issue , the importance of public spending on the aged can outweigh that of other aspects .
On the other hand , developing countries may invest most of their public spending on infrastructure instead of on the aged because economic development is likely to be their primary objective .
It would be unwise to limit healthcare spending on the aged since different countries have different needs .
In conclusion , public spending on the aged should not be limited due to its significance in view of the ageing population .
Instead , the government should allow its public spending on the aged to hang around a certain percentage .
However , such approaches will only solve the skin of the problem and not the root cause of the situation .
Not only that , it will generate the idea that it is okay to not look after the elderly as the welfare will step in and provide the elderly a place .
This replacement of looking after the elderly will only encourage more infilial children to neglect their elderly parents .
Hence , providing sustainable solutions to the aging problem have to start by tackling the root cause of the problem , that is looking at the children who is supposed to take care of them .
The root cause starts from children who have no wish to take care of their parents .
This can be due to many reasons .
One of which is the lack of financial income .
Japan was known to have many homeless elderly and by analyzing into the country' performance it is known that Japan has the highest expenses among the countries .
Beside cultural aspect , this gave us a slide indication that the people there may have problem handling their finance .
In Singapore , this is especially true to people falling under the sandwich generation who have to pay for the spending of their children and also their parents .
Instead of using taxpayer money on the aged , it can be used to generate more jobs and higher income for the people , resulting in better economic .
In this way , the children will have more financial allowance to take care of the parents .
Educating the society on aging issue helps in long-term basis .
Just like other issue like smoking and yellow ribbon , introducing of aging campaign should be improvised in a country .
This approach not only brings awareness to the country , but also educating on the people on what will happen to the elderly when they are neglected .
The experiencing and understanding of such situation changes the way the society thinks about aging elderly , taking this aging issue on another level of humanity instead of practicality .
Law should also being implemented in a country to help control the negligence of the elderly .
Fine should be made on family that neglects their parents .
The Law should not be made severe , as there are also many issues to why one has to neglect their elders .
Issue like financial problem and time allowance may prevent one to take care of their elder .
The Law should take on another part of being just fining on them , but bringing in welfare that helps family that encounter such problem .
In this way , there is a controlling factor in a country , making sure the welfare of elderly will be taken care of by their family and lessening the amount of homeless elderly .
In a nutshell , public spending should be limited and wisely spent in providing aids to the elderly .
Instead of helping directly to the needs of elderly , the government should tackle the root of the problem , which is the people who are supposed to take care of their elderly parent .
This can be done by improving on the economic issue of their country , educating the importance of taking care of the elderly and implementing laws on negligence issue of elderly .
These approaches may not produce effect soon , but it is sustainable for the future generation .
I strongly agree with the sixth strategy which suggests people to provide in advance for their own old-age dependency .
In my opinion , this is the most useful method to reduce the fiscal and economic cost .
That is also why so many countries are engaging in setting up effective systems to encourage or compel people to save money for later use .
For instance , China has developed a complete system which requires people to turn over some money every year according to the individual income and willingness .
Then when they are old they can receive corresponding care and living expenses .
This policy is implemented smoothly , since both the government and citizens can benefit from it .
It not only lightens the burden of government but also brings security to citizens' later use .
To certain extent , it also can inspire individual enthusiasm for work .
However , some people insist that the government should take the responsibility to look after the old people by increasing the pension and promoting the funding of the programs for the elderly , for they have engaged themselves in the development of their countries and deserve the care and respect .
In my perspective , it may not be practical especially for the developing countries with large population .
It not only cannot solve the problem effectively but also may lead the national budgets and economic to come under great pressure .
All in all encouraging people to set aside some money for themselves is the most wisdom method .
Throughout the years , the issue of aging has become a tremendous challenge for the developed countries .
Due to the increase in the standard of living , better medical treatment is available and this has caused the life expectancy of the people to increase .
People are marrying later in life and this has caused a fall in the fertility rate .
Young people are now faced with the insurmountable task of supporting an ever increasing population of the aged .
As a result , public spending on the aged has been on the increase .
Some may think that it is a waste of the taxpayers' money to fund such a spending as there can be no potential benefits to be reaped .
However is this the correct attitude to hold towards the elderly ?
Should we hold back the aid for the aged who had contributed to the country's success ?
That shouldn't be the case .
This essay will argue that public spending on the aged should not be limited to a large extent .
It will touch on the moral issues inherent and also argue that it is actually detrimental to a country's future if its aged are not well taken care of , even if the money saved by limiting public spending on the elderly is spent developing other areas such as education and research and development .
At first glance , spending on education may seem to be more important than aiding the elderly as what we teach the youths will determine the future of the nation .
An education provides a platform for the youths to face the challenges in the future .
When faced with difficult decisions , the analytical skills learnt in school will help us to determine how to deal with these problems .
Hence , for small country such as Singapore which human resources is the key factor for the success , it is important that the citizen constantly upgrade themselves with the latest knowledge .
Therefore , government should devote more capital to ensure that the education system remain relevant in today's dynamic global economy .
This certainly seems to be more important than pouring money down than on public spending on the elderly .
Some may say that it is more important that a country have an excellent research and development sector than healthy , happy senior citizens .
Research and development plays an important role in the innovation process which results in high quality products , successful businesses .
Research and development will very likely increase the levels of overseas investment as foreign multinational companies will see that country as a good place for business .
Therefore , with a strong research and development sector , a country will be more likely to succeed economically .
Again , public spending on research and development seems definitely to be more important than spending public money on the elderly .
After all , what can a group of healthy , well taken care of senior citizens bring to the country ?
Their knowledge has long become obsolete and there's not much value they can bring to a country anymore .
However , is it really true that the elderly is irrelevant to a country's development ?
This is not the case .
When the government provides sufficient money to look after the elderly , what is developed is the intangible moral value of gratitude and piety .
When a nation looks after their elderly without reservations , the lesson conveyed to its populace is that one should always look after the people who have contributed to our development .
As a result , what we learn then is to be grateful to the people who have aided us .
Such values are the essential element of the society .
It helps create strong lasting bonds between citizens and the result will be a more cohesive nation .
What about education and research and development ?
A strong education system and a strong research and development sector , when situated in a country that is not unified and chaotic will not be able to reap the benefits that they are supposed to generate .
Thus , public spending on the elderly does provide important benefits to the country and should not be limited thus .
In conclusion , we should not see elderly as a burden but an asset .
Even thought other sectors such as education and research and development are important to us , we should not forget ours greatly contributors .
There are the ones who build up a nation from the basic to what we have now .
Therefore , we must be grateful to those who aided us and create a sense of belonging to everyone .
In this way , younger generation will then work harder for the nations in the future .
The baby boom in the 1960s and the current low fertility rate in Singapore has entrench Singapore into one of the fastest aging population in the world .
Living expenditure for the elderly is increased by the rising medical costs and standard of living .
Therefore , it is necessary for the government to review the public policies for the elderly .
Essentially , the expenditure used to finance medical and welfare programs should be proportionate to the larger aging population .
The people are the asset of Singapore and they have contributed to the country's strong economic position .
As the population aged , it is the responsibility of the government to take care of its people .
Spending on the aged should not be limited .
The improvement in medical research has lengthened the life expectancy of the society .
However , the longer life span will inexplicitly incur a larger amount of long term health care expenses for the aged and the deterioration of physical mobility and communication might cause them to lose the ability to work and be self-sustained .
The situation is further worsened for a segment of the elderly in the society who is unmarried and inadequately educated .
They stand at the least advantageous position should there be a limitation in the public spending on the aged because they do not have families to depend on and the depletion in the marginal sum of savings will eventually result in social problems like starvation and homelessness .
Moreover , without the government's support for the elderly , the burden of caring for these elderly will fall solely on the "sandwich generation" , whereby the individuals are to be financially responsible for their family , children and parents .
This is especially straining for individuals who are less financially well off .
In the long run , this financial responsibility may be too much for the working population to bear .
Hence , there is a need for the government to intervene by using part of the public funds to care for this aged population and ease the burden on the working population .
Singapore invested much of our public spending on the other areas of the country's development like defence and economy .
Although these areas of development are necessary for the continual development of Singapore , we should not neglect the importance of public spending for the aged .
By providing more for the elderly and improvising health care polices , the government can actually improve the living conditions of the aged which will reduce possible social issues .
Furthermore , if the government can maintain social stability in its country , government may then focus on other aspects such as defence .
Ultimately , it is the responsibility of the working population and the government to take care of the elderly .
Other than taxation from the working population which is compulsory , it is necessary to garner support from the government to provide social welfare services , day-care centres , social support and improvisation of health systems .
Such coordination between the working population and government will benefit the aged who is concern with the provision of welfare from the state and this will give them a sense of security .
An ageing population is a worldwide pattern that is faced by all countries .
As the population is getting older this has social , political and economical impact on all societies .
Social impact would be that people would have to work harder because the proportion of people who are economically productive is not balance thus the younger generations has to be more productive to cater to the elderly low productivity .
An aging population will have a serious consequence on health issues in developed nations in the view that more medical support will be needed by the elderly .
National budgets and economies will come under pressure as growing numbers of elderly persons are supported by relatively fewer younger persons .
Political wise , policy to help the elderly whereas financially or welfare wise , it will hinder the countries growth in the long run which leads to the economical impact as more tax payers money will be used on public spending on the aged .
However , public spending should be diverted to other areas of the countries development like economy and technology which may help in prolonging and enhancing the quality of life for the elderly .
Investing in technology in the sense of research and development will allow the discovery of new medical advancement as well as better facilities for medical cares .
New drugs or medicine will be available for the sick elderly and more cures for diseases and sickness will be available to help the elderly thus reducing the stress on the working force in the sense that they don't have to worried about their elderly parents .
New technology or medicine to prolonging and enhancing the quality of life will be available for the elderly and this will reduce the stress on the working force of the economy and in return increase in the productivity of the working force as they are more focus at work and they are able to provide and spend more time at work .
This means that there will be a better output of production thus more business and more income for a better economy .
This will allow for better economical growth for the country which in return gives more funding for the government to spend on the elderly as well .
Public spending has constantly been an issue in any nation .
Politicians and law-makers are often debating on how much money should be spent in each sector of the country .
With the rising number of elderly in an aging nation , the amount of money spent in this sector would increase as well .
However , there are other areas that require cash inflow to facilitate and push society forward .
Such areas include the military sector , security sector , education sector , research and development sector etc .
Thus , the government should not spend too much on the elderly and neglect the rest of society .
When one grows old , his body will be going through adjustments and soon , he will not be as fast or agile as he was before .
The government steps in and upgrades the environment more user-friendly which includes , more handrails along steps and stairs , longer gentle slopes around the housing estates , upgrading of lifts to every floor in older flats , having more elder friendly lifts , etc .
Elderly become more vulnerable to illnesses and diseases as they age and it would take a much longer time to recover , unlike their younger days .
Together with rising medical costs and inflation , this would pose as a problem for the aged , even if one had prepared an amount of savings for his golden years .
The government would get involved once again and provide subsidies for the elderly in medical bills and as such .

Terrorism is a growing threat today as it is getting more complicated to understand the terrorists and counter or prevent them .
Constant vigilance against them will take a toll on the civil service sector such as the police and civil defense .
More research and studies would have to be done to learn about them , their thinking and their actions and how one should be prepared against them .
As the terrorism spreads and complicates their attacks , from bombing the Twin Towers in United States of America to the Mumbai attacks  , one could see that terrorism is growing and it is becoming much tougher to counter them in the future .
Other than relying on the police and military forces , the government has to educate the public on the dangers of terrorism and the importance in preventive them .
Research has shown that it is more cost effective to prevent than to deal with the aftermath of terrorism .
Thus the need to divert reserves into this area of the society is very important .
Clearly , spending for the aged is important .
However , the government should not focus too much on this particular sector and neglect the rest .
Education will have a positive impact on the economy .
Educating the youth , who are our future pillars of support , would equip them with skills so that they can handle potential problems , which in turn could support the elderly population in the future .
Education the older generation would also maintain and even push the economy into better times as they remain competitive and up-to-date with the relevant skills and also support themselves for a much longer period of time .
Security and safety of the people are as important as well .
As shown , preventive measures against terrorism is a cost effective way to counter them instead of dealing with the aftermath .
As a saying goes , it's better to be safe than sorry .

Singapore was ranked third for the highest life expectancy in the world , such that an aging population is evident .
Before taking effective actions , leaders must first realise that any further expansion of retirement benefits would only impoverish future generations and limit future public spending ) .
As such , I agree that public spending on the aged should be limited so that funds can be diverted to other areas like Ministry of Finance , Education , Health and National Development .
Each area must not be neglected , as they have significant contribution to aid in taking care of the aging population .
Firstly , for Ministry of Finance in Singapore , funds must be pumped into the economy to ensure solvency of the country .
For instance , Monetary Authority of Singapore and Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore are established to make sure that entities operating within Singapore's authority are attuned to the international standards and practices .
All these statutory boards and institutions require funds to run their operations to ensure Singapore's competitiveness , such that revenue earned can be allocated to other ministries' operation and policies usage .
Secondly , for Ministry of Education in Singapore , funds must be invested in educational institutions and policies .
For example , funds are needed to build good infrastructure and facilities for scholastic purposes such that their education is received under good environment .
After all , the younger generations are the futures of Singapore who will soon be the ones taking care of the aged .
Funds are also needed to draw effective educational programs to ensure that the young are equipped with fine skills to cope with the metropolitan society in Singapore after leaving the institutions .
In this society , funds are also needed to draw programs to educate the young on the moral values where moral values are the corner stone of an individual's character and personality .
Lastly , for Ministry of National Development in Singapore , funds are needed to develop housing policies to take care of the population and build national parks , neighbourhood parks and greeneries .
For the former , housing grants , subsidies , CPF schemes are used to ensure affordability of having a decent roof for the public .
Funds are also needed to build handicap facilities , for instance ramps and Lift Upgrading Program  .
For the latter it is especially important for the public as they can have a place for leisure .
It could be a place for all the residents in the neighbourhood to come together to interact , exercise and forge friendship .
This would help prevent them from experiencing loneliness and also a channel for the residents to communicate and help each other in times of need .
Therefore , after considering all the factors , I agree that public spending on the aged should be limited as other factors are equally important in taking care of the public , ensuring international competiveness and progress for the nation .
Each factor has its own way of contributing to the society as a whole and the elderly will benefit directly or indirectly from the development as well .
Public spending must be cost effective to ensure a steady rate of return from its investments to allow the country to develop and prosper .
Sufficient public funds are needed to develop different area of the country in terms of social , economical , defence and government administration .
To ensure that there are sufficient funds for the country's development , public spending on the age should be limited .
In order for the country to develop , funds are needed for investment in retraining of workers , expanding of economic structure and maintaining a high standard of education in various educational institutions .
Firstly funds are needed to invest in retraining of workers .
Due to globalization , training of workers is important to develop and maintain a highly skilled workforce .
The Singapore Budget reported that the government will be spending $457 .7 million of the public fund to subsidise training programmes for working Singaporeans .
In Singapore , the Ministry of Manpower and Workforce Development Agency had developed a program , which is called Skills Programme for Upgrading and Resilience , SPUR , in providing training courses at subsidies rate for people to attend .
Apart from working population to be re-skilled , the SPUR programme helps retrenched workers to learn new skills so that they can be reemployed and companies are able to send their personnel for training which helps to reduce retrenchments .
However , there are some older workers whom are unable to attend any courses despite being offered at subsides rate .
Dr Isa Hassan identified three factors on why older workers are not attending any courses .
Firstly , some older workers have weak command of English or are English illiterate as they are school dropouts .
This has discourages them from attending the training course as it is conducted in English .
Secondly , older workers have little time to attend training courses .
Some older workers are earning minimal wages thus they have to take a second job or part time job to boost their income earning .
Lastly the older workers have negative mindset of going back to school to be re-skilled .
Some older workers may feel embarrass or dislike going back to school at an old age .
Therefore to develop and maintain a highly skilled workforce , workers have to go for training courses to be re-skilled and retrenched workers have to learn new skills to be reemployed .
Lastly public spending are required to maintain high standard of education in various educational institutions .
A high standard of education is an important factor of maintaining a highly educated workforce in the country .
Investing in education is like investing in the future so the future generations are able to meet future challenges .
In Singapore , the government invests heavily on education through subsidising school fees of schools and post-secondary education institution .
In the Singapore Budget  , the Ministry of Education is investing $7 ,884 million into subsidising school fees .
This is to ensure that school fees are affordable and allowing every citizen to receive a proper education .
In conclusion , public spending on the age should be limited so that funds could be used in developing the country through retraining of workers , expanding of economic structure and maintaining a high standard of education in various educational institutions .
Funds being used for country's development to improve peoples' life wouldn't both the young and the old will benefit from it ?
Over the years , the problem of a rapidly aging population is becoming prominent and an area of concern for many countries .
Consequently , economic growth would be affected and many societal issues would surface .
Moreover , a fast aging population would inevitably increase the amount of government expenditure on healthcare and welfare programmes .
Although governments ought to provide financial assistance for the elderly , spending on other sectors of the country should not be neglected .
Therefore , public spending on the aged should be limited as funds should also cater to other areas of development such as education , training programmes , and even national defence .
Firstly , investment in education is vital in promoting economic growth .
Moreover , it prepares oneself to think independently and logically .
Through education , individuals are armed with the necessary skills and knowledge which would increase their productivity and competitiveness in the labour market .
The process of gaining knowledge is of paramount importance in developing countries as it would reduce the level of poverty and increase their ability to find quality jobs .
In this way , wealth would be generated and the economy would improve as their employability increases .
Nevertheless , it could be argued that the benefit of education in elevating economic growth is still unapparent .
There is no one type of education that is suitable for all societies .
Joshua also mentioned that it is unclear which type of education would lead to a higher economic growth .
Yet , one cannot deny the fact that a shortfall in educated people would restrict economic expansion .
Thus , it is crucial for countries to invest in the form of education that is desirable for its people to ensure greater economic development .
Secondly , countries should also focus on providing financial aid for trainings and seminars to be conducted for the working population .
Through the process of upgrading , individuals are empowered with the relevant skills and knowledge demanded by the job market .
For instance , the National Trade Union Congress  , of Singapore has been active in providing trainings for jobholders to upgrade their skills and knowledge .
In this way , they would have the proficiency to deal with any problems that may arise .
Nonetheless , it could be refuted that this might promote job hoping .
With the new skills and knowledge obtained , individuals would hunt for better paying and quality jobs .
Ilana claimed that people who possessed the essential skills would change occupations due to the lucrative salary offered by different companies .
However , funding of training programmes should still proceed as it would increase the productivity and capability of the working population in handling any challenges there might surface in the future .
Lastly , funding on national security should not be ignored .
A strong military defence helps to deter any possible threats and dangers that may occur .
This is of great importance in today's context where terrorism is becoming prominent .
In recent time , terrorists have accessed to sophisticated technologies that could create greater destruction to the surrounding and to instil fear in the people .
Hence , organisations and agencies related to national defence ought to receive adequate financial assistance for research and development .
In this way , military forces would then be armed with the latest equipment which is crucial to maintain their fighting capabilities .
For example , Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry stated that 13 million dollars are spent on national security yearly even though it places an immense pressure on the federal budget .
Therefore , continuous support on national defence is deemed important to ensure peace and harmony within the society .
In conclusion , nations should be careful in deciding the amount of spending on each area of development .
Expenditure should not be spent solely on the elderly as it would hinder the growth of other areas like education , trainings and national security .
Policy makers should realise and recognise that it is through careful planning and a combination of effective policies that would allow the nations to grow and flourish .
Aging population is a worldwide situation which will affect all countries in the world at different intensities and speed  .
This process is experienced by the developed countries at first but now the developing countries as well and it is especially rapid in this twenty-first century  .
As the proportion of elder persons in the world continues to increase , there is a need for the government to intervene as there will be many elderly who cannot support themselves .
Thus , the government needs to come up with policies to help them .
If this public spending on the elderly is not limited , it might have an impact on the countries in terms of national budgets and economies .
Therefore , public spending on the aged should be limited so that economic growth can be sustained , societal problems faced by the communities can be solved and other essential policies can be sustained .
By limiting public spending on the aged , some spending can be used to sustain economic growth , which is a key factor to the prosperity of a country .
According to Robert B . Friedland and Laura Summer  , "small differences in sustained economic growth will have a dramatic impact on the fiscal future of society ."
With little economic growth , society is limited in its ways to assist those who require assistance .
In contrast , with adequate economic growth , more can be done to help the people in need .
This is because people will have more spare money to help the needy and government will not need to increase taxations .
In addition , once economic growth is stable , there will be prosperity and employment rate will decrease .
The number of people in need of assistance will thus decrease .
Hence , it is crucial for a country to limit public spending on the aged and focus on economic growth so that there can be prosperity .
If public spending on the aged is not limited , the government will not be able to solve problems faced by society .
Many countries face problems such as housing , transportation and education  .
Policies will need to be introduced and thus will increase expenditures of the government .
This will increase the burden of the present and future working generations .
Through cutting down some spending on the aged , the funds can be used in solving problems faced by society and help to relieve the pressure faced by the current working force to support the elderly .
The government should channel its spending to sustain policies which are vital for the country .
It will need to focus on areas such as education and reducing elder dependency of the current elder generation .
With higher education , the future generations of working people tend to have higher incomes and thus can accumulate more wealth for future use when they are old  .
The government can also lower barriers to elder employment and stressing filial obligation  .
However , all these policies might not necessarily produce the desired results .
For example , though the government gives subsidies to companies to urge them to employ older workers , there may not be many who have the necessary skills .
The government will need to spend some money on retraining the elderly to equip them with the necessary skills for the job .
Thus , the government will need to be flexible in altering its policies .
Though there may be uncertainties that positive results will be yielded , it is still important to limit public spending on the aged so that some money can still be diverted to other important areas .
As more countries are facing the problem of an aging population , it is important to limit public spending on the aged so as to sustain economic growth , solve problems of the communities and support necessary policies for the country .
Different countries will need to have different solutions specially tailored to fit their own countries and public spending should be split evenly so that there is a balance in each area .
Presently , existing policies have helped Singapore extensively in providing ease to the foreseen aging crisis .
To achieve successful ageing , the government has implemented various policies to be well prepared in her golden years .
Firstly , in order to cope with the drastic fall in fertility rate , the government has encouraged Singaporeans to marry and procreate , and at the same time attract foreigners into our society .
Additionally , the government has also introduced a Marriage and Parenthood Package which includes bigger baby bonus , longer maternity leave , as well as increased subsidies at childcare centres to boost her population .
Unfortunately , these schemes did not seem to appeal to the vast majority as the birth rate still remains stagnant .
The next most apparent concerned is the need to ensure one's financial security during old age , either through retirement savings or an extension of employment years .
The government has implemented lifelong financial policy like the Central Provident Fund to prepare her people in planning and saving ahead for the ageing crisis .
Despite adopting the Central Provident Fund system , statistics has proven that only one in three Singaporeans are financially prepared .
Certainly , this statistics proved that not the entire nation is ready .
Therefore , it would only be wise if there are appropriate modifications made to the CPF scheme .
In recent years , awareness on the extension of employment years has also been promoted .
The society today has widened their perspective in employing aged workers and hence encouraged them to continue working even when they reached their retirement age .
A latest survey confirmed that most Singaporean companies agreed that retirement of older worker will be a great loss of valuable skills and knowledge .
Therefore , having an ageing workforce might not necessary be negative .
Elderly workers can also provide mentorship for the younger employees , imparting and sharing their valuable knowledge and past working experiences .
In an ageing society , the social aspects not only include the need for appropriate housing schemes but also health care systems for present and future generation of elderly .
An elderly-friendly built environment is a key principle to which an elderly can adjust and integrate themselves into the community .
For instance , accessible infrastructure provides a safe and comfortable environment for the elderly to recuperate their old age .
Indirectly , it also helps to maintain social network and allows them to participate in social activities .
Hence , The Housing Development Board has customised studio apartments equipped with elder-friendly fittings and features .
In addition , the lift upgrading programme was introduced to allow lifts to be provided at every level of high-rise HDB blocks for the convenience of the elderly .
Furthermore , other facelift programs in the older estates include ramps for wheelchair accessibility , fitness corner and covered walkways .
Hence , with these schemes , it is proven that elderly in Singapore are given top priority in the community .
Last but not least , to ensure that basic healthcare is affordable to all Singaporeans , Singapore has prepared her people with MediShield , MediSave and MediFund .
This is done by putting safety nets to ensure that healthcare remains affordable .
Besides , the government has decided to build more hospitals to cope with higher demands in the future .
Hence , with the multi-dimensional approach taken by the government , Singaporeans are able to enjoy quality healthcare services .
In conclusion , the government has done well to prepare the country for ageing population in the aspects of economy , social and population growth .
However , to allow ageing policies to be truly successful for the future generation , it should be reviewed and remodelled when necessary .
The society should also maintain a positive and mature attitude towards ageing population .
Most importantly , individuals should be responsible and self-reliant to take up ownership of the ageing issue .
Public spending has been increasing in many countries over the years .
With the world population ageing , many developed countries are trying to cope with high expenditure on the elderly .
However , there is a need to limit public spending on the elderly for the benefit of the country .
In the long run , investing in other areas would help to ease the problem of high expenditure on the elderly .
These funds needs to be diverted to other areas of development as it would help to improve the economy , benefit the younger generation and increase employment rate .
A nation needs a strong economy to support its expenditure .
A weak economy would have difficulty to divide its funds among the different areas .
Needless to say , the nation would have problem to support the increasing spending on the elderly in a bearish economy .
Hence , a strong economy would allow the nation to set aside more funds for the elderly .
Limiting the public spending on the elderly is only temporary .
This solution will benefit everyone in the long term .
Thus it is important for the nation to divert our public spending to with the aim of improve the economy .
Just like elderly is an important asset to a nation , children is an also important asset .
The nation can benefit the younger generation by diverting its fund on other areas .
Hoover  , 31st President of the United States , once said , "Children are our most valuable natural resource" .
Prof Ho also pointed out that children , being the future of a nation , are the most important asset .
This means that there is need to start early on each child's development .
The nation has great responsibility to help in developing the children's potential .
They will be the ones that will bring the nation to a greater height .
Therefore , funds should be diverted to assist on child's development .
There is another reason why public funding on the elderly should be limited .
A nation need to ensure the workforce is well trained to remain competitive .
Many countries , such as Denmark and Singapore , have started to retrain their workers  .

Since the economy affects how much funding a nation can spend on the elderly , it is important to ensure that the workforce receives enough training to improve the economy .
However , people should not rely on its government to provide funds for training .

But there is a need to remember that not all people can fully support themselves for training program .
As a result , the government should still provide basic incentives to aid people to remain competitive in the industry .
The three reasons provided explained why public funds on elderly should be limited and divert to other areas of development .
These areas will affect how much a nation can support its aging population .
Although the elderly are an important asset , but they are not the only asset a nation has .

By diverting the resources to develop on other areas , the elderly will benefit more in the future .

Policymakers should think of how the nation can solve the ageing population in the process of developing plans that will benefit the other areas .
To achieve this , we need to remember this assisting the elderly is important but building a nation is more important .

With regard to the problems , many countries focus much attention on it by introducing policies or by giving out funds in order to reduce the problems cause by the ageing population .

Assuming the same level of demand we have now , the need for nursing home beds will double in 10 years , triple in 20 years ," exclaimed Mr . Lim Boon Heng , Minister in the Prime Minister's Office  .

Whilst we spend resources resolving the issue pertaining to the aging population , implications such as the increase in societal costs could arise if welfare programs are curtailed , cut and restricted .

Through economic growth , funds can be used collectively and more profits and benefits can be allocated to the aged .

Singapore's constant upgrading of facilities such as having lifts that serve every floor of a building and replacing stairs with ramps , have facilitated the movement of the elderly .
However , there should always be a limit on public spending on the aged as funds can be diverted to the development of tourism , housing and education to promote the growth of a country .

Limiting public spending on the aged should be done so for the favours of other areas of the country's development .

As for the aged , although we cannot neglect them , but we can always provide them with just the right amount so that they will too get what they deserve from the society .
