I agree to a certain extent that current public spending on the aged should be limited so that this excess money could be used in other areas of the country's development .
The problem of an aging population has been a rising issue for most of the developed countries .
For instance , in Singapore , the number of people over the age of 65 will hit a high 19% by year 2030 . . Judging from the statistics , it shows that the elderly will form a relatively big portion of the country's population structure in the near future .
This implies that the impacts of the aging society will increase with time .
Therefore , it is important for these countries to tackle the situation before it reaches its peak .
But nonetheless , countries that are already dealing with the problem of aging population had identified the limitations of the policies that are implemented .
For example , in the context of Singapore , we have been holding pro-natalism campaigns since the 1980s , but there is still an insignificant rise in our replacement rate .
This indicates that perhaps the emphasis towards the investment of the country's revenue should be diverted to other area such as economy investments and improving the education system to further boost the rate of advancement of a country .
Firstly , public spending on the elderly should be limited and not be reduced .
But in additional , a pool of reserve funds should be available to cope with the rising aging population as well .
This is because the problem of an aging population affects the rate of development of a country on a long run .
And if this problem persists , it will gradually become a roadblock for the future advancement of a society .
As such , the country should still pay attention to the proper handling of the issue .
The approaches that countries usually adopt to solve the aging issue include the prolonging of working lives of the elderly and the provision of an array of welfare pension schemes for them .
Secondly , medical science has also come up with many types of anti-aging compact things called anti-aging drugs such as Deprenyl , one of the best anti-aging drugs currently available .
People will look younger and surprisingly , not just women but also men are now using the drugs .
Anyway , not all the drugs are good and cheap though so finding a suitable drug is a tough task to do .
Furthermore , the nutrition industry has also jumped in this battle against aging problem with milk and other products like quintessence that can help the aged from the depression of bone strength and the cells of the heart from damage like that benefit of milk thistle and many more .
As people , especially the youth , feel healthier , they will work harder and earn more money for their future life .
It would not only help the government to reduce the amount of money they have to spend on the welfare program for the elderly , but also provide the elder a chance to have a rich old-life .
If people have to work for themselves , they will try their best to earn as much as possible .
Therefore , they may get even more money for their own than receiving from the government's welfare .
However , taking too many anti-aging medical products like medicine in general is not as good as supporting yourself with a suitable and healthy diet .
Those natural solutions to anti aging process include fruits and vegetables .
Fruits like apples , strawberries , etc contain ellagic acid that has the capacity to hinder the growth of tumors within the body and those such as cantaloupe , peaches , etc contain lycopene guarding body's cells and organs like heart , bladder from damage caused by free radicals .
Vegetables would also demonstrate the same benefits in antioxidant capabilities , for example , Genistein in soybeans works as cancer genes' enzymes' inhibitor .
Besides , people who usually do gymnastic will live longer and healthier than those do not .
Some may argue that fruit and gymnastic do not play any part in easing the aging process .
In facts , by doing physical exercise , their immunity increases , make them immunize with lots of bacteria and viruses .
A healthy diet along with gymnastic will prevent some disease to germ .
To countries with old population , medical science needs to be considered , and invested more in so that we will have more and better ways of easing the aging process .
With the achievements of medical science , treatments , medicine and dietary habits , humans get not only happiness and health but also a better longer life .
Furthermore , medical science is one of the effective solutions for aging process , which help ease the economic burden for the country by reducing the money for elder's welfare , diverting it to other areas of the country's development .
The aging population in Singapore has been growing .
The percentage of residents aged 65 and above has increased from 6 .8% in 1998 to 8 .7% in 2008  .
This is expected to reach 20% in 2030  .
Thus , measures for aiding the increasing aging population in terms of healthcare subsidies and daily expenditures are to be proactively prepared .
Some strategies can be introduced to deal with the aging population .
Firstly , greater productivity should be encouraged with the younger generation to be cost-efficient and productive .
Secondly , filial obligation should be stressed among the younger generation .
Lastly , people could be encouraged to have proactive savings when they are secured with a job to save up for the rainy days  .
Therefore , the aging population is not an insurmountable problem , funds could be sub-divided for the expenditure in other sectors such as education , tourism and Research and Development  .
Firstly , education is one of the most important aspects in Singapore as it secures the future of the younger generation .
Singapore has institutions with outstanding records of interactive learning and a bilingual education system .
At tertiary level , locally leading universities are such as the National University of Singapore  , and the Nanyang Technological University  .
Funds are constantly pumped into the education system for the financing of students and also for constant improvements of the education system .
For example , the Tuition Grant Scheme is provided for the subsiding of high school fees .
Therefore , by investing in the education sector , the future of the younger generation will be secured .
In turn , they would be able to support the aged thus reducing the dependency of the aged on the government .
Secondly , the tourism sector is a revenue generator for Singapore through the various tourist attractions such as Sentosa and the upcoming Integrated Resorts .
Hence , funds have to be constantly injected for new tourist attractions and contingency plans in the case of an economy crisis .
For example , in February 2009 , the Singapore Tourism Board announced that an incentive of $90 million has been provided for the BOOST which is targeted at aiding the tourism sector in times of challenges  .
Thus , funds are essential to ensure that the tourism sector is filled with vibrant attractions and is prepared for any crisis .
This ensures a constant flow of revenue for the economic stability of Singapore .
Lastly , R&D is extensively utilized with various purposes such as major institution projects , innovation and creativity in new developments and for environmental concerns .
For example , R&D is supported with the National Research Foundation which focuses into areas such as the Environmental and Water Technologies and the Interactive and Digital Media .
A total of $1 .55 billion is invested in these areas  .
In addition , R&D discovered the NEWater and ensured the consistent high quality for the past few years  .
Although , the R&D sector is important , the aging population must not be neglected as a portion of the old may still remain vulnerable .
Due to globalization , the aged has become richer and of better health .
However , a portion of the population could still need financial help such as those of lower incomes .
Thus , financial benefits should be provided to those that are in need of help .
In contrast , schemes such as the Central Provident Fund and the Medisave schemes do cover a large proportion of expenses .
Hence , funds spent on the aged should be limited in order to accommodate for the high expenses in the three sectors that contribute a large proportion of revenue to the economy .
In conclusion , R&D brings about innovation and inventions , hence bringing various business opportunities and revenue to Singapore .
On the whole , the aging population is not insurmountable problem .
Hence , public spending on the aged should be limited in order for funds to be sub-divided among the education , tourism and the R&D sectors which are the main sources of revenue .
In turn , with more revenue being generated , more benefits and financial aids could be provided to the aged which benefits the country as a whole .
Aging population is a global issue nowadays , especially in the developed countries .
This will soon affect the Asian countries with more serious impacts .
According to Jackson and Howe's major findings , today , 8 of 16 nations of Western Europe have a median age of 40 or higher  .
By 2050 , 6 will have a median age of 50 or higher , so will Japan , the East Asian Tigers , and 17 of the 24 nations in Eastern Europe and the Russian sphere .
Due to the increasing aging population size , public spending on the aged has been rising .
Hence , this has exerted more pressure on the society , which could lead to problems such as low social security , economic depression and inadequate education .
Hence , it is essential to limit the public spending on the elderly , so more money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
Setting limits on the spending on the aged would raise indignation among the elderly , especially people without a savings , poor single women , and the illiterate .
Some may say it is inhumane when limiting the spending on the aged .
However , policy makers should always look at the interest of the whole country rather than just focusing on particular one area .
Additionally , the government can conduct specific tests such as the means- test for those who really require financial support .
In conclusion , it is applicable to make the spending on the aged limited .
The reduced spending on the aged can then be invested in other areas for instance education .
When the education is enhanced , graduates would have a higher chance of getting a job and hence contributing to the economic development of the country .
In addition , together with the development of economy , the young adults would be capable to support their parents .
Furthermore , they could enjoy a high living standard and security in life .
Generally , the government would have enough budgets to empower the stable development of the country , and to maintain the welfare and pension system at an acceptable level .
To illustrate these are only some out of many benefits which public can be achieved from the reduced of the aged spending .
To conclude , it is vital for the government to limit the spending on the aged to a reasonable level , and which money can be invested in different aspects of the country's development .
In the short run , the country may face difficulties , but in the long run it will be beneficial to the society .
Medicine nowadays gives us strong belief that aging process is something we can alter .
Medically speaking , we can expect longevity if our body is able to continuously re-generate living cells .
Results of many research have revealed that there are certain components which help to maintain a healthy cell like antioxidants , enzymes , hormones or "no cellular waste"  . . .  .
Together with cell collapse , diseases like heart disease or cancer , at the same time , speed up the process .
Luckily , modern medicine can provide us with procedures to cure our serious diseases and to prevent aging .
For example , doctors nowadays can be able to build a complete plan to slow down the aging process such plan includes individualized nutritional , hormonal , dietary and exercise program .
After six months joining the program , biological age of a man can decrease by 20 years .
With currently available anti-aging strategies , people can confidently look forward to a longer lifetime .
Besides , there are also some drugs which can be used as an anti-aging treatment like the Estrogen hormone  .
In other words , medicine can be used effectively to ease the aging process .
Although almost everyone agrees that economics is the vital component in the world's life , not many people realize that it also play an important part in easing the aging process .
The effects caused by global economy indirectly control the speed of aging .
In developed countries with strong economies , health issues and other social services are sure to be cared much more than in undeveloped ones .
With a simple comparison between Western societies with those from Africa , we can see significant difference in life expectancy and actual lifespan .
While Western people tend to live long happy lives with small number of serious diseases , people from African countries usually have much shorter life expectancy .
However , economic problems may cause very bad impacts on the efforts of slowing down aging process .
As the economy goes up , there are more concerns to be taken care of and people get busier .
This will reflect in their bad habits like over-working and also harm their mental health , which will shorten their lifespan .
After several researches , it is not surprising to know the fact that , usually , the richest man is not the happiest man .
But again , these are individual's lifestyle so a person should be able to change it easily by himself putting some understanding and efforts .
Hence , economics , in some ways , is providing a useful helping hand to ease the aging process .
In conclusion , aging is nowadays a global issue .
Human beings , with their intelligence , can find out ways to ease the aging process .
The only problem left is that with a longer life , what will a person do to contribute back to the society and next generations ?
Aging population and longer life expectancy will inevitably lead to rapidly increasing elder residents .
Housing , which is one the basic needs of elderly people , is significant because elderly need a safe , pleasing and interactive environment for their old age .
Current housing developments and policies have provided better choice to enhance the quality of life of older people .
Government agencies have strived to promote an elderly-friendly physical environment .
Policymakers have implemented various strategies to ensure older people own a home while enjoy sufficient retirement income for old age dependency .
Some housing schemes are also introduced to facilitate mutual care and support for elderly .
Housing policies and schemes play a critical role in easing the aging process .
Most countries have provided various housing schemes to ensure adequate supply of affordable accommodation for aging population .
Under these schemes , housing developers are subsidized with lower land costs to build up retirement housings , while needy elderly are given priority to access to public housing .
It may be objected that there are a number of elderly people are "asset-rich , cash-poor" .
They own a house but do not have sufficient fund to meet their basic needs in old age  .
Nevertheless , there are policies that allow elderly to monetize their housing assets .
These people are encouraged to sublet their house or to downsize to a more affordable one .
In Singapore , the Lease Buyback Scheme helps the elderly in smaller flats to monetize flat value whilst continue to stay in the same flat .
Hence , we can notice that the housing needs as well as the financial needs of elderly have been effectively tackled by various public policies .
Finally , a harmonious and caring elderly society has been promoted through housing schemes as well .
On the one hand , policymakers have carried out a range of policies to encourage younger children to take care of their elderly parents by staying with them .
In Hong Kong , the Harmonious Families Priority Scheme allows families to live in one flat or two nearby flats when they apply for public housing .
On the other hand , senior activity centres are also developed in housing estate to encourage elderly remain integrated in society .
These centres provide social and recreational activities , as well as community-based care and support services for elderly residents .
Indeed , these strategies have effectively enabled elderly people to lead a fruitful andmeaningful social life .
Clearly , the quality of life of elderly people has been more contented and enjoyable through various housing developments , policies and improvement programmes .
These efforts have successfully eased the issues in aging population .
We can look forward to a blending of housing schemes and developments in future that help the older people to live as independent as possible .
Today , many governments around the world are particularly concerned with problems brought about by a fast ageing population .
One cause for this is attributed to the era of baby boomers , who are now mostly in their late fifties or early sixties .
In Singapore , this constitutes to 31% of Singapore's population and approximately half the workforce .
Being born from 1946 to 1964 , they are fast approaching the national retirement age of 63 .
In other words , in 10 years time , half of the current employed citizens at work would have retired .
Such manpower shortages are examples of how an ageing population would have a detrimental effect on the economy .
Among some other issues that the elderly face are those of deteriorating physical condition and old-age sickness , which might cause a strain on the local healthcare system , and financial needs , which will threaten to drain the government's coffers .
In anticipation of this , governments have set in place policies as well as encouraged initiatives to ease the ageing process for both the individual and society .
In the context of Singapore , some of these include mandatory personal retirement funds , development of the health sector to better manage an ageing population as well as encouraging longer working lives .
Despite some of the limitations of these policies , they have certainly eased the ageing process in Singapore .
One such policy in Singapore is the Central Provident Fund  .
Set up by the government in 1955 , it serves as a retirement fund for all Singaporean citizens .
CPF is a mandatory savings plan for an individual , where a portion of their income is set aside in this fund , and will be made available to them once they have retired .
This policy provides for financial security for the elderly as they are financially dependent , and need not rely on public initiatives or their children for money in their golden years .
With this policy , the government is then able to redirect these resources to more vital sectors .
Critics of this position point out their concerns over the misuse of the funds once it is made available .
Being unsure of their future financial requirements , the elderly might be unable to plan for their expenditure , and might drain their finances too quickly .
However , a recent introduction by the Singaporean government has eliminated this problem .
Participants of this new , compulsory scheme , named Lifelong Income for The Elderly will receive lifelong monthly payouts from their CPF accounts .
Instead of being granted with a lump sum of money upon retirement , this ensures that the elderly do not exhaust their retirement funds too quickly , easing reliance on public funds .

Lastly , developments in medicine have also helped in the ageing process .
With new technological advances , the elderly now have a variety of medical treatments for most old-age related illnesses .
For example , advances in surgery have helped developed a non-invasive surgery technique for glaucoma , one of the main leading causes of blindness , in which the elderly are at a higher risk of contracting .
This non-invasive technique will help to minimize any potential surgical risks .
One impending problem with such rapid technological advances in medicine would be the rising costs of healthcare , brought about by the intensive research processes to develop new cures and treatments .
With most of the elderly retired and no source of income , they might be unable to fund their medical expenses should the need arise .
In view of this , the Singaporean government has in place a variety of measures to minimise the occurrence of this situation .
One such measure would be Medisave .
Introduced by the Ministry of Health in 1984 , Medisave would set aside a portion of an individual's income to their account , which will be available to fund medical expenses should the need arise .
With this fund , most Singaporeans will go into retirement with a sum of money collected from their working life which can be used to pay for medical expenses .
This reduces the possible reliance of public funds for funding of medical expenses for the elderly , which might result in taxpayers shouldering a larger burden of the alderfly's medical expenses .
In conclusion , this article has illustrated that the current policies in Singapore have helped ease the ageing process to a large extent .
As shown , policies such as CPF , raising the retirement age and the development of healthcare policies have helped to ease the ageing process in the society , thereby reducing the societal effects of an ageing population .

It is unethical to embark on the developments of a country at the expense of the aged .
By limiting the fiscal spending on the elderly , the extra funds created can be diverted to areas such as education , which has potential long-term benefits for a country .
As such , it will be even tougher for the government to cater to the growing needs of the elderly due to a budget constraint , and this problem will most likely pertain to countries in face of a persisting ageing population , such as Japan .
Opponents of this position argued that there is no need to divert too many resources to the elderly because they no longer contribute to the society upon their retirement .
Instead , these resources should be used in other areas that provide long-term benefits to the country .
For instance , the investing of funds for research and development will raise the productive capacity of the country , thereby attracting more foreign direct investments .
However , it is wrong to regard the aged as a burden , because the aged is a national asset who should not be neglected by the society .
Even after they have retired , they still do contribute the society but it is just done by a different mean , such as taking care of their grandchildren on behalf of their children who are out at work .
In this way , they help to coordinate the work life and family life of the working adults .
Consequently , the aged , as well as their insights and experiences , is a valuable asset to the society and thus the public spending on the aged should not be limited .
Lastly , the limiting of public spending on the aged will increase the financial hardship of the elderly .
This is faced by the elderly who are either single or have no children , and it is made worse for elderly who have low educational level .
In their younger days , their earnings might just be sufficient for them to cope with their daily living expenses and hence they have negligible or no savings .
When they fall ill , the high costs of medical fees discouraged them from seeking medical care , and as a result , their health conditions deteriorated over time .
As they aged , they became more susceptible to diseases , such as osteoporosis .
Thus , it is inevitable that their demand for healthcare will increase with age .
It will come to the time when they are left with no choice but to seek medical care for their illnesses , but since they are left with little savings , they are unlikely able to pay for the medical expenses .
It may be objected that it is one's social responsibility to be healthy , and to be accountable for his own medical expenses should he seek healthcare services , instead of relying on the government for subsidy to lower their financial burden for such expenses .
Jenson mentioned that the ageing population has accelerated the growth in healthcare spending , and this will lead to a fiscal crisis as increasing pressure is exerted on the fiscal budget .
However , the presence of a fiscal crisis might not necessarily be attributed by the fiscal spending on the aged .
The facilities built for the elderly should not be seen as a negative asset because these facilities are not built just for one time usage , but instead they provide long-term benefits to every individual of the country because ageing is an unavoidable process .
This applies similarly for the healthcare subsidies , as one will hope that he can be entitled to such privileges when he has limited savings , regardless of his age .
Hence , it is infeasible to limit public spending on the aged .
Old-aged citizens will bring along different illnesses and diseases where spending will be required for basic healthcare and treatment .
According to the National Institute of Aging  , experts predicted that there will be a huge raise in disability resulted from increases in age-related chronic disease in all regions of the world .
This implies that public spending should not be limited as it will be required to subsidise the costly healthcare expenses .
This is because the old-age population will not be able to afford the financial burden for the recurrent treatment of their illnesses .
Truly , old-aged citizens accounted for greater than 40% of the total hospitalisation days in the public sector hospitals in 2006  .
On the other hand , it is fortunate that the Singapore Central Provident Fund  , which is the fundamental pillar of our social security framework for the old-aged , lend itself readily to provide citizens for the needs of aging population .
Healthcare in Singapore are made affordable through the administration of the Medisave , Medishield and Medifund framework .
Each citizen CPF account consists of medisave , medishield and medifund , which helps individuals to put aside portion of their income to meet their medical expenses especially when they are old .
The medisave accounts assist older Singaporeans pay for or subsidise part of their expensive medical bills .
This would help to ease the public spending on the aged and money can be spent on other area of Singapore's development .
However , Singaporeans still enjoy heavy subsidies in public hospital , especially in the lower class wards .
Direct subsidies borne by the Singapore government have increased from $850 million in 2001 to more than $1 .6 billion in 2007 and are forecasted to exceed $2 .2 billion by 2012  .
As the population ages , the need for healthcare services will increase .
Public spending will keep increasing and should not be limited as the aging population in Singapore continues .
In conclusion , fertility rates are declining while life expectancies are increasing around the globe .
As a result , populations are aging rapidly and Singapore is not exempted from this trend .
The ratios of Singapore citizens aged sixty-five and above will climb from one in twelve in 2007 to one in eight in 2020  .
Therefore the public spending on the aged should not be limited and should fluctuate according to changes such as impending demographic shift , population growth and healthcare expenses .
However , it is also important and responsible for Singaporeans to plan ahead so that they can depend on several sources of income to sustain their old-age livings and at the same time ease the burden of public spending on the aged .
Employers should also do a part in changing their traditional perceptions that old-aged employees are unproductive and potential burden to society  .
Employers should try to retain and retrain older workers for them to be retained in the labour force , this will extend working life of citizens and they will be in a better economic position to sustain their own old-age livings .
Public spending is the amount of {money} expended by a {government} to {pay} for defence , development projects , education , social security , {health} , {infrastructure} , {law and order } maintenance .
It represents a large share of Gross Domestic Product and has a major impact on the productivity of the whole economy .
Public spending on social security and health care will directly benefit the aged people in the country .
This essay argues that the public spending on aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other area of the country's development .
Elderly in a country are usually supported mainly by public spending .
It is argued that the government should provide more public assistants to the elderly and not to limit the amount of spending on them .
However , some people may not have realized that there are many countries which are already having high public spending .
Schuknecht and Tanzi stated that many countries had peaked at almost 52% of Gross Domestic Product over the past twenty years .
From these large amounts of public spending , most countries tend to spent more than half of them on social protection and health and are used mainly to help the aged .
Mahal and Berman mentioned that several studies have indicated that per person expenses of health and social protect on elderly are usually much greater than those non-elderly .
If countries are to increase their public spending on the aged further , it may cause the proportion of public spending to be spent on other important areas , such as infrastructure and education , to be even lesser .
This could eventually slow down the productivity of the whole economy .
Therefore , public spending on the elderly should be limited and controlled to prevent it from increasing further , which may cause the economy to slow down .
Population aging is progressing rapidly in many countries and in the near future , this may push up the public spending on social security and healthcare costs .
In viewing the aging population problem , some people argued that we should not limit but to provide more public and financial assistances for elderly due to the increasing number of elderly in an aging population .
However , the increase in public spending means that working people may need to have higher tax contributions , as public spending is supported mainly by taxation .
Minford and Wang stated that researches have shown that the increase in tax to GDP had reduced GDP growth and lowered the output per worker .
In an aging population , having increasing tax contribution from the shrinking workforce can be a burden to the working people .
Straits Time mentioned that the huge increases in public spending could slow down countries' economic growth .
In aging society , it is important to limit and have control over the increasing public spending on aged .
If not , there could be a drop on the GDP and eventually cause the percentage of public spending to be spent on aged to reduced too .
It should be the responsibility of the country to ensure that all aged , who have contributed to the society , to be properly assisted in their old age .
However , when public spending on the aged is not limited and allowed to be raised continuously , everyone in the country is going to suffer in long term .
There might be one day that the country's work force can no longer support the extremely high amount of public spending .
This may cause the working people to be under pressure and financially strapped .
It may then cause them to be not able to take good care of their elderly parents and neglect their needs .
Toh mentioned that researches have shown that during the global economic recession , there are more elderly abuse cases reported .
Thus , one of the ways to prevent this from happening is to have control over the public spending on elderly , so as to prevent further increase in tax contribution .
Besides that , a country should try to divert a higher percentage of public spending to other areas that might contribute country's growth and development , such as the infrastructure and development project .
By investing more money in these areas , a country may generate higher return and has higher GDP growth .
This may again increase the amount of public spending to be spent on the aged .
It is no doubt that a country should do its best to assist and support the elderly .
However , countries have to be mindful on the amount of money that has to be spent on the social protection and health for the elderly .
We have to ensure that it is efficient and effective in spending this large amount money and prevent it from rising too high .
Having to spend too large amount of public spending on the elderly will definitely be a burden to both the country and working people .
Thus , we should try to divert more money to other areas of the country's development and promote higher GDP growth .
This can definitely benefit the aged people and without adding burden to the country's economy , working people and next generation .
Singapore has one of the fastest aging populations in the world and is expected to be considered a country with an aging population by the year 2030  .
This alarming trend is stimulated by declines in fertility rate , medical advances , and better health care which have resulted in longer life expectancy .
With this rising aging population , many issues related to old age become significant , especially the public spending issue .
Even though this trend would most likely affect Singapore negatively , the government must not only concern themselves with the increasing expenditures on the aged and try to divert the budget for the aged to other areas of development .
They must also consider the impact on the elderly if there were no financial support for the elderly .
In addition , they should also consider the contributions that the elderly could give and had given to the country .

The Korea population is graying rapidly , and the proportion of elderly with the aged of 65 and over is expected to reach 13 .2 per cent in 1960 .
Korea needs to reform its national policies if it hopes to create a better and sustainable future society as there will be a lot of negative impacts to the country such as inevitable labor shortage , increase in public spending and healthcare problems if the ageing population continues to grow disproportionately with the country's fertility rate .
This is supported by Jones  , stating that the increasing in this population will have strong physical , psychological , social , cultural , economical and cultural implications .
Therefore , in view of this acute phase , current research and policies have been carried out by the Korean government and have helped to buffer the ageing process .
A government pension system , namely the National Pension which is financed in part by employee's contributions and employer's liability for general workers was introduced in 1988 for retirees over 60  .
It is the main- old- age pension program covering the majority of Korean workers .
However , this policy executed by the government did not attain its goal when many of the retirees chose to take their pension in a lump sum at retirement .
This implies that the financial security for these elderly in the future will be strongly affected if they do not use their pension wisely .
Considering this matter , in 2004 , the National Pension Service started finding jobs for the elderly and the project was made permanent in 2006 .
There was an overwhelming result when job placements rose from around 30 ,000 in 2004 to more than 83 ,000 in 2006 and 196 ,000 in the first half of this year .
Despite this progress , there still are not enough openings for the baby boomers .
So , local governments have established "silver jobs" fair like chaperons for children returning home from late- night cram schools , gas station attendants , opinion survey interviewers and wedding officiators to recruit elderly job seekers as part of a government effort to assist a rapidly growing population of older Koreans in a changing society .

Social service programs have been introduced for the welfare of the elderly .
It can be divided into two groups , consisting of the recreational programs and community programs .
Under these programs , the elderly are able to obtain personal needs and social- psychological developments needs amongst others .
For example , under the community program , there is this sub- program called the Home- Help Program which provides home- help services to the elderly without any fees incurred .
Around 35 ,000 volunteer home helpers were active , linked to 552 voluntary organizations in 2001 with the provision of government in financial assistance for recruiting , training and maintaining volunteers .
Although many beneficial services has been provided to the elderly , this program still does not seem to be so effective as volunteers may or may not render their services whenever the elderly need them .
It is not a mandatory or binding issue for them to always lend a hand to the elderly .
Therefore , the government should think of a better way to tackle this problem so that the society will have a concept that their voluntary work is not an optional choice , but a domestic routine to serve the elderly who need their assistance .
Due to the low fertility rate and the growing of elderly in the society , there is a shortage of workforce in certain occupations .
To keep an ideal and constant working age group and ensure the stability of manpower in Korea , the government has been inviting immigrants to join the workforce .
The number of foreign labors has grown from a few thousand to estimates of 168 thousand in 1999 and 358 thousands in 2005 .
This replacement migration in coping with the population in Korea has not only helped to ease the ageing process when the older Koreans started to retire which resulted in certain downfalls of manpower in certain specialization , it also has helped to buffer the current shortage of labor in the market .
Unfortunately , the idea did not seem to give only positive impacts , but also negative consequences when there are around 65 percent of the immigrants imported in 1999 are working illegally  .
The large volumes of immigrants to fill up the labor shortage due to population aging also arouse fears of loss of national identity  .
Thus , even though the adoptions of the immigrant policy have helped to ease the ageing process , it might not be the best policy to conquer this matter .
Intyre once said that old age throughout this century has been seen as a 'social problem' and this is true when the government started off with all kinds of policies to ease this matter .
With the demographic ageing in Korea's population , priority on constructing a sustainable socioeconomics system at the beginning of the twenty- first century to cope with the rapid ageing of populations must be placed .
Peterson commented that in many developed countries , an ageing population will lead to a shrinking workforce , long- term stagnation and along with it a decline in real GDP .
Nevertheless , we agree with Frieden , who concluded: Ageing is not lost youth but a new stage of opportunity and strength .
Therefore , leaders of today must design a desirable socioeconomic structure under the pressure of an ageing population and environment constraints by identifying the necessary policy tools to attain stable and sustainable growth before taking any effective actions .

Global aging population is one of the most critical and pressing issues that the leaders of the twenty first century face .
According to the United Nations report , the proportion of population aged 60 or above in the developed and less developed countries is projected to reach 33% and 25% respectively by 2050 .
The change in the age structure of a country's population will has a profound impact on the political , social and economical conditions of that country .
In view of the increasing number of elderly , governments across the globe have implemented various policies to help them cope with the aging process .
Aging process here refers to the problems that will come about as one grows old , such as healthcare issues , financial problems and many more .
Although there are already policies in place , much changes and improvements have to be done to effectively help the elderly address their growing concerns and improve their quality of life .
Advocate of government policies often argue that many countries have provided financial security and support for the aged through policies such as social pension and compulsory savings  .
While this may be true , such measures are ineffective in reducing old-age poverty as many elderly have little understanding of how the system work and do not possess the necessary financial knowledge to manage their savings and allowance .
As such , government has to put more emphasis and effort to impart financial education and provide money advice and information to help the elderly better finance their savings and incomes .
Due to the complexity of these policies , some elderly do not even know how to use them to their benefits , hence rendering them worthless .
In addition , a study by shows that old people often do not know how to optimize their savings and spend their money carelessly .
As a result , their savings and incomes are exhausted quickly .
In another separate study by  , it is stated that around 67% of the respondent think that the compulsory saving in Hong Kong cannot provide them with a happy retirement life as they do not understand about the benefits of Mandatory Provident Fund scheme and hence do not care about it .
Therefore it is necessary that the government highlight the availability and benefits of their financial policies and equip the aged with basic financial education to increase the effectiveness of these policies .

Secondly , there is a need to increase the efficiency of the social and health care system by curbing the rising cost of health care service and making it more accessible to the aged .
Critics of this position often point out that there are already established health care system and policies in place to subsidise the cost of health care and that changes are frequently introduced to improve them .
Despite the changes that are implemented , such measures are insufficient to help the aged as the root problems of rising cost and increasing inaccessibility are not addressed .
As pointed out by Tanner  , rising health care cost is a global phenomenon .
Costly health care system is highly unsustainable as it strains government budget and imposes a great burden on the aged and their families' finances .
As a result , the savings and the income of the elderly may be used up quickly or large portion of their finances have to be spent on health care services .
One possible solution is to encourage people to buy more health insurance  .
Many elderly are uninsured as they fail to realise that many of the illness that can be prevented or treated cheaply in the early stages very often worsen into critical conditions .
In addition , although there are health care system in place , there are still many who do not have access to them .
This is due to the confusing systems that access elderly base on ambiguous criteria that makes it harder for them to obtain the service and simply lack of information and advice  .
Hence , containing rising health care cost and increasing accessibility are essential to help ease the aging process .
Lastly , more should be done to increase the labour participation rate of the aged in the workforce .
An argument against this is that adequate effort has been put in to encourage later retirement and longer working lives .
Despite the effort , employment level of the aged still remain low as the elderly continue to face discrimination at work .
Older workers are often viewed as less dynamic and less creative as compared to the younger workers , thus they are less preferred .
Unless there is a change in attitude towards the older workers , it will be difficult for them to be find jobs , which can keep them active and support their financial needs .
Discrimination towards the older workers is more evident during the recession .
There was a 46% increase in the number of unemployed people in the UK whereas the biggest increase is those aged 60 and above with an increase of 65%  .
A possible solution for this is to scrap national default retirement age which often give the power to employers to retrench those above this retirement age .
Also the government can give benefits or incentives to older workers to encourage them to go for re-training in order to increase their employability .
Employment can reduce elder dependency and provide some financial support for the aged to finance some of their activities .
In conclusion , current policies are inadequate in allowing the elderly to retire happily .
Changes should be made to the current financial , health care and employment policies for the aged so that they can better help the elderly .
There is a need to equip the elderly with the proper finance management to make the financial policies effective .
Also , cost reduction and increasing accessibility are vital for an efficient health care system .
In addition , reducing age discrimination in the workplace must be enforced to better help the elderly secure jobs .
Subsequently , these policies should be revised and improved frequently as the needs and concerns of the aged will change over time .

Public spending is the amount of taxation collected by the government to provide services for its people such as education , health care and law and order maintenance .
The dominating population in countries that are experiencing growing aging population is the elderly citizens because the demographic trends change had led rapid increment of the seniors rather than the young ones .
If the number of elders continues to increase , pertinent problems will definitely escalate .
Therefore , government should spend more on the aged not only to ease their aging process but also to tackle problems arising from a growing population .
Despite the government consistent spending on the old , public spending on the aged should not be limited but should be used accordingly based on the circumstances .
